PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the Senate that I received a letter from Senator John Wayne Olsen today resigning his place as a senator for the State of South Australia. Pursuant to the provisions of section 21 of the Constitution, I notified the Governor of South Australia of the vacancy in the representation of that State caused by the resignation. I table the documents.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette—Mr President, I seek leave to make a very brief statement.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the testimony he gave on 4 March this year in the Meissner case that he had met Mr Joe Meissner as recently as 1986 at the arrangement of a Mr Warren Anderson and that the Minister, in his own car, had driven Mr Meissner around Sydney's eastern suburbs while having a discussion. What interest could a senior Cabinet Minister possibly have in meeting in such a clandestine way a known criminal and standover man who, to the Minister's certain knowledge, had been convicted of stealing Army machine guns to sell to the underworld and who, the Minister claimed in this chamber, had been thrown out of the Australian Labor Party six years previously at the Minister's instigation? What was the purpose of the meeting?

—I am not certain how much it relates to my ministerial duties, but I will give an answer. That was, of course, before I became a Minister and it was at a time when a Mr Gary Sturgess from the Premier's office in New South Wales was wandering around with $100,000 in a suitcase seeking to give that to Mr Meissner, as I understand it, with John Dowd, who was then the Attorney-General, in an effort to get him to say something about me and about the Labor Party. I thought it sensible to inquire as to what the $100,000 might be for and what it might buy. I would also like to find out who gave the $100,000, from where it came and, given that at the end Mr Meissner did not accept it, who got it and where it is now.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Australian Bureau of Statistics recently published details concerning the level of industrial disputation during January? Can he advise the Senate whether they show that the decline in disputation achieved as a result of the accord is continuing?

—The answer to that is yes. We have now recorded a few records in Australia. January 1992 recorded the lowest total number of working days lost through industrial disputes since the Australian Statistician began measuring that performance. The States of Victoria and Queensland recorded the lowest number of working days lost since the series began and Western Australia recorded the lowest number of working days lost since February 1968.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, to the year to January 1992 only the State of New South Wales performed very badly. Its record was to have industrial disputes running at four times the level of the average for Australia in terms of the number of working days lost per thousand employees. If we disaggregate the New South Wales figure for the major blip that occurred when there was wholesale confrontation in New South Wales over State industrial legislation, New South Wales still has, on a State basis, the worst performance of any State in Australia in industrial disputes.

I think it is quite fair to say that this is the continuance nationally of a trend that has occurred under the Labor Government since 1983. Basically it is due to the accord. It is due to the change that we are fostering in the structure of industrial relations as well to what is now coming through increasingly—an attitudinal change in the workplace to encourage teamwork in place of confrontation and conflict, and cooperation instead of disputation.

There are signs now around Australia that in the workplaces of this country there is a move to world best practice; that workplace bargaining is beginning to take hold, and the amendments that I propose to make to the Act in the very near future will help to speed up that; that our wages policy has helped to deliver the big `O' in inflation for the last quarter and the very low level of inflation that this country is now enjoying; and that our wages policy settings are directed to locking in that low level of inflation as a permanent feature of the Australian economy, while recognising and addressing the real needs of Australian workers.

Our commitment to training in the One Nation statement will encourage Australian workers to work smarter through better training and better skills formation. In our settings, too, the Industrial Relations Commission—unlike the Opposition, we do support this independent body—continues to ensure that fairness and reason prevail in industrial relations, not the law of the jungle as is being advocated by the Opposition. On the basis of the figures that have now been tabulated by the Statistician, we are looking forward, having regard to all of the factors that I have mentioned, to a surge in productivity coming through the economy; to a major productivity surge being evident in the economy in the later part of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to comments by ACTU Secretary and Reserve Bank board member, Mr Kelty, reported in today's Australian Financial Review, foreshadowing that at tomorrow's meeting of the Reserve Bank board he will support a one per cent reduction in official interest rates. Does the Minister believe that it is appropriate for board members publicly to put forward their views on interest rates the day before a board meeting which will consider this very issue?

—I have not read Mr Kelty's remarks in detail. But, from what I have seen of them, I do not interpret them as doing that. Mr Kelty has said certainly that there is room for further cuts in interest rates. This is his view—it has been his publicly articulated view for some time, as it has been the view of many other commentators. I will look at precisely what Mr Kelty said and see whether I have anything to add.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer. But surely he is not equating other commentators with Mr Kelty, who is a member of the Reserve Bank board which has to make that decision. My supplementary question is: given the Prime Minister's close relationship with Mr Kelty, is this another indication of Mr Keating's boast when he was Treasurer that he had the Reserve Bank in his pocket? Will the Minister tell the Australian people just who is running economic policy in this country—the Government or the ACTU?

—The first part of the question had nothing to do with the second. Whatever the former Treasurer said at the time, I do not regard that as an accurate statement of the Government's relationship with the Reserve Bank at present.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to a report in this morning's Age that a group of 27 nations had signed an agreement about new controls on nuclear weapons related materials. What is Australia's role in this process and what is Australia doing more generally to halt the spread of nuclear weapons?

—Australia has been playing a very active role in recent times, particularly since the end of the Gulf war, in strengthening the nuclear non-proliferation regime, particularly International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards and controls on nuclear exports. We have also been putting international pressure on North Korea specifically to fulfil the non-proliferation obligations it has entered into.

PARA.TAB: This morning's newspaper report does refer to the highly successful outcome of the Nuclear Suppliers Group meeting which was held in Warsaw last month. The meeting significantly extended current controls by adopting a new control regime for 65 nuclear dual-use items. It was in this nuclear dual-use area that Iraq was able in recent years to continue purchases and that serious gap in controls has now been closed.

The meeting also adopted a common declaration requiring full scope IAEA safeguards as a necessary condition for new nuclear supply to non-nuclear weapons states. That declaration is particularly gratifying to Australia because we have led an international coalition and worked very assiduously on this issue over many years to achieve this result. The meeting called on other nuclear suppliers to follow suit. I might say in this respect that Argentina announced just last week that it had amended its nuclear export policy to require full scope safeguards as a condition of supply. I take this opportunity to urge those remaining nuclear suppliers, notably China, which have not yet adopted a full scope safeguards policy, to do so without further delay.

The other major focus of that Warsaw meeting was the situation in the former Soviet Union. The meeting made a special appeal to the CIS states other than Russia, which is a member of the Nuclear Suppliers Group, to promptly accede to the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty as non-nuclear weapons states, to accept full scope IAEA safeguards and to implement effective nuclear export controls. Again, I think it is fair to say that Australia played a leading role in that particular outcome.

The significance of the situation in the former Soviet Union for the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction is such that the Australian Government has now been invited to join with the Group of Seven in a major program of visits this month to those states to assist them in designing and implementing controls on the transfer of material, technology or related skills to potential proliferators in other parts of the world. This will cover controls to prevent nuclear, chemical, biological and missile preparation.

That Australia has been asked to join the G7 group as an eighth nation in this particular exercise is again, I think it is fair to say, a tribute to the contribution this country has been making to the prevention of the spread of weapons of mass destruction and to the depth of our arms control skill and commitment at an official level in this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I refer him to a report which I am sure he noticed, a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies entitled Expectations of Life, released late last week and specifically to recommendation 14, which says:

QUESTION.PARA: . that the increasing absolute and relative numbers of the aged in Australian society do not impose a burden on the economy or threaten the viability of the health and welfare system. . .

Given that the costs of future pensions is an important component of the Government's rationale for the introduction of the superannuation guarantee levy, does this report embarrass the Government or does it undermine the Government's stated rationale for the introduction of this compulsory levy?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to confess that the report did escape my notice. I know this is a shattering blow for Senator Kernot, but I have not actually seen the report.
—Like your directorship; it just escaped your notice.

—The directorship never escaped my notice; unfortunately, it escaped Senator Walters's. That being the case, I would much prefer to read the report before I comment on it and I shall try to give Senator Kernot an answer—probably tomorrow rather than at the end of Question Time today.

—Can the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the Senate of the reforms occurring at Email's Beverley plant in South Australia which are designed to transform the Email Major Appliance Group into an internationally competitive whitegoods manufacturer? Is the Email Group a recipient of a grant through the Australian best practice demonstration program to assist the company in that reform program and in the spread of international best practice? Can the Minister outline how the experience of this company illustrates the Government's cooperative approach to pursuing international best practice and labour market reform, in contrast to the confrontationist policies of the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a subject about which parties on all sides of the chamber can rejoice, because here is an Australian company which has concentrated on and succeeded in achieving world best standards and is now an increasingly important exporter out of Australia. In the current climate and tough international market, that is an achievement of which Australia can be proud.

PARA.TAB: The Email-Simpson Pope factory at Beverley in South Australia employs about 500 employees. It is an example of the team-work ethic and there is a cooperative attitude between the work force and management; there is not a `them and us' attitude. It is a multicultural work force and in microcosm is a representation of all of the multicultural communities in Australia. This work force has a low literacy level in the English language, but a literacy program is being run and there is a cooperative mentality which works very well.

The workers in this company have redesigned the production line so that it is worker friendly. In doing so, they found that the layout of the production line occupied a floor space which was one-quarter less than the floor space occupied by the production line when it was laid out by engineers, suggesting that the capital investment in the original plant construction perhaps did not need to have been as much. This production line works for the employees who work there.

Multiskilling is encouraged and there is advancement by qualification. The production line operates on a series of autonomous work groups which are self-regulating, each group in line being a customer of the group further up the line; so it regulates quality as well. The whole plant is overseen by a closed circuit television communications system, which means that senior board decisions taken at 6 o'clock one evening are known to each worker in the plant by 8 o'clock the next morning on the basis of face to face communication and on the basis of some discussion between their elected autonomous work group leaders and themselves so that management has feedback.

This plant has been judged by the independent panel that distributes world best practice awards as being an example in Australia of a world best practice company. In the Olympic year, it is the equivalent of an Australian company being selected in the Olympic team. This plant is moving towards the formation of a workplace agreement. It will do it in its own time. When an agreement is reached, as I am sure it will, the workers will own it, identify with it, take responsibility for it and make sure that their company is a winner in the international arena.

Email has recently placed a vote of confidence in Australia by announcing expenditure of a further $20m on the upgrading of its refrigeration manufacturing plant at Orange in New South Wales and, when commenting on this announcement, Mr Don McNeill, Email's Major Appliance Group Chief Executive, said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . in an increasingly open, internationally competitive environment, Australian industry could achieve—without compromise—productivity, quality, and flexibility to the highest standards in the world.
The results at Email are already a spectacular example of that: in the last three years Email has tripled its exports of major household appliances.

PARA.TAB: I began this answer by saying that honourable senators on all sides of the chamber should be pleased about this, because this is one company that is prepared to demonstrate how it reached that internationally competitive position to other Australian companies so that they can emulate and follow it. Email did so without promoting conflict, division or confrontation, the last three words all being metaphors for the Opposition's industrial relations policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I ask the Minister, as the custodian of national symbols, whether his office is promoting the desecration and denigration of our flag by selling T-shirts imprinted with the national flag but with the Union Jack removed and in its place the slang words `Jack Off'.

—I just cannot believe that anyone in the electorate would take Senator Parer seriously, and his performance in the way he has asked this question just now confirms my view. What Senator Parer has done is seized upon—

To preface an answer by making derogatory comments about the questioner, I would submit to you, is clearly out of order. I ask you to invite Senator Bolkus to withdraw.
—Order! I do not regard the comments that Senator Bolkus made as being unparliamentary.

—The point I was making was that this particular item managed to be treated so seriously that it rated about five lines on page 168 of a Sunday paper yesterday. It is that sort of issue that Senator Parer brings into this place this afternoon.
—Are you selling them?
—Order! Senator Bolkus is answering the question.
—As I say, it is not a mainstream issue. What is happening is—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If those opposite want an answer, they should just be quiet for a few minutes and they will get one. If they get back on the valium they will keep us all happy.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That comment is offensive and should be withdrawn.
—I withdraw.
—Yes, it should be withdrawn, but there have been too many interjections and Senator Bolkus should be given the opportunity to answer the question.

PARA.TAB: T-shirts are being sold. I think it is fair to say that a lot of people in Australia—an overwhelming, and a growing, number of people in Australia—are, in one way or another, getting into the debate on the flag. One of my staff has, at no cost to the Government or the public, been selling T-shirts for some time now as a fund-raiser. I am glad to see that last week she sold out, but she will be getting more. It is becoming more and more apparent obviously to a lot of us in this place that the mood for consideration of the issue and for a change is a growing one. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I noticed that in his response the Minister said that the sale of the T-shirts with the desecrated flag is being used as a fund-raiser. I ask the Minister: for what purpose are the funds being raised?

—Let me at the outset make it quite clear to Senator Parer, who has this enormous incapacity to understand answers, that there is no desecration of the flag involved here. Let me also reiterate, as was spelt out in the media this morning, that it is a fundraising activity for the Australian Labor Party. As I have said, we have had an enormous response to it. People from another country coming into this Parliament today would really wonder what is going on; we are obsessed with the issue of a T-shirt. Fair dinkum! Senator Parer should get on to the main issue.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Road Toll: Wearing of Seat Belts

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Has the road accident fatality and injury toll on country roads declined as much as the toll in metropolitan areas in recent years? Does the Government have anecdotal and/or other evidence that in some regional and remote areas a significant number of road users are not now wearing seat belts in motor vehicles? Would increased wearing of seat belts help reduce the fatality and injury toll on our country roads? Is the Government currently funding any projects to promote the use of seat belts among country road users?
—Has this matter also escaped your attention?

—No, the issue of road deaths has never escaped my attention; it has always been a source of concern to me and, I am sure, every other senator, certainly Senator Maguire. The road toll fell from around 3,300 in 1980 to 2,800 in 1989. Since 1989 road fatalities have fallen by 25 per cent to 2,100 last year. That trend is continuing during 1992.

PARA.TAB: In the period 1984 to 1988, the proportion of rural road fatalities fell from 49.3 per cent to only 48.5 per cent nationally; so, essentially, the proportion stayed the same. Consistent national data is not yet available for later years. From data available from New South Wales and Victoria in 1989 and 1990, rural crashes have fallen only marginally in proportion to the total crashes in New South Wales and have increased slightly in Victoria. However, it must be emphasised that the trend in rural Australia has been to a reduced number of fatalities and serious injuries.

In 1990, the Federal Office of Road Safety undertook a survey of seat belt use in rural areas. Overall, the seat belt wearing rate was pretty high at 94 per cent—by world standards, that is very high indeed—and was significantly higher than the previous figure of 79 per cent in 1988. Most non-wearers were found to be locals. Of the people killed in rural road crashes in 1988, 41.5 were not wearing a seat belt, which is a very high figure. Therefore, non-belt users are heavily overrepresented.

In the Northern Territory, around 80 per cent of the car drivers or their passengers killed in 1990 were not wearing seat belts. In its recently published road safety strategy, the Northern Territory Government has indicated that this situation has not changed markedly since 1976. The heavy overrepresentation of non-belt users among fatalities reflects the effectiveness of belts in preventing deaths. Most studies show that we have a 40 per cent less chance of being killed if we wear a seat belt. It also reduces the severity of injuries.

The Federal Government conducted a major road safety campaign in 1991 aimed at seat belt wearing amongst rural drivers, particularly young males under 30. The campaign used the slogan `Buckle up in the bush'. It was both a television and billboard campaign. It cost about $750,000 and ran for some six months to September 1991. The results were very good. A nationwide study showed that awareness of the campaign was very high, with 83 per cent of people in rural areas aware of it. The figure rose to 89 per cent for the primary target group. In terms of effectiveness, the survey revealed that 3 per cent of respondents who were not regular wearers of seat belts had changed their behaviour as a result of the campaign. That means that lives were saved. In the primary target group of young males, the study reported that there was a positive shift to seat belt wearing of 5 per cent. These changes are particularly significant when it is considered that seat belt wearing rates are very high Australia-wide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the United States Secretary of Defense, the Hon. Richard Cheney. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome Mr Cheney to the Senate. I trust that his visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications to reports in the Brisbane media at the weekend that Australia Post plans to close up to 110 offices across Queensland. Is the Minister aware that Australia Post told the Industry Commission that it is the Federal Government's reform program for government business enterprises, announced in 1988, which has acted as the mainspring for Australia Post's current policy direction? Is the Minister also aware that recent changes to Australia Post services are already having devastating consequences in rural communities? Does this proposed action now mean that Australia Post has all but abandoned any concept for promoting public benefit before profit? Can the Minister give an unequivocal guarantee to those in rural Australia who rely so heavily on their postal services for vital communications and deliveries that their current services will not be reduced?

—Very often the closure of a post office does not mean the closure of a service; it means a shift in the kind of service that people receive. It will be a real problem for Australia Post, once given any kind of commercial charter, to operate a service everywhere in Australia. Where a service has become uneconomic, obviously it becomes very difficult.

PARA.TAB: We will obviously approach any change to the arrangements for post offices, not only in rural Queensland but across anywhere in Australia, with as much sensitivity as is possible. Obviously it is an important service to people and we will be endeavouring to maintain it. It certainly was an important service to the former Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Blunt, and we would not seek at any time to hinder people such as him, or indeed anybody else in Queensland, attempting to gain access to the postal service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Is it a fact that the Commonwealth pays a subsidy of $27.80 per patient per day with respect to Tasmanian public nursing home beds? Is it also a fact that this figure was frozen in 1985? If so, why? Is it also a fact that the Commonwealth pays a subsidy for Victorian nursing home beds of $42.50 per patient per day? If this is the case, will the Minister explain why Tasmania is disadvantaged to the tune of three-quarters of a million dollars for every hundred beds? Finally, would the Minister agree that this disparity in funding is causing severe financial hardship, with the result that institutions with aged care beds at Evandale and Wynyard have already been closed down or are currently under threat?

—I accept the facts outlined in Senator Bell's question because of my respect for him but, as to the question of the gap between the subsidy which is offered in Tasmania and another State or Australia-wide, that is a matter that at present is subject to discussions between the Federal Minister for Health and the State Minister. I believe that they are likely to be very fruitful in the near future. I certainly do not intend to pre-empt the intergovernmental negotiations which have been carried on in a very decent and open manner. I will not give the Senate a preview of the outcome of those negotiations. I am sure they will ensure that the very high standard of nursing home care which is a feature of this Government's policy will continue to be achieved in Tasmania as on the mainland.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have just drawn the attention of the Senate to the fact that we have the Secretary of Defense of the United States in the chamber. Whilst he has been in the chamber, we have had a disgraceful exhibition by the Minister for Administrative Services concerning our flag. I ask for your guidance, Mr President. At the end of Question Time I have no doubt that Senator Parer will want to take note of that answer, and I want an assurance that Senator Bolkus will remain in the chamber.
—Order! There is no point of order whatsoever. The point can be raised at the end of Question Time.

PARA.TAB: As far as the rest of the question is concerned, I do not have any present knowledge of that. I am not going to go into any details of that until the whole matter is completed. I only appeal to Senator Kemp and others that, while I know it may well be fun to have a crack at me, at least have some thought at some point for the fact that people who have to go to trial, whether it is here, the Marshall Islands or anywhere else, really ought to be given an opportunity to do so without this kind of publicity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister for the third time: could he please table the reference which he gave to Mr Symons? Has he found it yet?

—The answer to that question is no. What I did not say last week is that we had been looking for the reference for the three previous weeks. I suspect that it may have hit the fence when I transferred portfolios, because there seemed to be no particular point in keeping it. But we are still looking for it and, if we can find it, we will table it.
—Mr President, I move a point of order.
—You don't move a point of order.
—I make a point of order. I wish to say that I happen to have a copy of the reference. I seek leave of the Senate to table it.
—There is no point of order. Is leave granted to table the reference?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. Can the Minister confirm that several local councils in New South Wales have now taken over responsibility for their local aerodromes? What does the Minister believe are the implications for the regions in New South Wales served by these airports?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that last week I attended two hand-over ceremonies at Wagga Wagga and Tamworth in the Riverina and New England regions of New South Wales respectively. At Wagga Wagga, the council of the city of Wagga Wagga has accepted full responsibility for the civil facilities at that joint user airport—it is a civil and military airport.
—Wagga, not Wagga Wagga.

—No, I am not allowed to drop off the second `Wagga'. I got local advice that the locals can do it, but for people from outside it takes two `Waggas' to make Wagga Wagga `Wagga Wagga'. So it has to be `Wagga Wagga'. As part of the transfer agreement, the Commonwealth provided a $2.5m grant to the city of Wagga Wagga towards the upgrading of the movement areas at the airport for medium jet aircraft operation. Wagga Wagga is the first of seven joint user airports—that is, with civil and defence operations—for which a local authority has agreed to assume responsibility for the civil facilities.

PARA.TAB: At Tamworth airport yesterday it was my pleasure to hand a cheque for $1m from the Federal Government to the Tamworth City Council for major drainage and taxiway works at the airport. For those honourable senators who are not familiar with what is happening at Tamworth—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is amazing, isn't it?

—Yes, it is. I think Senator Brownhill used the correct word. I was amazed at the facility that I was able to see yesterday—the pilot training school that has been established at Tamworth as a joint British Aerospace and Ansett initiative. I had been briefed, of course, on the actual detail of what was there, but I did not anticipate the size and standard of what I saw yesterday. It is one of the most remarkable investments and developments in regional Australia—that is, inland Australia—that I have ever seen.
—Even the American Air Force could come and train there if it wanted to.

—Yes, indeed, it could. I do commend honourable senators who are not familiar with this development at Tamworth to make themselves familiar with it. It is a superb facility that has been established at Tamworth. The college is a school of excellence and is eventually expected to cater for in excess of 200 students, over 80 per cent of whom are expected to come from overseas.

PARA.TAB: Considerable progress has been made in renegotiating the withdrawal of airports from the airport local ownership plan and the transfer of Commonwealth airports to local ownership. One hundred and one aerodromes have now withdrawn from ALOP and agreement has been reached for the withdrawal of a further 30 aerodromes. Seven Commonwealth aerodromes have been transferred to local ownership, and Wagga Wagga has become the first to take over the civil facilities at a joint user airport.

The additional $27.5m which has been provided by the Commonwealth in the One Nation statement will enable the acceleration of this transfer program, with completion now expected by 30 June 1993. I am fully aware of the responsibility being taken on by local operators in accepting full responsibility for their airports. Local councils have taken the view—it is one with which I fully agree—that they are best placed to discharge this responsibility to the benefit of their own local communities and the regions they serve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Transport and Communications or his staff had any discussions with Japanese Airlines regarding the purchase of a shareholding by JAL in Qantas and/or JAL having representation on the board of Qantas?

—I certainly have not had any discussions with JAL at all, over any matter. I am not aware of my staff having done so either. Certainly Senator Collins has had discussions with a number of airlines. I think JAL is among them, but I have had none.

—Welcome back, Mr President. My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation and it relates to the often needed search and rescue facilities in Australia. In this respect, can the Minister advise the Senate on the operation and efficiency of Australia's satellite aided search and rescue system in dealing with emergencies at sea?

—Honourable senators will recall that when this technology was first introduced there was some widespread concern about just how effectively it would operate in relation to the system that it was replacing. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the system is operating with spectacular efficiency. No major problems have been encountered since the installation, in September 1989, of the system of ground facilities for monitoring the global maritime distress and safety system. The system involves the detection by its orbiting satellites of distress signals emitted from emergency position indicating radio beacons—or EPIRBs, as they are known—which should be carried by all vessels going to sea.

PARA.TAB: Occasionally AMSA has encountered unidentified EPIRB transmissions caused by misuse or malfunction of beacons that have necessitated additional checking of the situation by AMSA and State agencies. To save this expense and possible diversion of resources from a real emergency, AMSA urges EPIRB users to periodically check their beacons and ensure that manufacturers' maintenance recommendations for the beacons are followed.

AMSA also has an active sea safety education program that provides information on, among other things, the operation of EPIRBs and the satellite aided search and rescue systems. AMSA has advised that, in the 1990-91 financial year, 33 EPIRB alerts were detected in the Australian segment of the satellite system, contributing to the saving of 109 lives. In addition to the obvious contribution to safety of life at sea from the carriage of EPIRBs and the satellite assisted system, the time taken for expensive air searches is reduced significantly because alerting of emergencies occurs sooner and more accurate position information is provided.

To advise the Senate of just how efficient these systems can be, the most recent example happened a week ago in Queensland with the rescue of three crew members from an overturned Shark Cat craft. The marine rescue centre declared a marine alert at 5 a.m. on the Saturday before last, 25 April, when it detected an EPIRB distress signal through the satellite monitoring system. The overturned craft was located by chartered helicopter and the three survivors were lifted out of the water at 6.40 a.m.—that is, one hour and 40 minutes after they activated the beacon.

The efficiency of this system reduces the risk to those who undertake the actual search and rescue, often in extremely hazardous conditions. I commend AMSA on its dedicated service in the search and rescue field and again emphasise the absolute necessity for all vessels to carry an EPIRB to save life at the cost to small boat owners of less than $250.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the fact that the annual inflation rate was 1.7 per cent for the year to the end of the March quarter 1992, that the average weekly earnings increased by only 2 per cent in the year to the end of the December quarter 1991, and that interest rates on savings investment accounts have almost halved, will the Government introduce legislation to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to calculate the increase in provisional taxpayers' income at a more just and realistic level than the current 10 per cent?

—Without accepting any of the premises of the question relating to the justice or injustice of the taxation system, I will direct that question to the Treasurer. It is a policy matter and I will obtain an answer as soon as I can.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Has the Minister seen the article in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed `Libs plan child-care rebates `? Is the Government now giving or has the Government ever given consideration to the use of tax expenditures to fund child-care for Australian families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has looked at various ways in which child-care can be provided in a fair way in the community. It has looked at tax deductions and rebates as part of the various formulas that might be used in this regard. We have rejected rebates basically because they fail the test of fairness. Clearly, tax rebates or deductions favour those persons putting children into care who are on higher incomes; that follows as a matter of course. Families whose incomes are too low to pay tax receive no benefit from rebates at all. Also, a tax rebate or deduction is of no value to a family which cannot find somewhere to place a child or children. Frankly, I do not think that a system of rebates, which is sometimes spoken of, will advance the cause of child-care in the way that some people hope.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, the Government's national child-care strategy has focused on the questions of affordability and supply. There are now 130,000 families being assisted by fee relief. The number of families receiving fee relief has more than doubled in the last two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You need more supply; you will not get them your way.

—Senator Newman has mentioned supply. There are now 178,000 funded child-care places. We have more than trebled the number since 1983. We will build 250,000 by 1995-96. These issues were well understood by the Government and by Australian families at the last election. Australian families then rejected the coalition's policy of tax rebates; I am sure they will this time. In fact, when speaking about the Government's child-care and fee relief strategy on ABC radio in Canberra in June last year, Senator Alston said :

ANSWER.PARA: It's income tested. . . it's fairly generous. . . and it seems to me that that approach in terms of where you cut out the assistance is probably not too far wide of the mark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Senator Alston said that. He went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: We've got to look very seriously at whether we think that is more appropriate than our approach.
Senator Alston has had a look and has retreated to an approach already rejected by the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is his approach, what does the—

—Senator, I can hardly hear myself think. Senator Alston went on to say that his preference would be to target assistance to lower income earning groups. It would be very interesting to see whether Senator Alston, when he fleshes out his tax rebate proposal, really targets the lower income groups and does not merely make some token cut-off at the income level of the wealthiest people in our society. We must see that he really does fulfil that particular promise to target the lower income groups and afford them assistance in the provision of child-care relief.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Australian families will reject tax rebates as a way of increasing the affordability and supply of child-care places and that they will see in our strategy the way in which they ought to be provided over the next several years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation to the incident involving a BAe-146 aircraft due to icing near Meekatharra in Western Australia. Since that incident the Australian Civil Aviation Authority has imposed a ceiling for these aircraft of 28,000 feet. The United Kingdom imposes a limit of 25,000 feet; British Aerospace recommends 31,000 feet. I ask the Minister: what criteria did the CAA use to arrive at 28,000 feet other than splitting the difference?

—I am stating the obvious by saying this but I will state it anyway. The Civil Aviation Authority as a regulator has an unparalleled international record in making the correct decisions about supervising the regulation of what is without question the safest aviation system in the world. In regard to decisions the CAA makes—and I described to the Senate the decisions the CAA has taken in regard to the icing problems that have been discovered on this particular type of aircraft—the CAA is often accused of being too conservative or too careful. But the CAA will always continue to err, if it does so, on the side of caution.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer but that is not quite what I asked him. I asked him how the CAA arrived at that figure and, what is more, when can we expect that aircraft to be able to operate without any special conditions, if at all.

—The aircraft is perfectly capable of operating satisfactorily and commercially at the altitudes that have been nominated. It was an extremely unusual set of weather conditions to occur in Australia, where icing conditions are not particularly common as they are obviously in the colder regions of the world. The CAA is satisfied, and so am I, that with the amended altitude which has been nominated for this aircraft and which it will not be permitted to fly above, the aircraft will operate safely.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of recent determinations taken by the Australian Government and of certain developments occurring in Vietnam, is the Minister able to comment on the current state of Australia's relations with that country? What are the prospects for a more substantial relationship, what elements are changing within it, and what are the implications for the region of an improved relationship between Australia and Vietnam?

—The achievement of a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia last year removed the last significant obstacle to Australia's development of a fully-fledged bilateral relationship with Vietnam. It will be recalled that in October last year we announced that as a result we would resume bilateral aid to Vietnam. In Hanoi last month the Treasurer and Senator Button jointly announced the introduction of a $100m bilateral aid package.

PARA.TAB: An agreement on trade and economic cooperation, which was signed in June 1990, is providing an excellent basis for the steadily growing economic relations which exist between Australia and Vietnam. A bilateral investment protection agreement was signed in March 1991, and a double taxation avoidance agreement—Vietnam's first with a foreign country—was signed by the Treasurer in Hanoi last month.

The Government's capacity to facilitate Australia's economic engagement with Vietnam has also been strengthened with the appointment this month of a resident trade commissioner to the Australian Embassy in Hanoi and the formal opening of a new Austrade office there. I think that trend towards closer economic involvement with Vietnam will intensify as Vietnam's own economic renovation program, or doi moi as it is called, gathers pace and as eventually Vietnam becomes eligible once again for assistance from international financial institutions such as the IMF, the World Bank and the ADB, a process which the Australian Government strongly supports.

The Vietnamese community in Australia—a community of which we are very proud—has an important bridging role to play between Australia and Vietnam both culturally and commercially. It would be quite wrong to suggest that our relations with that country are only about commerce. The sound political relationship that has been built up over the last 10 years does enable us to pursue with the Vietnamese authorities in a quite forthright manner the full range of Australian interests and concerns, including a number of matters of particular concern to the Australian Vietnamese community, such as human rights and family reunion migration.

In that respect I respond to Senator Reid's question on the adjournment the other night about what we might be able to do to raise the concerns that have been expressed about interference by the Vietnamese authorities with the funeral rites for the deceased Hue Patriarch, the Very Venerable Thich Don Hau. I have instructed the Ambassador in Hanoi to raise those allegations with the Vietnamese authorities and to convey the concerns of our Government that, if correct, the allegations would have the effect of undermining claims by the Vietnamese authorities that religious freedom is fully respected in Vietnam.

I have instructed the Ambassador to urge the Vietnamese authorities to allow those funeral rites to proceed in accordance with the wishes of the Patriarch as expressed before his death, and also those of his followers, without undue official interference.

Finally, given Vietnam's strategic and potential economic importance, the Government strongly supports the full reintegration of Vietnam with the regional and the broader international community. In this context we welcome the recent improvement in the relations of that country with China and with the ASEAN nations. Of course, full reintegration will be impossible without the full normalisation of Vietnam-US relations. In that respect the Australian Government welcomes recent progress in that connection and we look forward to the early removal of such remaining obstacles as exist to that early full normalisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Defence to reports over the weekend of bastardisation occurring at the Australian Defence Force Academy and of an announcement of an inquiry by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. What information can the Minister give at this stage as to the accuracy or otherwise of the media reports? When will the inquiry be completed? Can the Minister assure the Senate that the inquiry will include an investigation as to whether adequate supervision is being maintained at all times by staff in respect of the discipline exercised by senior cadets over junior cadets? Further, can the Minister assure the Senate that the inquiry will also investigate the allegation that an Army officer observed some of the alleged activities and, by taking no action, may be deemed to have condoned it?

—I did read the reports over the weekend concerning these incidents at the Australian Defence Force Academy. It is rather hard to tell from the first newspaper article in the Sunday Age just how many events there were. The implication is that there were 21. But, of course, when one reads the fine print one finds that there have been 21 resignations from the Academy. That piece of cheap journalism, for the second week in a row, again reflects badly on the Sunday Age. Nevertheless, we take very seriously the three cases that the newspaper mentions. I have made it clear as the Minister that I will not tolerate bastardisation in these institutions—it is not a good indicator of someone who wants to go on and become a proper officer and I am sure that the commandant shares that view with me.

PARA.TAB: The honourable senator asked how long the investigation is going to take. I would imagine that anything up to eight weeks is the normal time for all evidence to be taken in these cases. I can assure the Senate, though, that proper disciplinary action will be taken against any cadet who has been involved in those actions.

The question of adequate supervision is a very tough one. It is difficult to know where to draw the very fine line in respect of the extent to which one interferes with or supervises the private time of students. Compared with other university students, Academy students have much more supervision. If any officers witnessed these events but took no action, disciplinary action will be taken against them. The one that the honourable senator mentioned will be checked during the investigation and appropriate action will be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the views of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the level of briefing on the joint facilities that has been given to Committee members? Will the Minister respond to those concerns?

—I did see some comments on this report, especially during a debate in the House of Representatives. It has been the policy of this Government merely to continue the policies of the previous Government in regard to briefing, and that is that it is done on a need to know basis.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lindsay, the Chairman of the subcommittee, wrote to me some weeks ago expressing his concern. I wrote back to him saying that I was quite happy to hear his views on the matter and that the level of briefing would be changed if discussion brings out the necessity for that to occur. I am a bit disappointed that that letter was not included in the report because I think it would have given balance. I will table my response tomorrow when I am able to put my hands on it.

I also saw the comments of Mr Sinclair, which I found to be quite enjoyable. I always knew that Mr Sinclair had a thick hide. Here we have an ex-Defence Minister who rigorously enforced these briefing procedures, cutting out as many then Opposition members as he could. Last Thursday he bled all over the House of Representatives like some hippie, saying that we should broaden this and that everyone should be included. When it comes to rank hypocrisy, this must stand as one of the best efforts that I have ever seen from Mr Sinclair.

None of that comes as a surprise to me. I recall, when I was Home Affairs Minister, the supplication that one used to get from Mr Ian Sinclair on how badly Opposition office holders were treated and how much we had to increase their entitlements across the board. If anyone in government was ruthless to oppositions in reducing available resources to them, it was Ian Sinclair. But the moment he became the Leader of the National Party in opposition, every week we got letters—it must be the thickest file we have—pleading for more VIP flights or stamps or on any other particular issue. So I find his conversion on this briefing issue not at all surprising. Old George has a very thick hide when it comes to these matters. But I would have to ask him for just a little consistency.

To the substantive issue: yes, I am willing to consider that we broaden the briefing area. I think that would be appropriate in the current climate. It would probably best be done in a formal discussion between the Committee and myself, rather than in the sort of report it put to the Government when it already knew that I had the matter under consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. On 1 January 1991, the Government restructured pharmacies and estimated net savings to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of $19.7m in 1990-91, $65.5m in 1991-92, $145m in 1992-93, $137m in 1993-94 and $168m in 1994-95. Is the Minister aware that, instead of a saving of $19.7m, there has been a loss of $3.4m? Are the forecasts for pharmacy restructuring a microcosm of the One Nation forecasts?
—I will forward that question to the Minister and get a considered reply.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. While the Government congratulates itself about the level of depression inflicted on the people of Australia generally through its own failed economic policies, would it please spare a thought for the people of Bairnsdale and Cowra, who last week had the soul and livelihood of their communities destroyed by the loss of their respective mainstay industries? Does the Minister acknowledge that these appalling losses are occasioned by his Government's failure to adequately achieve micro-economic improvements to the economy? Does he recognise the catastrophe in losing these whole industries and of the effect yet again on our overseas balance of payments as Australia, by its own actions, loses more exporters and becomes an even greater buyer of food from other countries as it becomes more and more difficult for us even to feed ourselves?

—This question comes from one of the secular mullahs from the Opposition who is incapable of analysing an issue and just repeats the sort of wordy rhetoric that was put out in part by the shadow Minister, Mr McLachlan, last week. The first thing Senator Archer should know is that, from the restructuring of Petersville, his own State will be a very substantial beneficiary.
—I know that.

—Senator Archer did not mention that because he wants to come in here and make a cheap point. That is why he did not mention it. Senator Archer's question contained a multiplicity of confusion which is not rare in his case. It is a matter of regret that establishments at Cowra and Bairnsdale have been closed as a result of the Petersville restructuring which is now taking place. The closures at Cowra and Bairnsdale mean that, in a variety of other sites, some seven sites throughout Australia—
—Did you read the Good Weekend?
—I had an excellent weekend, thank you, Senator.
—Did you read the paper?

—No, I watched the football and I saw Senator Macdonald's lot get a hiding. Seven other sites which remain in the Petersville empire will be greatly strengthened by the changes which have taken place.

PARA.TAB: One thing that the Opposition has never understood about the restructuring of industries is that it involves the reallocation of resources into the most efficient areas of the company's activities. Senator Archer referred in his question to the question of exports. Petersville has not been a significant exporter from this country, but it will become one as a result of the restructuring of that company that will take place. That is paramount amongst the company's ambitions.

At Ulverstone in Tasmania $26m will be invested to improve the processing plant. Investment at Bathurst in New South Wales will also increase capacity, and the vegetable canning capacity at Manly in Queensland will be expanded by 40 per cent. We were not given a clue about that in Senator Archer's question. Also, the company has gone on to set out its export ambitions, which, as I indicated earlier, were significant and the result of a new export focus in Petersville which has not existed before.

I do not know whether I have answered all the points in the honourable senator's question. It is certainly a matter of regret that the plants at Cowra and Bairnsdale have closed, but, in terms of this industry as a whole, it must be regarded as a positive action taken by the company which will greatly improve the performance of Petersville in its future export activities, its capacity to sustain production and the development of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I call Senator Richardson.
—Are you going to announce your resignation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, but I am delighted that the honourable senator has announced hers. On Thursday, 30 April Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a number of supplementary questions about ABC on-air announcers and their involvement as candidates in local government elections in Western Australia. Senator Crichton-Browne wanted to know whether Mr David Hill had issued an instruction that announcers nominating for the elections should be taken off air, whether the State ABC manager had encouraged ABC employees to be involved in local government and what the current status was of the three ABC employees already involved in local government.

PARA.TAB: The ABC has provided me with the following answers:

ANSWER.PARA: The decision to withdrawn Mr Manning from his on-air role in the lead-up to local government elections this Saturday was made by the Western Australian Radio Management, that is, by the Manager for Radio in Western Australia and the Manager for Regional Stations in Western Australia in consultation with Federal Radio Management. This situation is being managed locally and will continue to be so.

At no time has the Manager for Radio in Western Australia, Mr Glenn Darlington, encouraged ABC employees in Western Australia to contribute to communities by getting involved in local government or given any directive whatsoever to seek to be a candidate for local government elections. In more remote areas of Western Australia local council activities and issues are more significant in the daily lives of the public than in metropolitan areas. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act guarantees the editorial independence of the Corporation's program services. Hence, all on-air personnel must be seen to remain fair, impartial and unbiased in their handling of local government issues.

The ABC's attitude to Ms Knight, Ms Ambrosia and Mr Hasleby currently holding or seeking a local government position is the same as that for Mr Manning. That is, they have withdrawn from their on-air roles in the lead-up to the elections, and each case is currently being reviewed on an individual basis by Western Australian Radio Management.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—My brief statement addresses the announcement made earlier by yourself, Mr President, regarding the vacancy in the representation of the State of South Australia. With this further vacancy occurring, I trust that the Senate will give early consideration to my notice of motion on the filling of casual Senate vacancies, which is due to come before the Senate on Wednesday, 6 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day, relating to the desecration of the Australian flag.

I and my colleagues, and probably the vast majority of Australians—in fact, on recent polls, over 65 per cent—were appalled, disgusted and sickened by the response given by Senator Bolkus to my question. My question simply asked whether his office was promoting the desecration and denigration of the flag by selling T-shirts which were imprinted with the national flag, the Union Jack having been removed and the slang words `Jack Off' having been put on the bottom of the flag. For the benefit of the Senate I now display this flag that has been put out as a fund raiser, according to Senator Bolkus.

Senator Bolkus treated the issue in a most flippant way. Here he is, the custodian of our national symbols—and one of our major national symbols is our flag—treating it in a flippant way by passing it off, saying it appeared on page 168 of some newspaper. He also said that overseas visitors would have been amazed by the line of questioning. He made that remark because Mr Cheney was in the gallery. I noticed over the weekend that Mr Cheney himself was interviewed on this very issue. A question was raised by a reporter as to what the reaction would be in the United States if this issue was raised. It took Mr Cheney entirely by surprise. His response indicated that this would not happen in the United States, and neither would we be asking those sorts of questions—and we should not be asking them in Australia. It just would not occur in other countries.

I might point out that the Flags Act, when introduced in 1953 to formalise something that had happened since Federation, never envisaged that the flag itself would be desecrated by an Australian citizen let alone a senior Minister of the Government. There was no provision made in the Flags Act for that. I presume that, if Senator Bolkus and the Labor Party want to raise more funds, the next thing we will have is some sort of public burning which, of course, in other countries would bring a lot of retribution. It is apparent that Mr Keating, who has no sense of history; Senator Bolkus, who has no sense of decency on this matter; and the Government, have no sense of nationalism, heritage or history.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a document put out by the Department of Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus's own Department, being custodian, of course, of the national symbols, the major one being the flag. I draw to the attention of the Senate and the people of Australia just what is in this document. It talks about the competition back in 1901. It goes on to say that, as a new nation in a new century, there was an urgent demand for a new emblem. This was determined after over 32,800 entries had been received from a country which, at that time, only had some 3.7 million in the population.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a bad looking flag.

—It is a very good looking flag. I draw attention to the Department's own document. It says that in 1901 the new flag heralded Australia's entry into nationhood. This is when we achieved Federation; this is when we became an independent country. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: It flew over the site for the national capital at Canberra in 1908, on the first ships of the new navy in 1910 and at the first Australian base on the Antarctic continent in 1911. Since 1953 it has flown continuously at Australian Antarctic bases.

I also would point out, again from the official documentation of the Department, that it has been raised for medal winners at every Olympic Games since 1908. That is the history of this flag, our flag, the one that represents so much to so many people in this country. The document continues:

PARA.TAB: The flag was carried into New Guinea at the outbreak of World War I by the naval and military force which captured the German colonies, by the cruiser Sydney in the first naval battle of the war, by the Anzacs who landed at Gallipoli and by the `diggers' who spearheaded the victories in France in 1917-18.
It was seen around the world again in World War II. When Singapore was retaken in 1945—

SPEECH.PARA: and this is an interesting bit of history and heritage—
the first flag to fly was an Australian ensign made secretly in a prison camp.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Changi.
—Yes, in Changi. It seems to me that the Minister is not only content with his loony left views to change the history of this country—
—He is trying to rewrite it.

—Yes, he is trying to rewrite it. He is trying to attack the symbol of what is truly Australian. The flag represents all the things that are important to us. As was mentioned the other day in debate, the Union Jack is part of our history. Yes, we were a colonial power, but from 1901 we have never been a colonial power. Just because the Prime Minister and the Labor Party do not know who they are does not mean that we have to change the major national symbol of this country. More important, and the reason I am responding to the answer given by Senator Bolkus, was the flippant way—
—Disgraceful.
—Yes, and the disgraceful way in which he responded to that question.
—Didn't he describe it as memorabilia last week?

—Yes, he did. The Government is doing this without asking the Australian people whether they want a change. We on this side of politics have made the point that we do not mind a debate on this matter, but let us have a proper, healthy, open debate. We should then ask the Australian people, by way of referendum, whether they want the flag changed. This should not be imposed upon them. If the Minister does, he will do so at his peril, as will the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: I have just described what our flag represents. I know that some of my colleagues will also want to speak to this motion so I will not take up that time. The flag that I have described—the Southern Cross, the timeless land, the constellation of stars that spreads over the southern hemisphere—represents Australia. The flag represents not only the past of the timeless land but also its future.

The Union Jack does not necessarily refer specifically to the colonial days but to our history. The flag represents the law, the democracy, our freedoms, the language we speak and this country's Christian heritage. The Union Jack represents the three crosses of St Andrew, St George and St Patrick. This is the flag which in Question Time the Minister sought in a juvenile way to belittle, denigrate and desecrate. The Minister should be condemned for doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly in response to Senator Parer. Senator Parer said that the Opposition welcomes debate in this area. The Government also welcomes debate. But I do not think debate is enhanced when people come to this issue with a closed point of view. Anyone who had listened to what Senator Parer said before he asked for this debate would have seen quite clearly that the Opposition comes to this issue with a closed point of view. If one analyses the speeches that were made in this place last week on this issue, one sees that the Opposition comes to it with a closed point of view. The only person on the Opposition benches who has spent some time with me discussing this flag, who was prepared to look at alternative flags but who at the end of it said that he was not all that keen to change, was Senator Kemp. He spent some time with me last week in this chamber going through alternative flags.

PARA.TAB: If we are going to have a debate it needs to be an earnest one. If we in this place do not think there will be a healthy debate on this issue, we are conning ourselves. Whether we come from the position of wanting to change the flag or not, there is one thing for certain: this issue is being widely debated and will be widely debated.

Some mention was made of the fact that in response to a question from Senator Parer I referred to Mr Cheney being in here. When Senator Parer raised the question in this chamber about the sale of a T-shirt I made the point—and I will continue to do so—that this was very much trivialising this place as a forum for national debate. That someone is selling T-shirts out of my office and raising funds as a consequence, quite honestly, should not really merit the time of this chamber. I stress that the weekend media thought that this matter was of sufficient import that an article on it appeared on page 168 of one of about five or six Sunday papers. Five lines is all it got.

Senator Parer mentioned Mr Cheney's presence in here. For the purposes of the debate we are to have, it is interesting to note that the US has made some eight to 10 changes to its flag in the time that it has had a flag. More importantly, of something like 40 sovereign nations of the Commonwealth, only four have yet to change their flags: us, Fiji, New Zealand and Tuvalu.

I think that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is spot on when he says that we have an ambiguous emblem. In that context, I am worried that our flag is so similar to the flags of, for instance, Tuvalu and New Zealand. There is ambiguity about the flag. I am not a great subscriber to the Hinch program, but last week the Hinch program went out to the streets of Australia with two flags, one being green and gold and the other being the New Zealand flag. People were asked whether they would like the flag to be changed. Everyone said that they preferred the existing flag and pointed to the New Zealand flag.

There is ambiguity both in the electorate and overseas about our emblem and what it stands for. One thing we cannot get away from is that we have an emblem in Australia which was brought about of necessity with a demand from the British Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't.

—Senator Parer should look at the records of the year 1900. Loyalty to the Empire was the basic criterion for the design of the flag. It was selected by a committee which had very little public participation on it; six of the seven people involved in the selection process had a military background.

PARA.TAB: This is and will continue to be an issue of importance. Australia is a country which is, and Australians are people who are, increasingly asserting independence. As part of that, I believe that we will be flying into the next century with a new flag. As the Prime Minister has said on this issue, the Government will not change the flag without a body of public support behind us. I stick with the Prime Minister's sentiment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to wear that T-shirt?

—No. I bought the T-shirt I wear quite often these days in the airport store in Darwin. It has on it the Aboriginal flag, which I also think is an attractive flag. The T-shirt that is now in the chamber is not my T-shirt. Even though Senator Button likes that flag—I presume for the fact that it has the colours of his football club on it—I have not worn that T-shirt.

PARA.TAB: I make a couple of points in closing: firstly, all the Opposition has done by this debate is trivialise this forum; and, secondly, as an assertion of fact, it has increased sales of that T-shirt by raising this matter. The Opposition is really wasting people's time. The real issue for Australia is what sort of symbol we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment, which you caused.
—It is about time you got your priorities right.
—Senator Newman and Senator Walters are worse than the Andrews Sisters. Give us a break. The basis of this issue is—
—Only one of your mates is in here helping you.
—I will not talk about Senator Tambling's mates.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I have some protection as I close my contribution to the debate?
—Yes.

—I just do not know what all those opposite have against me personally. Let me close on this point: the issue of the flag was pretty well expressed in the Adelaide Advertiser editorial of 29 April 1992. One line sums up the view of a growing number of Australians. It is:

SPEECH.PARA: A break away from the trappings and symbols of empire, of imperialism, fits the age and the mood of change desired by many people, not all of them young.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks made by my colleague Senator Parer on the motion to take note of an answer given by Senator Bolkus during Question Time. I was not in the chamber at the time that Senator Bolkus alleged—
—Stay, Senator Bolkus. Come back.
—Senator Bolkus, I have something I want to say about you.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! Senator Kemp, I ask you to address your remarks through the Chair. I ask people on my left to be quiet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I understand that Senator Bolkus, at the start of his comments in this debate, alleged that he had discussed the issue of the flag with me and said that I had an open mind. Indeed, I have an open mind on many issues, but I think the record will show that on some issues my mind is very, very firm indeed, and certainly made up. I cannot recall ever discussing the issue of the flag with Senator Bolkus, let alone discussing it for two hours. I do not think I have ever had a discussion with Senator Bolkus for two hours about any particular topic.

PARA.TAB: The record of my comments in this Parliament and elsewhere—in my comments to colleagues—would clearly show that I am not only a strong supporter of the current Australian flag but also a passionate one. Dr Evatt, a former leader of the Labor Party, described this flag so well as `possibly the most beautiful flag in the world'. That is a sentiment with which I fully concur. I hope this flag long flies over this great country of ours.

There are some remarks which are worth noting in this debate which, thanks to the Labor Party, has become a public debate. When we look at the issues which have concerned the Australian people over the past 20 years, we can recall that on many occasions opinion polls were taken to find out what the Australian public regarded as major political issues. My memory of that process harks back a long time, possibly up to two decades. In terms of the 10 to 15 major issues that have concerned the Australian public, I cannot recall anyone ever raising the issue of the flag—or, indeed, of the Constitution. So we are left with the fact that this issue has been totally contrived by the Labor Party.

I was speaking in the great city of Horsham on Sunday. A person in the audience asked me, `What has changing the Australian flag got to do with the issue of jobs?'. I said, `On the one hand, absolutely nothing; on the other hand, absolutely everything'. I explained by saying that, on the one hand, changing the flag, fundamentally changing our Constitution, would not add one job to the jobs in this country. In fact, through the division and unpleasantness that it would create, it may well even lower the public confidence in our future and we may well lose jobs. But I then said that, on the other hand, it has absolutely everything to do with the issue of jobs. The issue is this: the last thing that Mr Keating wishes to debate as we go towards the next election—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Labor Party opposite.

—As Senator Newman said, the last thing the Labor Party opposite wishes to debate is the Labor Party's record on jobs and the one million unemployed which Mr Keating's policies have created. So what Mr Keating has done, with the connivance of the Left of the Labor Party, is try to launch a major diversionary tactic, that diversionary tactic being the suggestion that, for some reason—because it is no great pressing issue to the public—we now have to debate our flag and our Constitution.

PARA.TAB: I want to make a few brief comments on that. Australia's history as a Federation goes back almost 100 years. Many great men from both sides of politics have led this country through war, peace and depression. Not one of them has not been proud to fly the Australian flag. Mr Keating is the first Prime Minister of this country who is not proud to fly that flag; he will not fly that flag on his car.

An opinion poll conducted over the weekend shows that two-thirds of the Australian public were very happy with our current flag. Just under one-third would be happy with a change. When asked what they thought of their Prime Minister attacking their flag overseas, 76 per cent of Australians were absolutely appalled that he could go overseas and attack their history, their flag and the institutions of their country. I do not believe that one other leader of our country has done that.

To remind the Senate of what appalled people about the behaviour of Mr Keating, I refer to an article which was published in the Australian Financial Review some weeks ago when Mr Keating, our Prime Minister, was in Jakarta. the article states:

"The Asians are entirely confused. They are not sure whether we want to be part of the area. They are not sure whether it is simply tokenism. They are certainly unsure of us when we turn up at the time with the Union Jack in the corner of our flag," he said.
"To make our way in the world, and particularly this part of the world, we have to be entirely certain of who we are, what we are and what we wish to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know which Australians Mr Keating mixes with. The Australians I mix with know who they are, what they are and what they want to do in the rest of the world. I suspect that Asians could not care less about our flag. I have been around for some 47 years and I have never heard an Australian worry about any Asian flag and I suspect, equally, that the Asians are not too worried about our flag.

PARA.TAB: A flag is not for a foreign country; a flag is for the people of the particular country. That is the issue. I may well ask Mr Keating: who are these Asians who are unhappy about our flag? That would get a very interesting answer. Which countries and which leaders are unhappy about our flag? If Mr Keating named those people, there would be a howl of outrage from Australians and, in my view, rightly so.

Whatever side of the fence people come down on in this debate—and let us face it, most Australians and, indeed, almost half of Labor Party voters, according to the latest opinion poll, are strong supporters of the retention of our flag—they are appalled that their Prime Minister goes overseas and grovels to try to win the respect of Asian countries in our region by attacking our flag. I do not think that the Australian people will ever forget that. We on this side of the chamber will never forget that. We know we have a foreign Minister whose habit it is to grovel to our neighbours'; we thought perhaps we had a man who was leading this country who was prepared to stand up and be proudly Australian. Regrettably, we do not have that.

This is an important debate. It was a debate put on the agenda by the Labor Party. It is a debate causing enormous concern in the community. It is not only a debate about a piece of cloth; it is a debate about a perception of Australia and it is a debate about what we feel about our history.

The reality is—and even those who want a change in the flag will agree with this—that this flag has flown over this nation for almost 100 years. It has been the symbol of this nation—the symbol of our language, our culture, and our belief in ourselves. Millions of Australians have felt very warmly and passionately towards that flag. Mr Keating and some of his colleagues—I say `some' because I believe many of them do not support him in this issue—now feel that it is time for a change. Because this is a free society, he can debate the matter in the rest of the community. However, people are revolted by the fact that this man can stand up and sneer at a flag that has meant so much to the Australian people. That is why there is a growing concern in the community about the performance of Mr Keating, about his judgment, and about what sort of Australia it would be if we had this immensely divisive man leading this country.

Mr Keating is not addressing a public concern—all the opinion polls have shown that this is not a public concern—but is trying to lock in behind him the left wing of the Labor Party. Earlier today we saw Senator Bolkus—one of the leading left wing figures in the Labor Party—get up and sneer at our flag. The man who is meant to be the guardian of our flag has produced a T-shirt which many Australians would regard as mocking the flag. It is a sad thing that the Labor Party has come to this.

I conclude my remarks by drawing the Senate's attention to the words of another former Labor Party leader, Arthur Calwell. I have already mentioned the famous quote by Dr Evatt, a former leader of the Labor Party, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: The flag that is now Australia's national flag, which is based on the Blue Ensign, is a very beautiful flag. It is probably the most beautiful flag in the world.
