To that I say, `Hear! Hear! Dr Evatt, former leader of the Labor Party'. Many of us in the chamber were quite young when Arthur Calwell was leader of the Labor Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —I wasn't born.

—Perhaps Senator Sherry's father bounced him on his knee and told him about Arthur Calwell, because many of Senator Sherry's colleagues were proud of Arthur Calwell. Senator Sherry is looking embarrassed, and so he should be. This is what Arthur Calwell said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that if proper respect were shown for the Australian flag, which is flown by our warships and by our troops in battle, a healthy national spirit would be promoted, and all Australians, whether newcomers or native born, would love and respect the laws of our country.

That was a former leader of the Labor Party, and what a contrast to Mr Keating. I believe that Mr Keating has broken ranks not only with the history and tradition of his Party, but with the history and tradition of the Australian people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support Senator Parer's remarks. I find it absolutely offensive that a Minister who is responsible for the flag is raising money from his office by desecrating the flag. I also find that the printing of the term `Jack Off' on that T-shirt has a connotation that is different from what the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has been saying publicly. I find that very offensive. How a Minister who is responsible for the flag—one of Australia's main reasons for pride—could do this defies my understanding. I do not know whether the Minister was aware that his office was selling these T-shirts to raise funds for the Australian Labor Party—
—He said he was.

—If he said that he was, then that warrants investigation as well. It is not the Minister's responsibility to raise funds for the Labor Party out of his ministerial office. If that were investigated, I suggest some action may be required under the Standing Orders of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is trying to divert the Australian people. He is trying to create a subterfuge by raising a debate that will turn their minds away from the million people who are unemployed, the record bankruptcy figures that are coming in month after month, the people who are walking off their farms or being thrown off their farms, and the people who are being thrown out of factories and jobs. That is what people are interested in. They will not be diverted by some phoney debate that the Prime Minister is raising in an attempt to get himself on television every night.

The people will not fall for that. They are worried about their jobs, homes, businesses and their children not being able to get a job. If the Prime Minister wants us to make our way in the world and he wants us to have pride, I suggest that he provide jobs for the 28 per cent of our youth who are unemployed, the thousands and thousands of small businesses that are going bankrupt every day and the thousands of farmers that are destitute and now the recipients of food parcels. That is what this Government has done to us. Then he has the audacity to get up every night and say, `We want to make our own way and we want to have pride'.

If we do not have pride in this nation, it is because the Prime Minister and the Labor Government have dragged us down into the depths. It is hard to have pride when one does not have a job. It is hard to have pride when one was once a proud farmer but will now get a food parcel as the only way one can keep one's family in existence. What sort of pride is that?

This is nothing but a subterfuge and a diversion. It is nothing but a disgrace that a Minister who is responsible for the flag, desecrates the flag, sells that desecrated flag out of his own office and then puts the money into the Labor Party coffers. It should be the subject of a Senate investigation, and the Minister should come in here and apologise for what he has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Saturday, I had the pleasure of watching the march of the veterans of the Battle of the Coral Sea, which we are celebrating in this country right now. When Prime Minister Keating arrived in his flagless car, this unelected Prime Minister was booed by the thousands who lined the streets. He was booed because he was not respected as a man who respects the symbols of this nation.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, former Prime Minister Hawke got a cheer and people said, `Why aren't you up there instead of down here?'. When other dignitaries arrived they were applauded, but this unelected, flagless Prime Minister was booed. As the march proceeded, we saw units of veterans and serving Australian men and women proudly carrying our flag. We also saw some very angry veterans who, as they came past the Prime Minister, made some motions with their hands that indicated their anger against this unelected, flagless Prime Minister.

On Sunday morning, I had the pleasure of attending an ecumenical service at Saint Andrews Church, again to give thanks for the service and the sacrifice of those who served in the Battle of the Coral Sea. But in that service we were saying thank you to all men and women who served Australia under our flag; not selecting some of them in the way the Prime Minister did in Papua New Guinea when he said, `You're the only ones that matter and everybody else who served Australia is somehow less important'.

What we did on that morning, and what the sermon that was given that morning did, was to say that World Wars I and II were fought for the principle of democracy. Mr McPheat said that democracy was not a system of government; it was a system of principles. That is the reason that the men and women of Australia went to war before we knew that we would have to defend this nation on our own doorstep. Never was that brought home more readily than on this particular weekend to celebrate the sacrifice and the coming together of Australian and United States men and women to fight an important battle—an important battle that had many ramifications for the defeat of Japan.

The courage that the Americans showed in support of us, but which we also showed in support of them, was a mutual effort. But so was the effort that we showed when we fought with our allies at El Alamein, with the Rats of Tobruk or in other theatres of war where our courage has been strongly shown. How dare this man who purports to call himself a Minister of the Crown, Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Administrative Services, say that our flag is trivial. How dare he!

The flag is important to me. The flag is important to Australia, just as our Constitution is important to us. If we have a Minister that wanders aimless, flagless and head of stateless and says he does not know who he is, do not purport to speak for me, Sir—because he does not—and do not purport to speak for thousands upon thousands and millions of Australian men and women who are proud of their national symbols and proud of this nation and proud to be Australian. All the spruiking forth of the great lie, all the paltry, poor, propaganda that this awful shirt represents, will not make any proud Australian lessen the pride in our nation and in our flag.

So when I rise to support the remarks of Senator Parer in taking note of the disgraceful answer that was given in this place by the so-called Minister earlier this day, I am reflecting the comments that have been made to me, the actions that were shown by the thousands of people who watched the march-past on Saturday, those who prayed together on Sunday and those who value the coming together of allies to fight against an evil and against a common enemy.

To be Australian and to live in this great nation makes me one of the luckiest people in the world. When I look at my flag, I remember what it says to me. It tells me about the origins of our system of law, our institutions, this very Parliament in which we sit, the ethics which are reflected in our law making, the fact that we came together as a single unit under Federation, a single nation, in 1901 and then chose by popular choice an emblem, our flag, to represent the things that were then precious to us and remain precious to us today.

The Australian Labor Party has become the great proponent of the great lie. If members of the Labor Party say a lie often enough they think people will believe it. This time those opposite have erred. All of those on that side of the Parliament have erred. When I was listening to an interview with the son of the man who was one of the successful entrants in designing our flag, although he was scathing of this unelected, flagless Prime Minister, he said, `I know there are many in the Labor Party who don't share his views and I know one Minister who doesn't share his views. Ben Humphreys loves our flag. He was with us in Gallipoli and he loves our flag. He is not one of them'. I dare say that that view is held about other Ministers or other members on that side of the Parliament.

It is indeed a sad day when the stocks of this flagless, unelected Prime Minister have fallen so low. Indeed, the polls show that, since he began this attack on our national pride, our national symbols and on our nationhood itself, he has gone down in the polls—and down is where this unelected Prime Minister will remain.

People who enjoyed reading the colour supplement in the Sydney Morning Herald this weekend—the story of the getting of Hawke, the machinations of people who call themselves Ministers in bringing down Prime Minister Hawke who had led them to victory so that we could have in its place this man who wishes to attack the very foundations of this nation—will have read it with a cynical amusement. What is the main feature of the illustration on the front cover of that magazine? It is a dagger at the throat of former Prime Minister Hawke. This unelected Prime Minister is putting a dagger at the throat of this nation. There is nothing he will not sacrifice. He will go to foreign nations and apologise for being who we are, hoping that they might somehow like him.

Who would ever respect somebody who said, `I am going to take down all the portraits of the members of my family who have gone before me because I have decided that I do not like them any more. I am going to pretend to be something else'? What a nonsense! Our neighbours respect their own traditions. They respect their own nationhood and the symbols of that nationhood.

I have a message for our neighbours, and it is this: I respect your integrity as nations, I respect your symbols—please respect mine also. Many millions of Australians are offended, just like I am, by this flagless unelected Prime Minister. They love this country, its symbols and the things it stands for. I am a proud Australian and I love my flag.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to support Senator Parer's motion. I find it hard to believe that a Minister of this Government would support an attempt by one of his staff members to raise money for the Australian Labor Party by selling T-shirts that denigrate the Australian flag. Polls have shown that a great majority of people still want the present flag as the flag of our country.

PARA.TAB: Except for a day like today when Canberra was for a time covered by fog, every morning when I wake up and pull aside the curtains I see the Australian flag flying on the great flagpole above our Parliament. The Australian flag is hung behind Labor Party speakers during election campaigns. We see the Australian flag on Labor Party television and press advertisements. I wonder why members of the Labor Party—people like Senator Bolkus and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—are so anxious to change the flag.

The Australian flag contains the Southern Cross. This very nice symbol represents the Southern Cross which can be seen in the sky over this part of the world. The flag also contains the star of Federation which symbolises the States joining together and forming a federation. Then, of course, the flag contains the Union Jack. I believe that the Labor Party and others who want to change the flag really want to get rid of the Union Jack.

I believe it is fatuous to argue that the presence of the Union Jack on our flag indicates that it is someone else's flag or that it reflects our colonial status. These arguments show little knowledge or appreciation of history. People who put forward such arguments conveniently forget that a nation is much more than a geographical entity and that it also exists in the context of time and culture.

We cannot escape the simple historical truth that the vast majority of early settlers who pioneered, explored and created this country and who developed our modern society came to Australia from England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland. It is nonsense to deny that some Australians came as convicts. We should be proud of our past. We should learn from it and move on to the future.

Parentage and creed make people what they are—these elements cannot be denied. British values and standards underwrote Australia's development. Moreover, our early settlers brought with them our basic social and political institutions which have served us well for over 200 years. Our Westminster system of government, both the envy and despair of so many other countries, has come down to us from as far back as Simon de Montfort's first parliament of 1265 AD in England.

In denigrating our British and European origins, some argue that we are part of Asia and that our flag and constitution should reflect this. That, of course, is what the Prime Minister said as he moved around Asia just recently. I do not believe that that is correct at all. Geographically, Australia is closer to Antarctica than it is to South East Asia, which lies almost entirely north of the equator. New Guinea is between Australia and the equator and the people of that country can scarcely be called Asians. These arguments also conveniently forget that other Asian countries, such as Thailand and Japan, are monarchies. Furthermore, Australia is a separate continent. Australia is not a part of the Asian continent. One could argue that neither is the Soviet Union. Our flag was chosen from many thousands of entries in a competition. I have always been proud of our flag. We fly it at home regularly. I certainly agree with and support the motion moved this afternoon by Senator Parer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly wish to associate myself with the disgust of my colleagues at the way in which Senator Bolkus trivialised the Australian flag during Question Time today. I support the motion moved by Senator Parer.

PARA.TAB: The manner in which Senator Bolkus dealt with this question was cheap and off-hand. His trivialisation of the flag was a disgrace to someone who holds the position of a Minister of the Crown in this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —And responsible for national symbols.

—And responsible for national symbols, as Senator Short points out. Senator Bolkus may not like the flag; he may wish to change it. But that in no way gives him an excuse to denigrate and belittle our flag in the way he did today.

PARA.TAB: At the weekend I, too, had the opportunity and the honour to attend Battle of the Coral Sea celebrations at Townsville, Cardwell and Cairns in north Queensland. At all of these places Australians, young and old, were proud to stand under the Australian flag and commemorate the gallant members of the Australian and American forces who 50 years ago this week fought in the Battle of the Coral Sea and, in fact, saved Australia from invasion. After spending a weekend when Australians of all ages, all nationalities and all origins were proud to stand under and salute the Australian flag in honouring the people who fought in the Battle of the Coral Sea, it

SPEECH.PARA: is a shame to see today a Minister of the Crown treating the flag in this way.

PARA.TAB: I find it hard to believe what my colleagues have said—that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) refuses to have the Australian flag on his vehicle. I find that absolutely incredible and almost impossible to believe. I only believe it because my colleagues have told me that they have seen this happen. To me, this is the ultimate disgrace—that an unelected Prime Minister, a man who got to his position by subterfuge and treachery, would dare to attend official functions without flying the Australian flag on his car. He may not be prepared to fly the flag on his car but, in the ultimate of hypocrisy, the Australian flag is displayed prominently on the logo of the Australian Labor Party. I am absolutely sickened when I see that.

We have a situation in which a party that is not prepared to stand up for the Australian flag, a party that is prepared to come into this chamber and, as the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, did, belittle and trivialise the flag, puts the flag on its logo and displays it prominently wherever it can. In the past, the Labor Party has thought that it would get votes out of displaying the Australian flag prominently at Australian Labor Party political functions. I have little regard for the Australian Labor Party. Whatever regard I might have sinks even lower when the Party has the hypocrisy to leave the Australian flag on its logo and at the same time trivialise and denigrate the flag as it does in this place.

Not one of the members of the Labor Party opposite is prepared to stand and support the flag as we have done on this side of the House. Those opposite are quite happy to have the flag on their logo, but they are not prepared to stand and defend it against the attacks, the trivialisation and the disgusting displays of the Minister for Administrative Services this afternoon.

The polls have been quoted by my colleagues and I will not continue with them except to say that an interesting sidelight of that poll in the Sunday Mail, the Quadrant poll, shows that the unemployed want to keep the flag—by a percentage in excess of the national average. Some 70 per cent of those unemployed polled want to keep the flag as it is. Some 74 per cent of those unemployed polled disapproved of the way the Prime Minister chose to talk overseas about changing the Australian flag and some 94 per cent of the unemployed indicated that they wanted a referendum to be held before the Labor Party took steps to change the flag.

It is interesting that unemployed people think like that. They are people who have been part of Australia, who have earned a living out of Australia and who have built assets out of Australia. But I suspect that, for most of them, that has long since gone. This Government has created one million unemployed. Unemployment has taken those people from where they used to be part of Australia's wealth to the position they are in now. I guess the only thing they have left of what was a great country is their flag. I guess that they, more than most, reel with horror when they see people like Senator Bolkus rejecting and trivialising the flag. The people who cannot get a job because of this Government's actions are strongly in favour of retaining our existing flag because it is their only connection with the great nation Australia used to be. It is interesting that those figures should come out. It is necessary that as many Australians as possible are made aware of the hypocrisy and the disgusting attitude with which people like Senator Bolkus treat our flag.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 59 citizens), Senator Campbell (from 57 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 143 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitions pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Waste
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That residents of Pontypool, Wales, have been exposed to unreasonable health risks by the incineration in their environment of toxic waste products including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs);

That it is unacceptable for the Australian Government to permit the Western Australian Government to dispose of such toxic waste products by exporting them to Pontypool, Liverpool, or other overseas venues;
That it behoves the Australian governments to compel the producers of such waste products to meet the costs of disposal in Australia.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice given on the last day of sitting on behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, I now withdraw the Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name for two sitting days after today with the disallowance of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) (Modifications of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 397 and Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 2, standing in my name for 11 sitting days after today for the disallowance of Guidelines HSB 3/1992 made under section 82F of the National Health Act 1953.
—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes that—
(a)the Australian flag properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses which represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language, law and parliamentary institutions,
(ii)the Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space, and
(iii)the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth;

PARA.TAB: (b)the presence of the Union Jack underpins our historical and cultural ties to Britain, and emphasises that it is British values and standards that underwrote our development; and

(c)a nation is much more than a geographical entity and that it also exists in the contexts of time and culture and, as such, the current moves by the Australian Labor Party and other organisations to change our flag and to make Australia a republic by the turn of the century deny this heritage and are a distinct sign of their immaturity and insecurity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)congratulates the Scouting Movement for adopting a new uniform which includes an Australian flag above the left-hand shirt pocket;

(b)notes that the Member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) presented the two newest members of the Australian Scouting Movement with their Australian flag badge at the launch of the new scout uniform on 4 May 1992;
(c)calls on the Member for Fraser to tell the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the left wing of the ALP that the majority of Australians want the Australian flag to remain unchanged;
(d)deplores the divisive debate on this issue created by a Prime Minister desperate to distract the Australian electorate; and

(e)urges the Prime Minister to turn his attention to the real issues that now face this nation which include his creation of the `Great Recession', record foreign debt, rocketing bankruptcy levels and deeply entrenched unemployment which has left a whole generation of Australian youth without hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes with disgust the actions of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in desecrating the Australian national flag by selling T-shirts from his office displaying the Australian flag with the Union Jack removed and the derogatory slang expression `Jack Off';
(b)calls on the Minister for Administrative Services to apologise to:

TAB.TAB: (i)the vast majority of Australians who wish to retain the flag,
(ii)those Australians who, under the symbol of the flag, fought for the freedom of all Australians, and
(iii)the relatives and descendants of those Australians who gave their lives in defence of Australian values reflected in the flag; and

PARA.TAB: (c)calls on the Government to announce that it will not attempt to change the flag, either directly or subversively, without first determining, by way of referendum, that that is the wish of the majority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(b)recognises that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the cause of these disastrous events lies in the grinding and long-term inequity in American society, which has produced an alienated and permanently disadvantaged subclass,
(ii)under the present Labor Government there has been a growing disparity between the `haves' and the `have-nots' in Australian society so that inequity, both in income and wealth, has grown,

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The strong endorsement by the OECD of the policies contained in the Coalition's Fightback! package of economic reforms.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose that the following matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion today: namely, the strong endorsement by the OECD of the policies contained in the coalition's Fightback package of economic reforms. I say at the outset that that package is specifically designed to cut taxes, create jobs and provide incentive and opportunity for growth in the Australian economy, which is still experiencing the most severe recession for 60 years, a recession caused by the policy failures of this Government.

PARA.TAB: This is not just an economic matter. The economic problems that we have today and the proposals contained in the coalition's Fightback package of reforms are much more than economic issues. Fightback! is much more than an economic document; it is a very important social document. It is an important expression of political principles and it is about a new role for government in Australia. It is based on the essential proposition that the role of government must be to provide a stable framework of policy and law within which individuals, families, businesses and other community organisations can plan with confidence and have economic and other freedoms to choose the courses of action which best suit them.

There is a very close relationship between economic freedom and vitality on the one hand and a moral and just society on the other. We can see that in our own society today. Our whole social fabric is under enormous strain from almost 40 per cent youth unemployment and from the desperation and despair of the huge numbers of people, particularly those in middle age, who have now been unemployed for upwards of a year and beyond. Economic freedom and growth do not in themselves guarantee a just, fair and moral community, but they certainly foster it and, for their full benefits to be achieved, they require it.

At the same time the greater freedom of economic choice does not achieve everything. There are limits to freer markets and they need a clear framework of rules within which to operate properly. Government must promote competition and ensure fair dealings between people. It must resolve conflicts and protect the weak against exploitation. They are the very principles which underline the proposals put forward by the coalition in its Fightback package. They are the very principles which are endorsed by the OECD in its latest economic survey of Australia released just last week.

I am sure Senator McMullan will claim—as have Government Ministers, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and Minister for Finance (Mr Willis)—that the report was produced after the Government's so-called One Nation statement, its economic statement of 26 February, was prepared.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before!

—Yes, released before. I acknowledge that and thank Senator McMullan. The point I want to make is that in the frontispiece to the OECD report it says that the final approval of the survey for publication was given by the Committee on 5 March 1992, after revisions in the light of discussions during the review. In the introductory pages there is a summation of some of the main aspects of the Government's 26 February economic statement. The report just lists them and gives no comment on them at all.

PARA.TAB: If the OECD had really believed that the conditions, policies and proposals contained in the Government's 26 February One Nation statement—which really was a one job statement; a statement designed to try to shore up the position of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—were significant, then it could have redone much of the analysis and certainly the conclusions contained in the report.

Did the Treasury slip up on this? The Federal Treasury has the opportunity to have a significant input into OECD reports on their own countries. Or did it secretly or privately agree with the criticism levelled by the OECD by implication at the Government's One Nation statement, and certainly the criticism that is levelled quite directly at the Government's economic policy performance? Did it secretly or privately agree with the reform proposals contained in the coalition's Fightback proposals? The comments contained in the OECD report provide a very strong endorsement of the coalition's Fightback proposals, while at the same time contain very strong criticism of the Government's policy performance; a policy performance which in no way is changed by the proposals in the economic statement of 26 February which, by now, has sunk absolutely and without trace.

First of all, let us have a look at some of the criticisms of the One Nation economic statement of 26 February contained, in effect, in the OECD report. The OECD report, although couched in moderate language and despite the fact, as I have said, of its having been prepared with the assistance of the Treasury, makes a joke of the economic statement of 26 February. It reveals beyond any doubt Mr Keating's failure to deliver micro-economic reform and highlights the macro-economic failures of this Government as well.

The report points out that the forecast growth for Australia is much less than that contained in the Government's economic statement; that is, there is a large discrepancy between the growth forecast of 3 per cent contained in the OECD report and the forecast of almost 5 per cent—or 4 3/4 per cent—in the Government forecasts for the next year, 1992-93. As I said, although the OECD forecast was made before the economic statement was released, the stimulation contained in that statement is very insignificant relative to forecasts of growth. There are other reasons why, clearly, the Prime Minister's forecasts in that statement are rubbish and why the statement based upon them has no validity as a serious economic statement.

The OECD, in contrast to the Government's much vaunted views, sees the recent inflation gains slipping away with inflation reaching 4 per cent in 1993. That, of course, is a figure that would be above the OECD average.The OECD has also criticised the Government in terms of its wages policy. It says that the wages policy did not deliver inflation performance comparable to that of Australia's trading partners.

Indeed, despite and in stark contrast to all the parading that this Government has done over recent years about its economic policy approach and the improved competitive position that it proclaims Australia has experienced, the OECD report categorically and damningly shows that to be absolutely wrong. For example, the report says that our inflation record in the 1980s `did not improve to the same degree as in the large OECD countries and has only, over the past year, matched their record'. It continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Most OECD countries adopted firm anti-inflationary monetary policies in the early 1980s and achieved substantial and sustained reductions in inflation. Australia was slower to come to grips with the legacy of the high inflation of the 1970s.

The report goes on to note the fall in inflation in the last year or so, but puts it down, quite correctly, to the enormous recession that we have had—the deepest recession in 60 years—and it expresses considerable doubt as to the Government's prospects of retaining inflation at a sustainably low level: certainly a level below that of our major trading partners. That, of course, along with productivity growth, is what will determine the future living standards of this country.

PARA.TAB: When it comes to the productivity record, the OECD is especially damning of Australia's performance. It says quite categorically that:

SPEECH.PARA: Growth in Australian labour and total factor productivity (TFP) has been slow. Between 1982/83—
that is, of course, when this Government came to office—
and 1990/91 hourly labour productivity for the whole economy grew at an annual rate of 0.7 per cent.
Indeed, in the five years to 1990-91:
. . . labour productivity on a comparable basis was approximately unchanged—

that is, no labour productivity growth at all in the five years to 1990-91. The report points out that the growth of productivity has slowed on whatever measure one wants to adopt for it. Productivity is a difficult thing to measure, but on all measures productivity growth in Australia has slowed. On a comparison between countries, the OECD says:

. . . available data suggest that while productivity levels in the Australian agricultural and mining sector are substantially above the OECD average, those in other sectors are well below the OECD average.

It draws particular attention to the abysmally low productivity levels in government business enterprises which, it says `would appear to be roughly one-half the OECD average'. So, in relation to inflation and productivity—two key determinants of the future competitiveness of this country and, therefore, of our prospects of job creation and improved living standards—we have in this OECD report a damning indictment of the Australian experience.

PARA.TAB: The report also goes on, in effect, to criticise very strongly the Government's lack of performance in terms of privatisation. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has undertaken a limited privatisation program.

If one knows how the OECD bureaucrats go about drafting and framing their reports, one would know that that is in fact a strong criticism of the Government. The report goes on, in some detail, to underline and describe the poor performance of government business enterprises in Australia over recent years and, in effect, to criticise the Government for its failure to go further down the privatisation and corporatisation route.

PARA.TAB: Of course, there is a major road block there as far as the Labor Government is concerned. The unions have said to the Government, `You're not going to get greater efficiency in government business enterprises by corporatising and privatising them; we are going to stop you from doing so'. They have put a stopper, therefore, on improved productivity growth in terms of what is arguably the major determinant of the underlying growth in productivity in Australia. So, again, we have there a damning indictment of the Government.

I noted with interest and acclaim Senator Watson's notice of motion just prior to this debate. The OECD has strongly endorsed, by implication, the Opposition's proposals for a goods and services tax. It has criticised the existence of the wholesale sales tax in terms of its failure to be eliminated from the costs of doing business in Australia.

The wholesale sales tax in Australia is a very significant impediment to business efficiency and competitiveness in Australia because it is built into our cost structure and there is no way in the world that it can be eliminated. That is one of the fundamental reasons why the coalition is proposing the abolition of the wholesale sales tax—an unfair, discriminatory, arbitrary tax that adds to the costs of business—and its replacement with a goods and services tax which, on any measure of fairness, equity and efficiency, is a vastly better tax.

The OECD report is strongly critical of the Government's policy performance and its actual growth performance. The OECD, through its call for the urgent speeding up of micro-economic reform, has endorsed very strongly indeed the whole thrust and many of the specific proposals of the coalition's Fightback package. The message in the OECD's report is very clear—it is said specifically that more vigorous micro-economic reform is urgently needed. The whole tenor of the OECD report is that not enough has been done in the area of micro-economic reform, not enough urgency is there. Therefore, Australia will continue to suffer on a competitive basis—a basis which determines our living standards—unless we take urgent measures to the contrary.
It is incredible that the now Prime Minister, when he was Treasurer addressing a foreign exchange conference in 1988, with his typical arrogance, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, we are at the point where there is nothing left to reform.
What an indictment of this now unelected Prime Minister's lack of understanding of the basic requirements of the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the particular policies in the coalition's Fightback proposals which are underlined and underpinned in the OECD's report on Australia which was released last week. The major practical proposal to achieve the objectives that the OECD is telling us that we need to achieve if we are to create jobs, increase our economic growth and derive improved living standards for our people, is tax reform. The OECD report talks specifically about tax reform. The Fightback package contains a proposal for a major reduction in personal income tax at all income levels, particularly targeted at lower and middle income earners. There is a total reduction of $13 billion, almost 30 per cent of the existing personal income tax take in Australia. It is the largest reduction in our history.

The coalition will reduce, by abolishing various taxes, some $20 billion of the tax cost of producing goods and services in Australia. It will do so particularly through the abolition of the wholesale sales tax; that dreadful tax on jobs, namely, payroll tax; and the fuel excise, which adds so much to the costs of transport and distribution in Australia. We will replace the wholesale sales tax with a value-added tax from 1 October 1994. A value-added tax, in the form of a goods and services tax, is an efficient tax, a fair tax and a tax which will help to create jobs and improve our competitiveness and productivity.

We will also increase national savings through major changes in superannuation and in other ways. We will concentrate industry policy on making business more competitive and profitable by reducing business costs. We will embark on a major program of privatisation to improve the efficiency of public sector enterprises.

They are the things that this country needs; they are the things that this Government stoically refuses to undertake; they are the essence of the Fightback proposals and the only way to reform and lead to better living standards for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance claiming OECD endorsement of the coalition's Fightback package before us today is rather pathetic. The Opposition has become a little like a puppy running around hoping that somebody will pat it. It is running around the world looking for someone to do anything which can be remotely interpreted as endorsing its Fightback package, because the Opposition is correctly aware that the Fightback package is increasingly being rejected by the people of Australia. The research makes it remarkably clear, but I am quite happy to rely on the voters' judgment on that matter.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Opposition are drawing a long bow with respect to this OECD document and the OECD's endorsement of their views. To his credit, Senator Short said that the OECD endorses the Fightback package strongly `by implication'. That means that the OECD does not endorse the package at all but he can interpret it in that way, and he set out to do so.

I want to speak specifically about some of the OECD documents, but firstly I want to say that I am not all that impressed by whether the OECD supports the Government, as it has sometimes, or not. These organisations trot around the world, flash into a country for a few days—not just Australia but all around the world—and come out as instant experts on its economy. There are a lot of profound analyses of the Australian economy going on, of which the OECD's may be regarded as one of the least significant. This report comes from a very important organisation, but that does not mean that a back-of-the-envelope assessment by a few people wandering through Australia for a few days is one of the most important assessments of our economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You used to champion the OECD when it suited you.
—Your own Treasury has a major input into that, you know.

—I understand that. I am simply saying that it is a bit pathetic to run around seeking out these particular endorsements. Sometimes the OECD agrees with us, and we think that is very nice and we say, `What a wonderful thing'; sometimes it criticises us; and this time it is a bit each way and is no more relevant than it was on the other occasions. I just wanted to make that comment as a generality—it applies not just to this inquiry, not just to the OECD and not just to this country.

PARA.TAB: The most significant question about the OECD report on Australia, notwithstanding that it was released recently, is: when was it done? It is based on a visit to Australia in September 1991 when the basic survey was undertaken, and a meeting at which that was reviewed in January 1992. Those are the two key periods. The visit to Australia on which this survey is based was in September 1991. It is true that the Australian economy was in recession in 1991. If that is what the OECD set out to find out—

TALK.START.PARA: —It still is.

—That is actually not true, but Senator Crane need not worry about it. The report is no great achievement. The OECD could have saved the money and spent 40c to send a letter and we could easily have told it that the Australian economy was in recession in September 1991. The report is not a useful contribution to the debate about the Australian economy in May 1992.

PARA.TAB: A great number of things have changed since then and I want to refer to some of them. The Government disagrees with some of the views expressed in the OECD report, but we welcome it—it is another contribution to the debate and there are many things in it with which we agree. I do not want to refer to this, because it is history—although one day we may have an interesting debate about it—but I think the OECD's analysis of inflation in Australia in the 1980s and its causes and effects is severely flawed and inadequate. It is the sort of conclusion one could draw only on the basis of a brief visit. The OECD should not be proud of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been studying the Australian economy for 20 years; you know that.

—It is just wrong about that, but that is not important because whether the OECD is right or wrong does not affect the issue before us today. I will not talk about it any more; I just want to put it on the record.

PARA.TAB: The OECD is absolutely right when it says that the issue is about locking in the low inflation that we have achieved. To the December quarter our inflation rate of 1.5 per cent was the second lowest in the OECD. That is a significant achievement. We did not have that in September but we have it now. We have built on it. We want to sustain and maintain that low inflation because inflation is a very unfair mechanism which is eating away at the wealth and income of Australians. The OECD's predictions on inflation are wrong because they are a bit out of date. Certainly on the basis of the circumstances that Australia is confronting now with, as I say, the second lowest inflation rate in the OECD, its predictions are a bit ungenerous.

The most important disagreement I had—I do not want to talk about this at length, but Senator Short gave it some emphasis so I will respond—involves the predictions about growth. We can all get too carried away with econometrics and say, `My model is bigger than yours', but let us look at factors that affect the likely outcome on economic growth in Australia which were not taken into account in this review, because that is a very important issue.

First of all, the predictions were pre-One Nation. There is a significant input to economic growth from One Nation. The prevailing assessment is that there is about half a per cent increase in economic growth in Australia from that. The view on which this document is based is September 1991. The December national quarter accounts have revised the GDP growth in the September quarter and have produced a significantly amended statistical base upon which the prospects for Australia for 1992 and 1993 should be based and assessed. Factoring those elements into the analysis would certainly have produced a stronger assessment.

Equally important, since September 1991 the drought has broken, and there is nothing in the OECD assessment to take into account the significant benefit that will flow in economic growth to Australia and the very positive contribution to growth from the farm sector which is expected in 1992-93. The assessment is based on outdated data. It is pre-One Nation. The policy situation has changed. Those are the areas of the OECD's critique about which we disagree.

Let us look at these so-called great endorsements of the Opposition. I do not want to talk all the time about One Nation and Fightback as they relate to the OECD; I want to talk more about the general analysis of the Australian economy and the relative prospects under the competing packages that are before the Australian people. It is said by implication in Senator Short's matter of public importance and in his remarks, although he did not say so explicitly, that the OECD recommends that Australia implement a GST, which it does not. It makes only a very passing reference to that issue. It concludes rightly that there is further room for improvement in tax reform. There have been significant changes in the tax system as it relates to business arising from One Nation, some of which have already passed through this Parliament, some of which are currently before it and some of which will be introduced this week and next.

For example, the proposal for the simplification of sales tax will be coming before the Parliament with a whole range of other important reforms. So there is no endorsement of GST in the document. It does not purport to do that and it does not do that. However, it does say that we need to continue to reform our tax system, and that is correct.

Does the assessment recommend the adoption of explicit inflation targets and the granting of a greater independence to the central bank? I have to say that I would not care if it did because I would not agree with such a recommendation. That is a fundamentally anti-democratic proposal. The assessment does not recommend that we adopt an inflation target, nor does it suggest there is a need to grant the Reserve Bank of Australia greater independence.

The document spends a lot of time talking about the credibility of one's credentials on an anti-inflation front. The credibility of Australian monetary authorities has been enhanced by their achievement of low inflation rates and, more importantly, the fall in inflationary expectations. These things will enhance significantly the prospects for Australians with regard to interest rates and other matters in the future.

We then turn to what the report has said about micro-economic reform. Senator Short—I am sure it was because of time—did not make reference to the very favourable comments the survey makes about Australia's micro-economic reform program, including in particular recent progress with labour market reform. It says that there is more to do, and there is. Significantly, it could not possibly refer to the significant micro-economic reforms proposed in One Nation in the areas of domestic transport, electricity and education. Those reforms are all important and will flow from the Government's initiatives in One Nation. So the survey does not endorse a GST and the Opposition's policy with regard to the Reserve Bank or micro-economic reform. It calls on us to do better; we should and need to do better.

The OECD survey was a little more fairly dealt with by the Australian Financial Review—I do not want to take too long on this—in an article headed, `Praise—and a prod—from OECD'. That gets the balance more accurately. Basically, it praises what we have done, but it also says that we need to do more. Anybody who doubts that the Government needs to do more should look at the policies outlined in the One Nation package, which policies are the next stage of doing more about reforming our economy. The editorial in the Australian Financial Review says:

SPEECH.PARA: It—
that is the OECD—
still struck a more optimistic tone than previous surveys about inflation, trade and controlling the foreign debt level—
even though it was prepared before this week's release of a zero inflation result for the March quarter. It continues:
It is a timely reminder that, while some progress has been made on getting it right, the rest of the world has not been standing still.

There are a number of other Australian Financial Review assessments indicating the progress that has been made but suggesting correctly that there is more to do. If I get time, I will come back to them.

PARA.TAB: It is not surprising that we find here today an Opposition desperate for somebody to be seen to agree with its Fightback package because, increasingly, the Australian people do not. The Australian people are looking at the goods and services tax and saying, `We do not like this proposal for it is fundamentally unfair and it is fundamentally inflationary'. Industries are saying more and more that they do not like this policy proposal. For example, a member of the restaurant industry in Queensland has said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the effects of GST are going to be diabolical. In countries where GST has been introduced, the restaurant industry has been the most affected.
Further:
We're so terrified about GST that on the national level we have engaged accounting firm Ernst and Young to put together a thesis on the effect of GST.

The restaurant industry has seen right through the Opposition. It is saying, `We want you to reintroduce business entertainment as a tax deduction'. I will be very interested to see the Opposition's response to that, because I think that that is what it will come back to. The Opposition will return to some of those other unfair proposals to reinforce the inequity of the GST. The fact of the matter is that the restaurant industry has seen through the Opposition, as the Australian people increasingly are doing, in this unfair and inflationary proposal.

PARA.TAB: I do not have time today to talk about the fun that the Opposition has been having with the tariff aspects of its Fightback package. However, I want to turn to the proposal for the major expenditure cuts, which I think is the most unfair aspect of Fightback. That is where the inequity is compounded. It is the most serious shortcoming altogether of the proposal. The evidence makes it clear that the most fundamental redistributive thing which governments can do is in the manner in which they spend money rather than raise it.

The GST and the associated tax changes to income tax and other taxes will make the way in which government raises revenue in Australia less fair. It is more important that the way in which the cuts are proposed will make the way in which we spend money less fair. In particular, the cuts will be affecting most adversely in Australia and internationally those least able to cope with that extra burden, be it the absolutely reprehensible proposal to cut overseas aid—$100m will be taken from the poorest people in the poorest countries—the welfare proposals, the health policy or the other areas of cuts in the document.

In particular, I want to talk about the jobs impact. When $10 billion is cut from government spending there is an adverse regressive effect not only in the redistribution of wealth in this country but also quite clearly in the cost of jobs. We only have to look at where the savings are proposed to realise that, directly and indirectly, this package will have a very unfair effect on jobs. It will create fewer jobs. It is exactly the wrong proposal for Australia as it emerges from a recession.

There are also significant and legitimate concerns about Fightback and its impact on the environment. It removes the capacity of the tax system to discriminate in favour of environmentally beneficial goods, whether they be solar panels or recycled paper or goods for insulation. At the moment the tax system can give benefits and discriminate in favour of environmentally beneficial goods: that disappears under the proposals of Fightback. We all know the adverse environmental impact of the proposals with regard to petrol prices.

There are some who argue, on both sides of the chamber, that the biggest distinction between the Government and the Opposition with regard to One Nation and Fightback and the context in which they are being developed is in the area of industrial relations. That is a very major area of distinction, although it is not my view that it is the most important area.

Under the Fightback policies there would be a return to the bad old days of conflict. It certainly reinforces the argument that those in the weakest position will have the protection removed. It weakens the weakest. The consequence of the whole philosophical thrust of Fightback—and I am not saying it is intentional; I am not saying that people are evil or terrible—is that those in the greatest need will be those who suffer the most. It is a return to the fairly orthodox conservative formulas. It is about fighting unemployment by putting people out of work, fighting inflation by increasing prices, and increasing living standards by reducing real wages. That is why the Fightback package is in trouble. That is why the Opposition is running around the world looking for some people who might look even a little bit like they agree with some part of it. As I say, the Opposition is running around like a puppy looking for a pat at a party.

One thing Senator Short said with which I do agree is that this debate is about more than economics. The competing economic packages being put before the people of Australia are about fundamental values. They do reflect different values about society and the role of government in society. I think that is a good thing; it is a matter for major debate on another day.

One thing that distinguishes this approach is this over-obsession with the phrase `freedom of choice'. Freedom of choice is of itself a good thing and no-one should criticise it, but the problem with freedom of choice when it has no context is that it can easily become the freedom for the already powerful to take advantage of their already privileged position to disadvantage those who might otherwise be being assisted.

It has been said by others, and remains true, that it is as unfair to treat unequals equally as it is to treat equals unequally, and that is the problem with Fightback. By pretending that all people—whether people in the labour market, people in the welfare area or people overseas in need of assistance—are equally in a position to be able to protect and advance their interests, that the poorest and the wealthiest, the weakest and the strongest, are equally able to cope, is a recipe for inequity. It is no wonder that the Opposition is clutching at these flimsy straws.

The OECD document is more accurately described as a timely reminder of the need to maintain the momentum of change and reform which the Government has introduced. I do not feel the document is as important as many other people seem to think it is. Nevertheless, to the extent that it is a contribution to our economic debate, we welcome it. But we totally disagree with the rather tenuous analysis that Senator Short tried to introduce today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter before us today arises because of the recently published annual OECD economic survey of Australia. The Opposition has found some solace in the OECD report in that it claims that the report supports its policies. Hence we are debating this matter of public importance this afternoon. The specific words of the coalition's proposition read:

SPEECH.PARA: The strong endorsement by the OECD of the policies contained in the Coalition's Fightback! package of economic reforms.
We need to look at exactly what the OECD did say in its report.

PARA.TAB: The report states that more vigorous micro-economic reform is urgently needed. While not wishing to defend this particular Government more than any other, I still think it is fair to point out that no other postwar Federal government has tackled many of the areas described in micro-economic reform at all, and obviously that has been to our detriment. But our uncompetitive ports, shipping, rail and other transport areas are being reformed. It is very easy to say, `We would do it more quickly', but that approach involves imposing settlements which may lead to strikes and other disruptions, because such an approach may impose very high costs on industries and even slow down reform in some of these areas.

The Opposition says that it will slash transport costs; it will slash goods handling costs; and it will slash shipping costs. But all these solutions involve large-scale sackings, and we can see that this is mooted to be happening and to some extent has begun in the case of AOTC. In that case the Government has insisted on corporatisation; it has argued that this will make this part of the public sector more efficient. So we go ahead, we introduce a competitor on a very tilted playing field, and the first efficiency outcome mooted is the shedding of 20,000 jobs to add to the existing one million unemployed.

So much for the Government's commitment to the AOTC industry plan, a commitment to which the Government was dragged with some considerable reluctance by the Australian Democrats, and a commitment on which it looks to be reneging already. So-called efficiencies must be managed so as to minimise human impact, especially in rural areas. So-called efficiencies must be accepted by the work force, or they will be counterproductive in the long run. Industrial organisations will not accept unfair and provocative tactics and will understandably resist. The result will be that all Australians will lose.

In any event, the Opposition's position is considerably weakened because it is at this time supporting the Government's tariff reductions, even though these supposedly vital micro-economic reforms have not yet been completed. The Democrats believe that orderly and universally accepted change is infinitely preferable to confrontation. It is very easy to publish a document saying, `We will do things more quickly', but it is a completely different matter to try to implement change in the real world. There is more to life, as the general public is saying, than computer models.

All economic reform involves changing people's lives. People have a right to be a part of the process of change and they have a right to have an opportunity to input into the process of change. But they do not have the right to control that change. For example, it is easy to campaign that Australia should remove cabotage, but what would that mean in real life? Bear in mind that most, if not all, countries in the OECD retain cabotage for their coastlines. It would mean the virtual destruction of local shipping industry. How can we compete against exploitative wages and conditions? The answer is that we cannot, and more unemployment is not a sensible policy for us to pursue.

So we do not accept the assertions in Fightback about micro-economic reforms being deliverable or being necessarily desirable anyway. This OECD report does not back up the Opposition in this area, although it does tell this particular Government to get a move on. Predictably, the Government, through its Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), has said that the report is out of date in this area because the Government has announced some transport initiatives in the One Nation statement. There is more than a grain of truth in that defence as well.

The OECD has said that there needs to be a more decentralised industrial relations system. Fightback proposals are still a little bit unclear in this area. On the one hand, we have Mr Howard saying that there will be a purely voluntary system of enterprise bargaining in which employees and employers can choose to opt out of the award system, subject to some basic minimum terms and conditions, and they can go on to make their own arrangements. On the face of it, that simply provides that workers can alter their situation if they so choose.

On the other hand, however, we also have Dr Hewson flitting over to New Zealand and floating the adoption of the New Zealand model. This is a completely different proposition from Mr Howard's. It involves the automatic termination of all awards and the substitution of individual contracts. While most people would not have much difficulty with being paid on the basis of how hard they work, the usual New Zealand experience has been that people have been presented with an ultimatum—`Work for less than you used to or you don't work at all'.

The Australian Democrats support a fair system of wages. The point about wage decentralisation is that it affects people's standard of living. People have commitments, such as mortgages and education expenses, just to name a couple. There must be some protection of the weak, as some speakers have already said, if we are to call ourselves a civilised society. As such, the Democrats support the continuation of the Industrial Relations Commission with appropriate powers to ensure that working conditions and wages are fair. The New Zealand model is not a fair system and it is not found anywhere else in OECD countries. There is no endorsement in this OECD report for a totally unregulated labour market. So much for the OECD's endorsement of Fightback policies.

The major matter from which the Opposition has drawn hope is the supposed endorsement of the Opposition's goods and services tax proposal. Firstly, I concur with Senator McMullan that there is no clear recommendation in this report that Australia needs a GST. There is a recognition that the existing wholesale sales tax imposes a 2 per cent increase on business inputs. This can simply be changed by continuing to widen the inputs currently exempted from the tax. Also, the report does not consider the costs that a GST would impose, especially the compliance costs, which fall so disproportionately on the small business sector.

Over the weekend Mr Kelty announced ACTU policy, which confirmed that unions would seek a pay rise to offset the inflationary aspect of the GST. This would compound the inflation effect of the introduction of a GST. It would massively increase the inflation rate and probably lead to widespread industrial action, which would impose further costs on all Australians.

What is the great efficiency that this GST would deliver? It would increase the price of basic food and clothing items and would impact most heavily on families and those on low incomes. As I said before—I have said this often—there is more to life than economic efficiency. There are basic social justice issues, such as the quality of life, which are never factored into the models of such shock-troop of government as the Industry Commission. The imposition of a GST is vigorously opposed by the Democrats. It is not supported by this OECD report, despite the remarks of the Opposition.

The OECD report also touches upon the question of tariffs. This is where the academic nature of the report is fully borne out. The basic rationale is that all tariff protection is bad and it should be eliminated as quickly as possible. This statement is made in the same report which makes the appalling prediction that unemployment will stay above 10 per cent for the next two years. Faster tariff reductions, especially given the chaos in the major engines of the world economy—that is, financial in Japan, social in the United States, and social and industrial in Germany—will inevitably result in higher unemployment in Australia.

The doctrinaire approach of the Opposition on tariffs is very similar to that of the Government. It is just that to this point in time the Government has done a pretty good job of fooling some sections of the media and the community that there is a big difference between Labor and the coalition in this area. The voters in Wills, who are the casualties of this kind of policy, have said, `A pox on both your houses'. It is interesting to note that Hugh Mackay's latest research report confirms that this view is widely held in the community.

I want to step out of the academic analysis, which is so fashionable, and look at the views of some of the industrialists who also have to operate in the economic experiment which the economists tell us is good for them. For example, Carol Austin, the director of public affairs for BHP, is quoted in this week's Bulletin as arguing that we should have reformed our inefficient sectors first and then reduced protection so that we could join the international marketplace with some sort of chance. What ordinary commonsense logic!

I draw an analogy with sport. We do not just send our promising athletes to the Olympics in the hope that they win. We select the most promising young performers, give them the best assistance, the best coaches, and the best facilities; and we nurture their development. This is how we should treat industry. The Government has unilaterally cut tariffs without giving our industries and their work forces a fair go. The country of Chile is cited by Ms Austin as an example of reform before tariff reductions.

Let us look at what another industrialist, Mr Peter Cottrell, managing director of Email, has to say about the Government's tariff reduction in the same Bulletin article. I choose this example because today we heard a lengthy contribution from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) about how Email has been a model firm under the international best practice policy of the Government. Mr Cottrell says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . one logical impact of tariff reductions is for manufacturers to become importers. This is what Email has already done, reducing the number of appliances made in Australia, closing factories and importing brands such as Electrolux and Frigidaire. As the recession has tightened over the past few years, Email has laid off more than 3,000 workers—and lower tariffs are among the reasons.

Causing unemployment is wonderful best practice policy! Reducing tariffs costs jobs in the short term. We must ask: why can we not wait until the economy has picked up and employment is growing again?

PARA.TAB: The Opposition claims that its policy is to achieve these cost savings and efficiencies before reducing tariffs. But in the meantime, it voted in favour of an acceleration of the phase-out of the tariff on sugar. As I have said, the Democrats do not support all of these so-called efficiencies, especially when they are regressive in their impact on the community. But at least there is beginning to be an acknowledgment in the general populace that Australian business must not be sacrificed to unfair competition. In that context, I question the big picture of why the Opposition supports the Government's tariff reductions when the economies it says are necessary have not yet been achieved.

Thus, for all of the reasons stated already, the Democrats do not support this matter of public importance because the OECD report did not strongly endorse the Fightback package and because more deregulation, more privatisation, the total abolition of industry assistance, plus a much harsher social security system and an unfair industrial relations system, are not a recipe for success but are, rather, a recipe for economic and social stagnation, as has occurred during the previous five years in New Zealand.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance that we are discussing—the strong endorsement by the OECD of the policies contained in the coalition's Fightback package of economic reforms—is a most timely discussion. Quite clearly, every Australian knows that the policies of this tired Labor Government, with its unelected Prime Minister, have delivered this country into recession, one million unemployed and a lowered standard of living. Every Australian knows that this Government has got it wrong. Everybody knows that the unelected Prime Minister was the Treasurer during the time of our decline. In the last 48 hours the balance of payments figures have been released, and again they have shown that we are going down into further debt to the tune of yet another $1 billion for the month of March.

PARA.TAB: It is a true amazement that we still have a press that kowtows to the Government to the degree that when the balance of payments figure is under $1 billion it says, `Isn't that a wonderful result?'. The fact that every month we consistently go into greater and greater debt seems to go unnoticed and the impact of it is not properly reported in our media.

Quite frankly, the size of our debt and our inability to deal with it can be compared with an ordinary householder who gets problems with the mortgage, Bankcard and other debts and is simply not earning enough to meet the monthly payments. This country is in the same situation. We have run up an international debt simply because we have not saved enough to provide capital for investment in our own country, and we have had to go overseas and borrow other people's savings. We have to repay those savings, but we are now in a situation where we are not earning enough to make those repayments. No matter how good our import-export figures are, those interest payments put us further into debt every month—somewhere between $14 billion and $20 billion a year. That debt has to be stabilised.

We all know what would happen in the household situation—the bailiffs would come in, they would sell us up and our standard of living would go down. While the country does not have the bailiffs coming in, it has the International Monetary Fund coming in and telling the government of the day, `We will reschedule your debts but you have to apply these policies and those policies'. That happens, and the standard of living goes down again.

The Government seems to have no wish, vision or anything else for a policy that will counteract that, but the Fightback package of the coalition has. The Fightback package has as its central theme the need for tax reform, and it has as its central theme the need for tax reform for all the reasons that the OECD report highlights. Very simply, we have to move away from a reliance on direct taxation where annually, of the $90 billion we collect by way of taxation revenue, $50 billion comes out of individual taxpayers' pockets—$41 billion by way of PAYE payments, and the remainder by way of provisional tax payments.

In reforming this situation we will abolish seven taxes—seven taxes which impact upon the cost of doing business. We will remove $20 billion from the cost of doing business. One of the taxes we will remove is the wholesale sales tax—the tax that presently collects somewhere between $9 billion and $10 billion a year, and the effect of which is built into the cost of every transaction in this country. Even the emotional necessities of life have a component of that wholesale sales tax in them—be it by way of printing or the production of a carton.

Then, of course, there is the petroleum excise which dramatically affects the cost of business in this country, which was described as a country suffering from the tyranny of distance. What do we do? We have a Government which, during its life, has increased the tax on petroleum—26c per litre. The cost of delivering a product even a short distance from the place of manufacture through the wholesaling system into the retailing system, is subject to that tax as well as that wicked tax on jobs, payroll tax.

They are three important taxes which are to be abolished, together with tariff tax, compulsory superannuation—which is another form of payroll tax—and the training levy. That will reduce the cost of doing business by $20 billion. These are the things that are highlighted by the OECD report.

The OECD report notes how the impact of the wholesale sales tax is detrimental to the cost of doing business. It talks about a goods and services tax. That was rejected by the trade union movement in 1985 when Bill Kelty—who was having another spray at it in the weekend press—in the dead of night crept into a motel down the road and told Bob Hawke that it was not on. Of course, whatever the trade union movement says goes—we all know that. Bill Kelty is the unsworn-in member of the Cabinet. If there is a deal between the unelected Prime Minister and the unelected leader of the trade union movement, that is the policy we get.

That is why we will never see this Government carry out the necessary reforms, again highlighted in the OECD report, of the waterfront, transport costs, electricity costs and so on. Quite frankly, that would encroach upon the power of the trade unions. The Labor Party is nothing but the political wing of the trade union movement. We hear it all the time from Senator Cook, when he speaks as a good trade unionist rather than as a Minister of the Crown. We know that the ALP will not cannibalise itself and destroy the power base of the trade union movement. The only way we will see true reform in this country is to see this unelected Prime Minister and his ilk—his troops—thrown out and a coalition government elected.

The OECD report highlights the fact that the privatisation of government assets has not been done to anywhere near the extent that it can be done. It is essential that contracting out, and the other practices advocated in the Fightback package, are implemented.

The Government has combined the worst of all possible worlds. With its corporatisation policy it has pushed what have been government activities off budget and away from the proper scrutiny of the Parliament. The result is that millions of dollars have been dealt with by these so-called GBEs which are not subject to parliamentary scrutiny, unless we have the grace and favour appearance of those agencies before Estimates and other hearings. The OECD singles out Telecom as perhaps—and I use the term facetiously—the star attraction; that is, as the GBE which has had the least productivity gain of any government activity in Australia during the life of this Government.

The OECD report also states that we need swifter tariff reform for the highly protected industries such as the automotive industry—the passenger motor vehicle industry—and the textile, clothing and footwear industry. It is interesting to note where we still have those very high levels of taxation; it is tariff tax. All that so-called protection means—and I have abolished that word from my lexicon—is the imposition of a tax on one group of people with the benefit accruing to another group of people because policy says that that group of people is special and the rest are not special at all.

Consider a struggling family, or a single mother on a pension trying to cope with feeding and clothing her offspring.
