What happens to her when she goes into K-mart to buy an inexpensive item of clothing for her small daughter? What happens to the price of that garment? The imposition of the tariff tax on an imported garment, which would enable a mother to dress her child with pride—and the same applies to shoes—has an effective consumption tax component in excess of 25 per cent. In other words, tariff tax penalises the people at the lowest end of the economic scale, the people most in need of access to cheaper goods. The reduction of tariff tax and swifter reform in that regard is highlighted by the OECD report.

With regard to the direction of monetary policy, the report highlights the need to maintain low inflation. It notes that this direction must be pursued with a medium term focus by a central bank afforded greater independence. Each of the points that the OECD report makes is reflected in our Fightback package. The report highlights the desperate need for labour market reform. That means the undoing of all those deals done at the time of Federation, when Victoria and New South Wales said that they would bear the financial brunt of paying the mendicant States in return for Federation. But Victoria in return said, `We'll do that but we have to have protectionism and a centralised wage fixing system'.

That was, in a way, able to work while we had a fixed exchange rate on the pound. But once that went the rest of it became quite unsustainable and the need to move to true labour market reform, in the way it is set out in our industrial relations reform policy—

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't set it out yet.

—Indeed we have set it out. We have made it quite clear that the essence of our policy is to allow that quite radical thing to occur—that employers should be allowed to talk to employees without the intervention of the trade union movement. That is very clearly spelt out and it is a fundamental principle that will bring about radical change.

PARA.TAB: The report identifies the distinguishing factor of our industrial relations system as the slow and heavy process of recourse to the conciliation and arbitration tribunals—the very ones that Senator Cook attacks on a regular basis, taking away any sense that there ever was in the Government's argument that the Industrial Relations Commission could in any way be an impartial arbiter. The Commission has been attacked viciously by the people who purport to claim that it is somehow independent and an arbiter. It is not. It has been undermined and demeaned by the people who say that it is necessary. Our policy is a much more honest and straightforward one.

The other remarks that need to be made about this report are these: here is an OECD report which supports the policies that we have outlined and yet it is based on briefings given by the Government's own department—Treasury. The difference between the conclusions to which the Government came in its One Nation statement and those to which the OECD came is that presumably the officers who briefed the OECD from September through to January were people who were not politicised and were not drawing politicised conclusions but were simply feeding in the raw data to be interpreted by others in an impartial way.

When we had the Estimates hearings on several occasions we asked Treasury representatives about the special micro-economic model that they built to test the coalition's Fightback package. We asked them whether they tested the One Nation package, or the `No Nation' package as it is more aptly called. They refused to answer. Senator McMullan, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer who was attending that hearing, refused to let them answer because the Government would have been embarrassed by the answer.

This Government has succeeded in politicising parts of the public sector to do party political work. That is one of the great wickednesses that this Government has wrought upon the public sector. So when we see that raw data is given to the OECD and that it can come up with conclusions which are at variance with the One Nation statement, all we can hear is a bleating from Senator McMullan that one really cannot count that because it really does not matter too much. I am sorry that Senator McMullan is not here. But it does indeed matter, because we have seen the Treasury supply figures to the OECD, we have seen an impartial analysis of those figures and we have seen the resultant report which backs up the Fightback package and the policies outlined in our 20-point plan which, quite frankly, will abolish seven taxes, bring about true micro-economic reform, replace the wholesale sales tax with a goods and services tax, increase pensions and lower income tax—truly a policy for recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter before us today is the so-called `strong endorsement by the OECD of the policies contained in the coalition's Fightback! package'. I say `so-called' because an analysis of the OECD report reveals there is no strong endorsement of the coalition's Fightback package, and I will come to that a little later. The main reason that the Opposition has raised this matter today is that it is getting very desperate because it wants bad news and over recent months there has not been a succession of bad news.

PARA.TAB: We have an inflation rate that is now nil, amongst the lowest of all the OECD nations. We have an improving balance of payments and we have an increase in job advertisements. So it is very clear that the recession is at an end and that we are returning to economic growth. But the Opposition is desperate to seize upon any sort of half news that it believes accepts its particular policies. The Opposition is desperate in seizing upon the OECD report and drawing attention, in some areas, to some small amount of endorsement of its particular approach.

The Opposition is increasingly desperate because the Wills by-election reflected the fact—and I will be quite honest about it—that whilst there has been some level of disillusionment in terms of political support for the Government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—Senator Patterson can laugh but the people of Wills did not exactly embrace the Opposition, did they?
—Your vote went down by 7 per cent.

—As Senator Cook says, the Liberal-National vote went down by 7 per cent. On the following day the former Liberal Prime Minister Mr Fraser came out and said that it should have been the Liberals' Bass by-election. That was hardly a ringing endorsement of the Liberal-National parties' Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to a number of comments made in the previous contribution by Senator Bishop. She said that the OECD report was based on Government briefings. That is partly correct, but she is guilty of an untruth in that she left out reference to the other organisations that the OECD receives briefings from.

The OECD does not talk just to the Government. It talks to State governments, business organisations and the trade union movement. The OECD takes into account a range of views. Its report is not based, even substantially, on the input provided by the Federal Government. So Senator Bishop should be a lot more honest in her analysis of the briefings given as input to this report.

Other areas of great untruth in her speech involve the continual assertion that the Opposition is about abolishing seven taxes. One of the taxes she referred to, the coal levy, has already been abolished by this Government. So we are down to six taxes.

The Opposition refers to the abolition of the education and training guarantee levy. In fact, a substantial number of businesses in this country were spending on education and training an amount in excess of the levy. If the levy is abolished, it is highly unlikely that that will have any effect whatsoever on business costs. So, again, it is an abolition in name rather than in fact.

The Opposition speaks about abolishing a superannuation tax. This must be the greatest area of hypocrisy that I have heard from the Opposition. First of all, Senator Bishop confused the superannuation guarantee levy with the taxes on superannuation. If she reads the Opposition's Fightback package—and obviously she has not—she will find that the Opposition is pledged to maintain the superannuation guarantee levy at its existing level, should the Opposition get into government. That is hardly likely, but if the Opposition does get into government the superannuation guarantee levy, if it is passed, will stand at 5 per cent. So there is no pledge by the Opposition to remove the superannuation guarantee levy. Senator Bishop is confusing the superannuation guarantee levy with the Opposition's proposed reduction, in some areas, of taxation on superannuation.

Again, Senator Bishop has not read the Opposition policy because the Opposition makes the point that it will increase some of the taxes on superannuation. The Opposition will increase the tax on superannuation investment income from 15 per cent to 25 per cent. In fact, there is no net reduction in superannuation taxes in the coalition package. So that is strike three—a third tax measure that is of absolutely no benefit whatsoever to business.

We then have the example of payroll tax. Payroll tax does not apply to the majority of businesses in this country. So that is strike four. We will give Senator Bishop half a point; payroll tax does apply to big business in this country, but it does not apply to small business. So we have three and a half taxes that do not apply to business in this country. So the position put by those opposite, particularly Senator Bishop, on the abolition of so-called taxes and levies is a half-truth.

Of course, in the other breath, Senator Bishop draws our attention to the balance of payments. The Opposition refuses to recognise the effect that a reduction in the petrol tax would have on the balance of payments. This is at worst petrol pump populism by those opposite, pandering to the National Party and its constituency. A reduction in petrol taxes would lead to a very significant increase in demand and an increase in the import of petroleum or oil into this country. That would have a devastating effect on the balance of payments. So one can have it both ways when in opposition—one certainly cannot have it both ways in government.

I would have to commend the speech that was made by Senator Kernot. Whilst I do not agree with some of the remarks that she made, I think the overall balance of her speech was very good. Senator Kernot referred to tariff reductions that occurred after restructuring in Chile. I would point out that a brutal military regime carried out that restructuring, with devastating social consequences. There was a dramatic widening of the poverty and wealth gap in that nation. Some economists might like to allude to this as the way that we should go. Certainly, the fallout from that experimentation has been quite devastating. I think we can point to similar social consequences in the United States and the United Kingdom.

I return to the OECD report which purportedly supports the Opposition's Fightback policy. The OECD report is relevant in this debate in terms of its comments about inflation, micro-economic reform, the goods and services tax, labour market reform, education and training, and tariffs. The survey contains some statements that the Government believes are overdrawn. As I have said, the survey is based on a variety of views and inputs in this country.

The Government does not agree with all the survey. We do not accept all of its views. But there is much in the survey that we can agree with. There is nothing unusual in that—it is all part of the healthy economic debate that is taking place in this country.

The claims by the OECD in relation to inflation clearly have to be rejected. The OECD would prefer a more independent watch on our inflation rate through the Reserve Bank of Australia. Of course, the Opposition has made great play of the fact that it intends to allow the central bank to have greater independence. I would argue that it is results that count. We have an inflation rate that is almost the lowest amongst OECD countries. The nil inflation rate that we have at the present time is something that we can be proud of and boast about. This very commendable result was not achieved by an independent central bank.

We would reject the approach that the Opposition originally announced of having an explicit inflation target of zero. I notice that the Opposition backtracked on that last week. The Opposition shadow Treasurer, Mr Reith, in fact did concede that there were circumstances in which a zero inflation rate was inappropriate. So the current inflation rate stands to the credit of this country and this Government. The likelihood of the inflation rate remaining low for a significant period is certainly very high.

I would reject any criticism or suggestion by the OECD that we need to change our approach to inflation. The OECD did not adopt explicit inflation targets. It did not recommend that Australia should adopt an inflation target in any way. The survey did note that New Zealand and Canada had chosen to address their inflation levels by adopting an explicit intermediary inflation target. This is, to some extent, totally contradictory to adopting a policy of a GST which, of course, would increase inflation. I will get to the comments about the GST shortly.

OECD observes that there has been much significant progress in the last decade in the area of micro-economic reform. Our Government is the government that has implemented reform in the micro-economic area. The Opposition did nothing when in government. Its record was a flat zero. Of course, the OECD report was put together prior to the release of the One Nation package. There is explicit reference in the One Nation package to reforms in the areas of transport, electricity and education—the three areas in which there was some criticism by the OECD.

In the area of transport, the Government announced that it would be placing higher priority on rail, highway and competitive ports. It announced that the Brisbane-Sydney-Melbourne rail line would be modernised and upgraded; that a standard gauge spur would be built to the Port of Brisbane; that a new rail-sea-road terminus would be constructed at Dynon in Melbourne; and that the rail facilities at the ports of Fremantle and Adelaide would be upgraded. It also announced that an extra $600m would be spent on road construction.

In the area of aviation, where there has been a revolution in the last decade, the Government has announced policies that will allow Qantas to carry domestic passengers. The Government expects that Australian and Ansett will be operating across the Tasman by 1993.

In the area of power generation—and, frankly, this is a State, not a Federal, government responsibility—the Government has facilitated greater cooperation towards a national power grid by offering $100m to upgrade the transmission link between New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. So there is positive reform in the micro-economic area.

It is not correct to say that the OECD report embraces a GST. It makes a passing reference to the issue of GST. It concludes that, as regards tax reform, there is further room for improvement. A number of issues are being addressed by this Government and the simplification of sales tax is occurring. The report concludes that it may be beneficial for the economy in the long run. Of course, embracing the introduction of a GST is at odds with a low inflation policy. There would be a very significant increase in inflation if we embraced a GST tax. This is aside from the fact that this Government rejects such a tax because it would be socially inequitable and unfair to 70 per cent of Australians.

The OECD report is somewhat contradictory in the area of labour market reform. It supports the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the move away from centralised wage fixing in favour of decentralised enterprise bargaining. This stands in contrast to the approach of those opposite who want individual bargaining, which would strip away the independence of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It would also lead to the removal of such entitlements as annual leave, sick leave, long service leave and superannuation. That is what the Opposition policy means. The OECD is not endorsing that. The survey is somewhat contradictory in that it notes the Commission's decision to put in place a number of checks to limit wage flow-ons. That was prudent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that portion of Senator Sherry's speech which I did hear was not any better than the portion that I did not hear, it was undoubtedly a pathetic defence—
—It wasn't.

—Senator Short says that the part I did not hear was no better. We must therefore conclude that his speech in toto was a pathetic defence of the Government's position and, in particular, a pathetic defence on behalf of the Government against this OECD report. Of course, that is why the coalition—and in particular Senator Short, Senator Bishop and I—has proposed as a matter of public importance the strong endorsement by the OECD of the policies contained in the our Fightback package of economic reforms.

PARA.TAB: I heard Senator Sherry claim that the abolition of payroll tax, which is a key part of our Fightback package, will have no impact on small businesses because they do not pay payroll tax. What Senator Sherry has forgotten is that every small business pays payroll tax when it buys goods and services from those big businesses which do have to pay payroll tax, because the cost of that payroll tax is added into the cost of the goods and services which those big businesses produce and which are often bought by small businesses for use in the products which they in turn produce.

Senator Sherry also claimed that the abolition of fuel excise, another very important part of the Fightback package, would have a devastating effect on our balance of payments because it would increase demand. He completely ignores the fact that the efficiencies and incentives which Fightback will offer to business will encourage greater oil exploration and greater discovery of oil in Australia. But, more importantly, it will not encourage significantly increased demand for oil products. What it will do is reduce the cost of goods and services in Australia because, with the enormous size of Australia and our relatively small population, the cost of transport makes up a much higher proportion of the cost of goods and services than it does in many other countries.

It is absolute nonsense to retain an impost on fuel which adds to that cost of transport. We need to get rid of it if we are going to make the Australian economy internationally competitive and make the cost of our goods and services competitive with those provided in overseas countries so that our producers can not only compete against imports, but also have a great chance of competing with Australian goods and services on export markets.

I notice that Senator Sherry has left the chamber. He obviously does not like his false claims being contradicted. Senator Sherry then cited Chile as an example of the way in which Fightback-type policies would be devastating. Let me remind Senator Sherry and other members opposite that, in fact, Chile is one of the few countries in South America that has achieved an economic turnaround because it has adopted the sorts of policies which the Liberal and National parties advocate. As a result of that, it is now among the best performing economies in South America. That country now has a much brighter future than many other countries in South America—

TALK.START.PARA: —At the point of a gun.

—As a direct result of the sorts of policies we are advocating in the economic field. Senator Sherry then went on to claim that central bank independence was not necessary to achieve a sufficiently low inflation rate. He lauded this present Government's achievements on inflation. When one drives the economy into the depths of depression, as this Government has, of course one is going to have a low rate of inflation. This Government has driven the Australian economy into the ground. That is the only reason we now have an acceptably low rate of inflation. If we are to have the sort of growth and prosperity of which this country is capable if Fightback policies are introduced, then we will need to give the central bank, the Reserve Bank, independence and give it a charter to keep inflation low in that much better economic context.

PARA.TAB: So the message from last week's release of the January report of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, which is based in Paris, is very clear. There are a number of messages which that report makes clear: first, that Mr Keating has failed to meet the challenge that the Australian economy provides at the moment. He has failed to deliver and both he and his Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) have failed Australia and the Australian people.

Second, growth forecasts for the 1992-93 financial year are predictably quite low but, in fact, are not as rosy as the present Labor Government would have us believe. Third, the Federal Government remains in trouble because micro-economic reform has not been implemented sufficiently quickly or efficiently despite the fact that the Government continues to attempt to convince us that it is on track and in tune with Australian industry.

Fourth, the Fightback proposals of the coalition will significantly reduce the burden on business inputs through the abolition of wholesale sales tax and the substitution of that tax with a goods and services tax which, of course, will not be levied on business inputs. Fifth, productivity levels in government business enterprises are about half the average of the OECD countries. Sixth, labour productivity in Australian railways is less than half of that in the United States and Canada.

Seventh, a 1990 study showed that Telecom has the lowest productivity of the telecommunications providers in the nine OECD countries surveyed. Eighth, Qantas ranks only seventeenth in productivity terms compared with major international airlines. Ninth, the private sector reflects productivity well below that of other industrialised nations with which we compete. Tenth and finally, micro-economic reform, including tariff reform, will add something like $22 billion to the size of the Australian economy and expand employment by about 53,000.

The OECD has not declared the end to the worst recession in Australia in more than 60 years. Its view is, as I said earlier, that low inflation has been achieved at the cost of unemployment rates of more than 10 per cent. The embarrassed and shameful attempts of the present Treasurer to shrug off some of the OECD's unpalatable findings and attacks on the Government's economic policies in its recent biannual report on the state of the Australian economy are as pathetic as the media release he put out last Friday when he claimed that the OECD's growth and employment projections were both dated and clearly understated.

The Treasurer claimed that the report did not take into account the boost to activity coming from the Government's 26 February One Nation statement. So what? In the two months since that statement there has not been any evidence at all that One Nation is providing any boost to activity or employment. In fact, since February we have seen unemployment hit the staggering 11 per cent mark. That is 11 per cent of working Australians now out of work—unable to find a job of any kind. Is this the mark of the Government's success? Is this the record that it wants us to look at? Is this, in fact, the basis on which the Treasurer would claim that the OECD report is out of date?

Union activity still manages to halt production and hold up productivity. Industries are moribund and failing and bankruptcies have become commonplace in many quarters. The fiscal stimulation in One Nation just does not account for the differences between the OECD and the Government's growth estimates. Even Professor Ross Garnaut highlights that the One Nation statement increases the risk in the medium term.

Professor Garnaut clearly disagrees with the Treasurer and the Government. On last Friday's ABC PM program, he reinforced the findings of the OECD report. His conclusions were that it was very far reaching and confronted many of the issues facing Australia; one of which was the importance of accelerating this country's flagging structural or so-called micro-economic reform. He did not discount the report as irrelevant simply because it was prepared prior to the release of the Government's One Nation statement. He did not advise us that the effects of the drought were not countered. He said that we had made some progress but we had not made enough. In fact, we have not made nearly enough progress in the important areas of reform that are required. He said that we were not moving fast enough and that the OECD report was correct in underlining and focusing on these issues. So, quite apart from the OECD, Professor Garnaut has raised the concern that we in the Opposition have now held for a long time: that Australia is not moving fast enough to address the areas of growth in export industries and that faster progress on transport and communications efficiency must be made.

The OECD's message is distinct and lucid. For all the claptrap from the Government about its claims of micro-economic reform and improved industry efficiencies, Australia is still way behind the most efficient industrialised economies. Of course, if we continue our reform at this laggardly pace, they will jump farther and farther ahead because they are not standing still. Other countries are continuing their reform process and unless we catch up to their pace of reform, we simply fall farther behind.

After a decade of Labor Government, we need look only at where we now find ourselves. Australia now ranks in the bottom third of the OECD list of living standards, having fallen from near the top. It is this Government that has put us there by its misguided and wayward attempts at economic management. Not only has the OECD caustically criticised Australia's productivity record and questioned whether it will improve, unless structural reform is pursued more vigorously, but by the release of its report it has lent the great weight of its support to a goods and services tax, which is an essential part of the Opposition's Fightback program, as being better for business than the Government's present wholesale sales tax regime. The OECD confirms what the Liberal and National parties have argued for a long time, which is that a goods and services tax will remove the tax burden on business inputs which the Government's present sales tax maintains.

The OECD has said that monetary policy has been primarily responsible for getting inflation down in Australia, whereas the Prime Minister claims that this is nonsense. He says that zero inflation came about because of the Government's incomes policy. He says that the Government alone can claim that it was able to break the back of Australia's inflation. As I said earlier, we all know that in fact it was this Government's monetary policy and its enormously high interest rates which destroyed so many businesses and jobs and which have resulted in inflation being as low as it now is. For the Government arrogantly to argue otherwise simply reinforces what the Opposition has known for a long time, and that is that the time for this Government is running out and that its days are numbered.

The OECD report has rightly cast competent doubt over the One Nation statement and rightly attacked the Keating Government's economic policies. As a consequence, Treasurer Dawkins is bleating that it was not done the right way. The OECD has forecast higher unemployment, lower growth and higher inflation than is claimed will happen under the Government's One Nation statement. It clearly indicates that Australia must accelerate all of its reform process if we are to boost productivity sufficiently. It further points out that Australia is likely to lag considerably in the ensuing economic upturn because of high business debt and a surplus of commercial property.
With regard to the goods and services tax the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Simplifications of sales taxes, while not necessarily a priority issue, may be beneficial for the economy in the longer term.

If Australians want rapid economic growth, more jobs and higher real wages—and there is certainly no doubt among all the people whom I speak to in the community that they do—we must press on with the reform process at a much more rapid rate than this Government offers, including tariff cuts, regardless of what is happening in other countries. That is the essence of Fightback! and there is no question that the policies contained in Fightback! will achieve all this.

PARA.TAB: The OECD report endorses a number of the coalition's proposals contained in the Fightback package, including the full privatisation of Government-owned enterprises and a greater reduction in tariffs in the highly protected industries, such as car manufacturing and clothing, textiles and footwear, in association with those structural reform measures which will reduce the costs of production.

The OECD also supports the coalition's proposals to reform our ports and open up coastal shipping and trans-Tasman shipping to foreign competition. Most importantly, the OECD report supports the replacement of our centralised wage system and industrial awards with enterprise bargaining, including a single national minimum wage as has occurred in New Zealand. It endorses our notion that monetary policy should be directed towards achieving low inflation. With regard to wages the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The less responsive are wage increases to higher unemployment, the more prolonged will be high unemployment following a tightening of monetary policy.

We must implement the Fightback proposals as quickly as possible. The OECD recognises that; the people of Australia recognise that, and that is why they will throw this Government out at the next election and give Fightback the chance to restore their prosperity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that we all use quotations selectively and try to find those quotations in any report that best suit the arguments we are trying to proffer. However, Senator Chapman is arguing more selectively than anybody I have ever heard. I can understand why the Opposition wants to latch on to anything that appears to be support for what I believe is an increasingly discredited Fightback package. Having enjoyed an early honeymoon, while we in the Government were a little preoccupied, the package has come under increasing criticism. It is now well and truly upstaged by One Nation, which I believe has caught the mood of the electorate in a way that Fightback has not. It has made Fightback yesterday's plan and One Nation tomorrow's plan.

PARA.TAB: I can understand why the Opposition is now grasping at straws, but the fact is that the Opposition can take no succour from the OECD report. First, the report was written before the One Nation statement, as other speakers have indicated, so that many of the conclusions and predictions need revision. This aside, the report by no means is an endorsement of the Opposition's proposals, as is claimed by the Opposition, any more than it is a critique of Government policies. It is an objective analysis of Australia's current position and where the OECD sees us going.

As an objective assessment, it will have people arguing for and against it. It represents the views of a group of economists, and no group of economists will ever attract a consensus of views. However, it does focus attention on the fact that the Government has achieved a level of inflation which is not only lower than that of our trading partners, but is historically low. I quote from page 9 of the OECD report:

SPEECH.PARA: Importantly, inflation expectations have also fallen substantially, indeed to historically low levels, unlike the experience of the previous recession.
And at page 34:
Whereas inflation has always fallen in past recessions, the marked reduction in inflation expectations is unique in this downturn.
And again at pages 48 and 49:

Despite the strong rise in demand in the late 1980s, inflation did not increase, principally reflecting the operation of the Accord and exchange rate appreciation. . . .Inflation across a range of measures has now fallen below the OECD average, to levels not seen for a generation;. . .

The OECD is then keen to draw attention to the fact that we have achieved very low inflation, that that inflation is lower than our trading partners but that, in addition, it is historically low for Australia. The report also makes the point that it is very important to lock in this lower rate of inflation and that this should be our prime consideration. The report states on page 88:

The challenge to the authorities in the 1990s is to match their excellent record in debt reduction, tariff and agricultural reforms in the 1980s by locking in low inflation and by further advancing structural reform.
I might add that that quotation hardly sounds like a criticism of the Government.

PARA.TAB: By implication, however, it is critical of the Opposition's package which includes in-built inflation. On its own estimates of 4.7 per cent—although I think this a fairly optimistic estimate—it seems to take the view that nobody will raise prices when costs have increased. On our estimate—including some other assumptions, such as the inclusion of road user charges—it might be as high as 5.6 per cent. However, between 4.7 and 5.6 per cent inflation is built into the Fightback package.
This is clearer if we look at the estimated price effects of the Opposition package on some everyday consumer goods. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), in his statement of 3 March, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the Opposition package on food products generally will be 8.9% overall (or 9.57% with the effect of road user charges):
. dairy products will increase by 9.6% (10.4% with road user charges)
. cereal products will increase by 9.2% (9.9% with road charges)
. fresh fruit and vegetables will increase by 10.1% (11% with road charges).

He said that clothing would rise by 11.2 per cent, or 11.8 per cent with road user charges; electricity by 10.7 per cent, or 11.2 per cent with road user charges; post and telephone services by 8.1 per cent, or 8.5 with road user charges; and health services by 22.6 per cent, or 22.9 per cent with road user charges. That, according to the Opposition, would be good for the country.

PARA.TAB: The OECD's report is about the Australian economy and its prospects; it is not about Fightback. The OECD has not analysed Fightback. If it did, it would find—as Treasury, Finance and the Taxation Department found in their analysis prior to the Treasurer's statement in March—that there is, as I have already said, an in-built inflation of between 4.7 per cent and 5.6 per cent, which we can ill-afford now; that there is, and we seem to have forgotten this in recent months, a $4 billion fiscal hole which still has not been filled by the Opposition; and that the distributional effects of the package are, in fact, illusory.
I will quote again from the Treasurer's statement of 3 March 1992. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, so far as it is possible to follow the consumption tax money trail and using the Opposition's methodology. . . that trail leads to an outcome where over 70% of households of full-time wage and salary earners and about 60% of self-employed and farmer households would be worse off under the Opposition's proposed arrangements. . . In particular, the Treasury analysis shows that wage and salary earner and self-employed and farm households on incomes of $90,000 a year and above would be better off by between $15 and $105 a week—that is, by up to $5,460 a year better off.By contrast, married full-time wage and salary earners with non-working spouses and children, and family incomes up to $57,000 a year, would be worse off by up to $8 a week—that is, up to $400 a year worse off.

Similarly, self-employed and farm households with incomes up to $61,000 a year would be anything up to $12 a week worse off. . . Further, the Treasury analysis shows that, under the Opposition's preferred Scenario C on the tax measures alone—that is, not factoring in any other changes—all people paying tax on incomes below $40,000 a year would not be adequately compensated both for bracket creep and for the price effect of the Opposition's package. That is, the Opposition's own proposed tax scales would not compensate low and middle income earners for its new food and clothing tax. . . For example, a taxpayer on an income of $30,000 a year would receive a tax cut of 6.8% under the Opposition's announced plan but, after taking account of bracket creep and the CPI impact of the consumption tax, taxpayers on this income would still suffer a decline in real disposable income of some 2%.
Thus, while taxpayers on an income of $30,000 a year would be $9.20 a week worse off, people on $100,000 a year would be $73.20 a week better off.

In other words, taxpayers on $30,000, would receive a tax cut which would be only about three-quarters of that necessary to compensate for the introduction of the consumption tax. But people on $100,000 would get a tax cut which is almost double that which would be adequate to compensate them for the reduction in their purchasing power.
The point of quoting that passage of the report is that the distributional effects of the package, which are made much of by the Opposition, simply are not there; they are illusory.

PARA.TAB: If the OECD were to do an analysis of the GST and the Fightback package, it would find not only that it is grossly regressive, despite vain attempts at compensation, but also that it contains in-built inflation which would blow apart the advantages we now enjoy over our trading partners. In the light of this, it is doubtful that any OECD analysis of Fightback would have contained any comfort for the Opposition.

Add to this the fact that small business people and self-employed people will become unpaid tax collectors, and I think we have an almost unworkable scheme. It will mean, for example, that those small business people and self-employed people will suffer a massive increase in red tape—inflicted by an Opposition that claims it is going to get rid of red tape—as they attempt to record returns and collect and pay taxes on all the goods they produce and services they provide. It will mean massive increases in administration as they try to assess and claim rebates for inputs. It will mean that they will bear the brunt of compliance costs.

If we take the UK experience, following the introduction of the value added tax, which is very similar to the GST being proposed by the Opposition, we see that compliance costs in that country are 260 times greater for smaller companies than they are for big business. The smaller companies are the ones which are going to bear the brunt of the cost of compliance with this tax. Small business people and self-employed people will become the unpaid tax collectors for the Government. I think, once they find that out, once it sinks in—the Opposition has not told them yet, but certainly we will—there will not be too many of them prepared to vote for it.

More fundamental than all of this are other elements of the package which draw a clear distinction between the Government and the Opposition in the way each approaches the question of economic reform. The Opposition seems determined to apply the blowtorch to the economy. It is a macho approach which was best expressed by Senator Chapman when he was speaking: nothing is going fast enough; reform is not fast enough; crash through and we will make sure that reform happens regardless of the chaos which it leaves in the process. It sets Australian against Australian. It is a return to the confrontation of previous years—the Fraser years, for example.

Policies which the Opposition has announced as part of the Fightback package in health, education, welfare and industrial relations are, I believe, cruel, brutal policies, which this nation will not accept and which will be thrown out by the electorate when it gets a chance to vote on them. I believe the Australian people have already shown that in the Ashburton by-election in Western Australia, which was fought not by our choice but by the choice of the Opposition on the GST. The Opposition achieved the startling swing of about 3 per cent in a by-election atmosphere in Western Australian circumstances—which I think is an abysmal result—and we won the seat handsomely. It was the GST which won that seat for us primarily, although we had a very good candidate as well.

By contrast, the Government has gone to great lengths to involve all parties in the process of reform. It has done this to make sure that, once consultation has occurred, reform is accepted by all and that the reforms, once accepted by all, are lasting as a result. Much has been achieved in workplace reform, award restructuring and industry reform. I would like to quote again from the report, which makes that point itself. Page 57 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Significant progress has been made in deregulation of domestic aviation, introducing competition into telecommunications, enhancing efficiency in transport (shipping, rail and road), liberalising foreign investment, and privatising or corporatising government business enterprises, as well as a start in rationalising State and Commonwealth Government functions.
So the report recognises that significant reforms have been made. On tariffs, page 73 states:

To date, the single most important structural reform undertaken was the decision to cut Australia's high tariff rates unilaterally in the early 1980s. . . The 1991 extension will ultimately reduce average tariffs to about 2 per cent in the next decade.
So the report concedes that as well.

PARA.TAB: Despite the Opposition's jibes in this area, it is worth noting that on a recent visit to this country the Secretary-General of the OECD, M. Jean-Claude Paye, said that he had witnessed in Australia between 1985 when he was last here and this year a sea change in management attitudes. He said that instead of being cringing, inward-looking and timid, they were outward-looking, aggressive and export oriented. He said of the union movement that it was visionary—that was his term. He said that widely around the place. He said that union movement here was visionary in a way that he was not aware of in any other country in the world. The fact is that fundamental changes in management, work practice and industry structures—(Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Senator Beahan is the final speaker in the debate on the matter of public importance. The discussion is now concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The United Nations has proclaimed 1994 as the International Year of the Family, and rightly so. The stability of society is a reflection of the stability of the family. I regret to say that family life is breaking down in Australia and, unfortunately, this is manifested in many antisocial activities, particularly by young people.

PARA.TAB: The Institute of Family Studies has an important charter: to identify and to meet the public need for reliable and policy relevant information about factors affecting marital and family well-being in Australia. Unfortunately, the Government's priority to family issues must be questioned, particularly if one looks at this Government's financial contribution to the Institute of Family Studies. In fact, the Board of the Institute is concerned about the stagnation of its budget in recent years and has constantly argued for a larger appropriation.

I refer to the budgets granted to other bodies. In 1990-91 the Institute received $2.72m. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission received $8.9m; the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies received $5.3m; and the Australian Institute of Health received $4.9m. I do not wish to criticise the absolute grants to each of those bodies, but I think it is significant that the Institute of Family Studies ranks well below each of those.

My concern is not only as to these absolute amounts but as to what is happening in terms of percentage increases and growth. We see from the report that the Institute has been less well off. For example, the Australian Institute of Health has had a 56 per cent increase over the past two years; the Australian Institute of Criminology an 18 per cent increase; the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission a 56 per cent increase. The Institute of Family Studies received an increase of only 10 per cent. That 10 per cent increase in funds was mainly for a long-awaited computer upgrade which, in effect, was a one-off gain rather than an ongoing appropriation.

It appears that this Government is requiring the Institute of Family Studies to do its important work with one hand tied behind its back. In fact, it says that several approaches have been made for external funds for research—for example, for the disabled—but without success. In fact, the Institute has contributed papers to the national inquiry on community violence. This is an area that demands much better research than has yet been done.

Unfortunately, the Institute is not eligible to apply for additional funds from the Australian Research Council. In fact, it has not been able to receive grants from charitable trusts because it does not have tax exempt status under section 73 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I remind the Senate that in recent years the Institute's budget allocation to core, basic staffing has grown because of salary increments, retention rates and superannuation. The problem is that the Institute is left with very little money for variable costs with which it can contribute to new research. Thus, I put it to the Senate that the Government expects this Institute to perform vital work but with one hand tied behind its back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report of the Institute of Family Studies. I want to give credit where it is due because I believe that over the years this Institute has been doing very useful work in putting on the public record more and more information about families. For example, in the last year the Institute did a valuable study on the Defence families of Australia. It is incredible—in fact, I could not believe it when I came to this place six years ago—just how little information there is on the dependants of the Defence Force.

PARA.TAB: In most cases, the dependants of employees are not all that important to employers, but in the case of the Defence Force they must be vitally important. The Government has a responsibility to house them, to move them from one job to another, and it has a number

SPEECH.PARA: of allowances to which these families are entitled. Clearly, the Government was not keeping a good enough record of what its responsibilities were and to whom. The Government did not know how many disabled children it was moving from place to place; it did not know whether they were getting proper education; it did not know whether they needed special education or health facilities; and, if so, how many of them needed such assistance. The report has been valuable. I am sure that the policies to be developed in future by the Department of Defence and the government of the future will rely heavily on the work done by the Institute.

PARA.TAB: I also find that outside the Defence area specially useful information is being gathered. I was saddened by a study which was reported in, I think, the December edition of Family Matters which referred to a study of mothers and fathers of very young children. I cannot remember the precise figures, but I think that some 60 per cent of mothers and fathers expressed a wish that, in an ideal world, the mother would stay home and look after the children while they were young. However, financial circumstances meant that this could be only a dream. It seems to me that we are failing the children of our nation; we are failing their parents who are battling so very hard in today's economy if we cannot give proper attention to the needs of the families with very young children.

Governments make policies based on a whole lot of material. The Institute of Family Studies has always been very careful to give proper attention to the needs of families where both parents are in the workplace. It was very interesting to find parents registering how strongly was the wish that, for some period at least, they could have only one parent in the workplace. I challenge the Government to do more for families with very young children and only one income. I think there is a big lack in that area which must be addressed in policy terms.

As a member of a political party, I find it is extremely useful to be able to turn to the research work done by the Institute of Family Studies for policy development and to look ahead to see what Australia's future needs will be. The year 1994 will be the International Year of the Family. Obviously all Australians will be giving even more attention than usual in that year to the needs of Australia's families. It takes quite a long time to develop policies and programs which are appropriate and needed by the Australian community. We cannot suddenly arrive at 1994 and say, `Wouldn't it be a good idea if we did this?'. Clearly, it is valuable to have the research material which the Institute provides and slowly, in a careful and appropriate way, develop measures which will be of value to Australian families. The Opposition is doing just that. A number of the policies which apply, particularly to women and children, in the Fightback package have been developed from work done by the Institute. In addition, the consultations which I have been having with Australian women are adding to that policy development.

I commend the work of the Institute. I remember very well when it was set up by the Fraser Government, a Liberal Government. I believe the Liberal Party has found the work it has done very useful. As Opposition spokesman on the status of women, I have found it very valuable indeed. I only wish that the Institute were better able to do the work that I know it could do if it had more resources. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The purpose of the Bill is to set in place the final stage of the legislative framework to meet obligations under the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, so that Australia can proceed with ratification of the Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Attorney-General introduced the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act in 1990 he said that it represented the first step in the process of Australia's ratification of the Convention.

Ratification of this Convention is in accordance with the Government's ongoing commitment to the international fight against illicit drug traffic and abuse. The Convention seeks to ensure that the international community co-operates in the adoption of a wide range of measures aimed at stemming the illicit drug trade.

Mr Duffy said in August 1990 that ratification of this Convention will achieve one of the aims of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, which has the support of all governments in Australia. The States and Territories have been aware of the proposed Convention and the Commonwealth's wish to become a party to it from the beginning of the drafting process in 1985, and their views were sought at each stage of the negotiation process.

Since that time the Government has continued with a process of consultation and negotiation with all of the States and Territories to identify areas of the Convention which can be given effect to by State and Territory legislation. The purpose of this consultation was to preserve the existing balance of responsibilities in the drugs area. The Government has been, as Mr Duffy said in his second reading speech in August 1990, very much aware of the importance of not encroaching on areas of State jurisdiction in this field, and fully supports the continuation of the cooperative approach to drug law enforcement with the State and Territory governments and their law enforcement agencies.

In particular, the Government has sought State and Territory co-operation in enacting legislation to meet the mandatory obligations which the Convention imposes on parties. This includes legislation relating to money laundering, where the money or property has been derived from a drug trafficking offence against State or Territory law.
Unfortunately, there have been delays in some of the States and Territories, and some legislation is still to be enacted.
The amendments give effect to particular obligations created by the Convention. These are obligations with respect to criminalising money laundering, and confiscating the proceeds of drug offences.
The legislation relies on the external affairs power and therefore follows the terminology of the Convention where appropriate.

First, the Bill provides a shorthand description of various forms of conduct which are called `dealing in drugs'. The conduct identified as `dealing in drugs' reflects the activities required to be prohibited under the Convention. Most of those activities are already subject to criminal sanction under existing State and Territory laws. In this Bill the expression `dealing in drugs' does not create offences.

Secondly, the Bill defines an offence called `a State drug offence'. This is conduct which is both a drug trafficking offence in the terms of the Convention and a serious offence under the law of a State or Territory punishable by at least 12 months imprisonment.

Use of the phrases `dealing in drugs' and `serious State drug offences' is merely a way of simplifying the reference to these activities in the later provisions of the Bill. Thirdly, the Bill creates the required offences of laundering money or other property that is known to have been derived from a `serious State drug offence'. These offences are described in much the same terms as those used in the Convention.

Finally, the Bill makes provision for Regulations to prescribe States and Territories to which the legislation will not apply. This means that the operation of the offence provisions in the Bill will be limited to those States and Territories which have not legislated to create offences of money laundering. Once these States and Territories have enacted conforming legislation, the Regulations will be amended so that the legislation does not apply to them.

It is intended that these Commonwealth offences will, in the event of a conviction, attract the confiscation provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 with respect to `tainted property'. This is intended to enable compliance with the confiscation requirements of the Convention in relation to those States and Territories which do not yet have confiscation of proceeds legislation.

In applying these new Commonwealth money laundering offences, it will not matter that the conduct which is the `dealing in drugs' offence, for example manufacturing drugs, occurred in one State or Territory, and the money laundering conduct, for example the transfer of property, occurred in another State or Territory. Also, it will be possible that confiscation of proceeds action might be taken against property in a third State or Territory. Even where the State or Territory law is adequate to meet the obligations imposed by the Convention if all of the relevant conduct had occurred there, it may not cover conduct that crosses State or Territory borders.
This Bill does not affect the validity of any State or Territory legislation creating money laundering offences or any confiscation of proceeds provisions, and does not limit their operation.
I do not anticipate that the proposals put forward in this Bill will have a significant impact on Government expenditure in the foreseeable future.
This Bill is the final legislative stage in the process of ratifying this Convention.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: REGISTRATION AND DECLARATION OF SENATORS' INTERESTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend the notice of motion relating to the registration and declaration of senators' interests standing in my name.
—Is leave granted? I imagine that the amendment has been circulated or is in a circulable form.
—I haven't seen it.
—It has been, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Could you outline it.

—Paragraph 1(1)(a) of the motion says that senators shall register their interests within 28 days essentially of their being sworn in as senators. That does not make sense in the current context. I have added these words, of which I am sure Senator Hill has a copy. They have been circulated, but I will pass a copy to him.
—Senator Button, the form of those words is not before the Chair.
—Perhaps I can read it. There should be a new clause (5) added which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding the provisions of clause 1(1),

Upon the adoption of this resolution by the Senate each senator shall provide within fourteen sitting days a statement to the Registrar of Senators' Interests in accordance with the provisions of the resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order as to whether this does amount to an amendment. It seems to me that it makes it a substantially different motion. In fact, when we were having some discussions on this matter this morning, we not surprisingly interpreted the Government's intention that this matter should commence after the commencement of the next Parliament. Those are the terms of the motion that it put down last week. It does not seem to me that this is therefore an amendment but rather provides a totally new regime to be implemented in effect forthwith. In those terms, the motion that was put to us last week apparently was quite misleading. So I put to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, whether you will accept this as a valid amendment.

—The matter before us is whether the Senate will give leave to the Minister to amend his motion as is set out in the Notice Paper. If the Leader of the Opposition or any other honourable senator is disposed to regard this as a matter that ought not be given leave, it is simply a matter of any one senator refusing to give leave for such an amendment. Presumably, as a result of leave not being granted, full attention could be given to the possible amendment by its being considered at another time.

—I do not want to refuse leave, Mr Acting Deputy President, but it does not seem to me to be transitional in any event, now that I come to look at it. It has all the signs of being tacked on the end in an inappropriate way. The Government is now seeking to provide this new procedure for registration of interest to commence within 14 days of today. But instead of being up-front and putting that in as the terms of the motion it wants debated, because it made the mistake and failed to do that the other day, the Government has tried to tack it on the end and call it transitional. It is not transitional at all; it is the substantive day within which this new regime is supposed to start operating. Therefore, its substance is totally misleading.

—Order! We are saved by the bell. The time for the suspension of the Senate is 6.30 p.m. It will be a matter for consideration when the Senate resumes. It being 6.31 p.m., the sitting of the Senate is suspended until 8 p.m.

—Before the suspension of the sitting, I sought leave to amend the motion to try to overcome a fairly technical point. Following discussions with Senator Hill in the chamber at that time, I have circulated a proposed new amendment to clause 1(1) of Government Business notice of motion No. 1 relating to the registration and declaration of senators' interests. The amendment adds, after the word `within' in clause 1(1), the following words, `fourteen sitting days after the adoption of this resolution by the Senate and'. I seek leave to move the amendment; it can always be moved later if leave is not granted.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate adopt the following resolution relating to the registration and declaration of Senators' interests, such resolution to continue in force unless amended or revoked by the Senate in this or a subsequent Parliament:

1.(1)That, within fourteen sitting days after the adoption of this resolution by the Senate and 28 days of making and subscribing an oath or affirmation of allegiance as a Senator, each Senator shall provide to the Registrar of Senators' Interests a statement of—
(a)the Senator's registrable interests; and
(b)the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware
(i)of the Senators' spouse; and
(ii)of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support,

in accordance with this resolution and in a form determined by the Committee of Senators' Interests from time to time, and shall also notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar within 28 days of that alteration occurring.
(2)Any Senator who—
(a)knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests by the due date;
(b)knowingly fails to notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests within 28 days of the change occurring; or
(c)knowingly provides false or misleading information to the Registrar of Senators' Interests,
shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly.

2.That the statement of a Senator's registrable interests to be provided by a Senator shall include the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware (a) of the Senator's spouse; and (b) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, and shall cover the following matters:
(d)shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies;
(e)family and business trusts and nominee companies-
(i)in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and beneficial interest, and

(ii)in which the Senator, the Senator's spouse, or a child who is wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, is a trustee (but not including a trustee of an estate where no beneficial interest is held by the Senator, the Senator's spouse or dependent children), indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust;
(f)real estate, including the location (suburb or area only) and the purpose for which it is owned;
(g)registered directorships of companies;
(h)partnerships, indicating the nature of the interests and the activities of the partnership;
(i)liabilities, indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned;
(j)the nature of any bonds, debentures and like investments;
(k)saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned;
(l)the nature of any other assets (excluding household and personal effects) each valued at over $5,000;
(m)the nature of any other substantial sources of income;

(n)gifts valued at more than $250 received from official sources, or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources, provided that a gift received by a Senator, the Senator's spouse or dependent children from family members or personal friends in a purely personal capacity need not be registered unless the Senator judges that an appearance of conflict of interest may be seen to exist;
(o)any sponsored travel or hospitality received;
(p)membership of any organisation; and
(q)any other interests where a conflict of interest with a Senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Register and Registrar of Senators' Interests

SPEECH.PARA: 3.That-

(r)at the commencement of each Parliament, and at other times as necessary, the President shall appoint an officer of the Department of the Senate as the Registrar of Senators' Interests and that officer shall also be Secretary of the Committee of Senators' Interests;

(s)the Registrar of Senators' Interests shall, in accordance with procedures determined by the Committee of Senators' Interests, maintain a Register of Senators' Interests in a form to be determined by that Committee from time to time;

(t)as soon as possible after the commencement of each Parliament, the Chairman of the Committee of Senators' Interests shall table in the Senate a copy of the completed Register of Senators' Interests and shall also table from time to time as required any notification by a Senator of alteration of those interests; and
(u)the Register of Senators' Interests shall be available for inspection by any person under conditions to be laid down by the Committee of Senators' Interests from time to time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Declaration of interest in debate and other proceedings

SPEECH.PARA: 4.That, notwithstanding the lodgment by a Senator of a statement of the Senator's registrable interests and the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware (a) of the Senator's spouse; and (b) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, and the incorporation of that statement in a Register of Senators' Interests, a Senator shall declare any relevant interest—
(v)at the beginning of his or her speech if the Senator participates in debate in the Senate, committee of the whole Senate, or a committee of the Senate or of the Senate and the House, and

(w)as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the Senate, committee of the whole Senate, or a committee of the Senate or of the Senate and the House if the Senator proposes to vote in that division, and
the declaration shall be recorded and indexed in the Journals of the Senate or minutes of proceedings of the committee and in any Hansard report of those proceedings or that division,
but it shall not be necessary for a Senator to declare an interest when directing a question seeking information in accordance with standing order 72 or 74.

I wish to briefly refer to what this motion does. In all the debates we have had here over a number of years about this issue, there has always been confusion about the motion proposed to the Senate. If one looks at the terminology of the motion, essentially it requires that there be a register relating to senators' interests and that within a prescribed period, which is now an amended period in the motion now before the Senate, after the senator is required to make an oath or affirmation or after the passing of adoption of this motion:
. . . each Senator shall provide to the Registrar of Senators' Interests a statement of—
(a) the Senator's registrable interests; and
(b) the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware—

relating to family and so on. A penalty is imposed for a senator failing to provide such a statement. He or she would be regarded as being guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and would be dealt with by the Senate accordingly.

PARA.TAB: This matter received some attention in a different context last week, and indeed today, when Senator Richardson was asked about his directorship of a radio station in Sydney where he became a member of the board of that station by virtue of his holding certain offices in the Labor Party, and he remained a director after he had left those offices, as I understand it.

The question as it concerned Senator Richardson essentially was whether he had, pursuant to Cabinet rules on this matter, declared his directorship of that radio station in a return which is provided to the Prime Minister. Senator Richardson's answer to that question was `no', that he had misunderstood or misinterpreted the rules and thought that he was required to do that only in circumstances in which he had what can fairly be described as a pecuniary interest; that is to say, that he stood to gain personal benefit from the directorship. In Senator Richardson's case, he apparently misinterpreted the Cabinet rules. He apologised—

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!
—I have to deal with me next.
—Have you misled us too?
—Absolutely. It was long before Senator Macdonald's time. Senator Richardson misinterpreted the Cabinet rules, he subsequently apologised to the Prime Minister and has rectified the position.
—Why shouldn't he suffer a serious contempt penalty?

—Precisely. Why should he not suffer a serious contempt penalty; and why should I not have? The answer to that question is that there is no provision in the Senate for a serious contempt penalty to be discovered because of the lassitude, indifference, obfuscation and neglect of Opposition senators who on numerous occasions previously have sought to oppose this motion which is now before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Let us take what we will call the `Richo case'. In terms of the Cabinet rule, I fully understand Senator Richardson's position. It is a position involving his believing that he had to make that declaration of holding a directorship in circumstances where there may be some question of his benefiting personally from it. He did not do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds a bit like Burke not knowing the guidelines when he was Ambassador.
—It is all very well for those opposite to talk about this. They have consistently opposed this all the way along.
—We have never had a vote on it.
—Those opposite have made it quite clear what their vote will be. Their opportunity is here now; they can have a vote on it now. That is the situation in the Richardson case.

PARA.TAB: In the John Button case, which occurred in the early days of this declaration of interest issue, what I did, being in a similar position in Victoria to Senator Richardson, was that I declared my directorship of a company called Industrial Printing & Publicity Company in Melbourne. Some people on the opposite side saw that public declaration by me of a directorship and raised a number of questions about whether I could have any conflict of interest arising from that declaration. As I result of that, I resigned the directorship.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it in liquidation since you have gone?

—I do not know. That was the problem: I did not know at the time. Because I was a non-attending director, I certainly had no remuneration or any possibility of remuneration from that directorship. It was a formal trust deed relationship on behalf of the Labor Party. I was picked up because my declaration was public, and that is the way it ought to be.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make about the registration and declaration of senators' interests is that if those opposite feel strongly about this—and I am sure they do from the interjections that are being made—they should agree that anybody who provides false or misleading information to the Registrar of Senators' Interests shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly. That is the point. If those opposite are hot to trot on this issue, they as senators have the chance not just to ask Senator Richardson, for example, about his return to the Cabinet, but also about his return to the Senate, and deal with him or deal with me, as the case may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —We expect the Prime Minister to deal with it.

—Those opposite cannot hold out all sorts of expectations because they have not been too good on this issue themselves. I want to come to that in a minute. What I am seeking to do, using illustrations along the way for the benefit of Opposition senators, is to explain what this motion actually does. Firstly, it provides for a declaration of senators' interests, which I would have thought nobody should have any objection to. Secondly, it provides a definition of what are registrable interests.
—I have an objection to telling you what my wife has not got.
—That is a different issue from the question of principle. That is a question of detail.
—Is that in the detail?

—It is included, but let me come to that point in a moment. Thirdly, it provides for the Register and the Registrar of Senators' Interests and who that will be. Finally, clause 4 provides for declaration of interest in debate and other proceedings. I must say that in my long time in the Senate, I think I am the only senator who has made a declaration of interest in a debate in these proceedings, except when I was Opposition spokesman on broadcasting.
—Senator Panizza does so all the time.
—I apologise.
—I even said so last week.
—I really do apologise. I want to pick up Senator Panizza on a couple of things he said in another debate. I hope he does not let me forget that. I apologise in respect of that.
—Senator Watson, too.

—If Senator Watson has done that too, I also apologise. That makes three senators who have made a declaration of interest in the context of a debate. The fourth and final point of the motion requires that senators make a declaration in the context of a debate.

PARA.TAB: All along, this issue has been confused with other issues as to what constitutes a pecuniary interest and what constitutes a conflict of interest. All these issues are supplementary to this essential question of providing a register, a method of senators registering their interests, a penalty for failure to register their interests, and a method for senators to provide declarations.

When we debated this issue at earlier times it was always gone through by the Opposition in moments frequently of heat. I hate to suggest to the Opposition that it would be guilty of heat, but it was a more heated debate on the issue and it was very confused. People started to raise all these other questions which are unrelated to the question of a register of interests such as they have in the House of Commons, in the United States, various countries in Europe and in the House of Representatives here in Australia where there is a register of interests which does not seem to cause—in the silence of the night it might cause some members some angst—any public concern because it is all there on the record. The public can have access to that, but Senator Panizza should not pretend for a moment that honourable members or senators are required to declare amounts of money or anything like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of the debates, as to whether they should.
—I am not taking it that far. This does not require that. If the Opposition wants to amend this to include the amounts, I will give it leave to do so.
—If you were a share trader, you would change it every fortnight.
—Change what?
—Your return, if you were a share trader.
—No. I am not sure that one is required to do that. One is required to bring it up to date.
—Within 14 days. If you were are a share trader, you would be doing it all the time.
—If a senator has time to be a share trader, he or she ought to have time to bring his or her declaration up to date.
—You would need a full time registrar, wouldn't you?
—Senator Panizza or Senator Macdonald might.
—The Parliament will.
—No. The Clerks and officers of the Senate are very competent people. They could handle that; they could pursue all the relevant issues.
—What about cattle and sheep? Each time you traded your shares in them, would you have to declare that?

—No. One would just declare that one had sheep. There are already signs that this issue might be clouded by extraneous questions when the only real question is whether we should have a register as does the House of Representatives and other organisations throughout the world.
—It is an absolute farce if you ever take the trouble to have a look at it.

—It exists in other chambers in other places. The point is that it ought to exist here. We can always improve on it in the Senate and look at questions. I find some minor issues of detail in this a bit difficult to handle. As a Senate, we can always look at those. Historically, we have had a different regime from the House of Representatives, which has a register of interests; we have none at all. There is no reason why subsequently the Standing Committee on Procedure, which deals with the Standing Orders, could not deal with some of the difficulties which members might encounter in being members of clubs or something like that. The Senate could have a slightly different system from the House of Representatives. But that does not alter the fundamental question of principle. I want to go quickly through the history of this matter.
—Get it more accurate than Mr Keating did in his press release.
—I have not seen the press release. But in 1983 this matter was first raised—
—It has been defeated three times in the Senate.

—In some ways he is right about that, but I will tell Senator Hill why in a minute. In 1984, the House adopted a resolution requiring registration of interests. In 1986, we had a debate about it in the Senate. In 1986, the House adopted an amended resolution. In March 1987, Senator Gareth Evans moved an identical motion for the Senate. That 1987 debate was adjourned essentially and fell foul of an election timetable and has not been pursued since. Although there was quite a lengthy period of debate at that time, that motion was referred to a committee. The motion lapsed with the July 1987 election.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, in November 1987, this matter was again raised and, in negotiations with Senator Chaney, the then Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, I agreed that the debate should be further adjourned because of the pressing nature of government business and the difficulties for the business list. In 1989, Senator Macklin, the then Democrat Senator, wrote to the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, proposing a joint select committee on the ethical behaviour of MPs, which was a much wider thing. We did not support that at the time and I understand the Opposition did not either.

If I might summarise the views—I do not wish to speak at length in this matter—the matter has had a long history. It has come up again in the context of allegations relating to my colleague Senator Richardson.
