The fact of the matter is that if the Senate was concerned about this issue it would see that it, the Senate, as distinct to leaving it to Cabinet rules or anything of that kind, ensured that there was a register of senators' interests and it, the Senate, could deal with any question of penalty for a member of the Senate failing to comply with the rules associated with that register.

That is the situation which the Senate ought to want. If it does want that and there are matters of detail relating to the interests of spouses or membership of organisations and so on which the Senate wanted to deal with, they are appropriate matters which could be dealt with by the Senate, I should have thought, through the committee dealing with the Standing Orders.

The issue at the present time is one of principle: whether we introduce a system as obtains in the House of Representatives, which was formulated following the Riordan Report of the Joint Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament in 1975 and the subsequent report of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest appointed by the Fraser Government—all those years when nothing was done about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bowen report opposed it.
—No, it did not. It had a different formula from that devised by Riordan.
—As I read it last night, it opposed it anyway.
—I do not know what shape Senator Hill was in last night—
—I will read it to you.
—I am sure Senator Hill will.
—Have you read page 15?

—No. I have the report here. I cannot say I have singled out page 15. Anyway, nothing was done about that and this Government is of the view that something ought to be done, and this motion is moved at this time accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One wonders why this matter is being debated now: either the Government is short of business—we are told that that is certainly not the case; we understand that there is an enormous backlog of legislation that has not yet been put through this chamber—or it relates to the events of last week. That concerned the embarrassment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last week in his failure to take action against Minister Richardson in his default of the standards that the Government had publicly stated it would accept and would demand of itself and its Ministers.

PARA.TAB: That is what this is all about. This issue was last in the Senate just in excess of five years ago. In that period of five years the Government has not chosen to progress it on any one day, not even on one day. It has had no interest in the matter whatsoever. The Government's interest was only rekindled last week through its embarrassment over what the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) referred to tonight as the `Richo affair'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Richo case.

—The `Richo case'. So they should be embarrassed by that. What did that mean? It was a blatant breach of the standard which the Government had set for its Ministers in 1983. When the Government announced what it was doing in 1983, it boasted of this new standard of behaviour that it was going to demand of Ministers in a Labor Government. I remind Senator Button of his presentation to the Senate on 22 September 1983, when he talked about this decision of the Government to require of its Ministers not only disclosure but also a statement of interests. He said the proposals:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . which I have presented to the Senate represent a landmark in the development of this Parliament . . .
He went on to say:

The public—the electors of this country—are entitled to have confidence in the integrity of their elected representatives, to know that Ministers of the Government will perform their duties without fear or favour, to be reassured that a Minister's private interests—whatever they may be—do not conflict with his or her public duties in holding the high office of a Minister in the Federal Government.

That is the boast of the new standard that would be achieved through this mechanism, this regime, of disclosure and a statement of interests. When the Prime Minister was put to the test last week, what action did he take? Nothing at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —He apologised.

—Senator Richardson apologised. The Prime Minister said, `I accept the apology; the matter is at an end—except for the fact that we now want to test the bona fides of the Senate, so we will send the matter back and see where the Senate stands on it'. Even Senator Button would have to admit that that reaches a new level of hypocrisy. The Prime Minister totally disregards the standards that he set down publicly for his Minister when it is politically expedient to do so whilst at the same time saying that he expects the Senate to adopt those standards and comply with them. If there is a better word than `hypocrisy' for that, I cannot think of it immediately. Senator Button went on in that speech in September 1983 to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Ministers are required to resign any directorships in public companies and directorships of private companies unless, for example, such companies operate a family farm, business or investments and the retention of the directorship is not likely to conflict with the public duty of the Minister.

That relates particularly to the issue concerning Senator Richardson. When he took on this directorship of the relevant radio station, according to the standard and the guidelines that have been made public by his Government and his Prime Minister, he was not entitled to take on that directorship. He may argue that he should not have had to make a disclosure because he should not have taken on the directorship in the first place. But that was just totally disregarded because it suited his purposes for the moment.

PARA.TAB: It may not be a question of some financial or pecuniary conflict. This is related to registrable interests, not just pecuniary interests. The statement and the standards that the Prime Minister said he stands by require that Ministers disclose other registrable interests so that the public can see that they are not, in dealing with legislation and Cabinet matters, putting themselves in any potential position of conflict.

What did we find from Senator Richardson last week? We found that on many occasions apparently matters pertaining to broadcasting legislation—and they may, incidentally or directly, have affected the radio station of which he was a director—were dealt with by this Government. At Question Time my colleague Senator Baume read out a whole series of Bills and other matters that could pertain to this radio station. Did Senator Richardson disclose an interest in those matters? On no occasion did he disclose an interest. Furthermore, he said that his notes did not indicate whether he was even present at the debates. He could not find any evidence of a disclosure of interest from Cabinet records either.

I remind Senator Button—he accepted this himself—that we are talking about two separate situations. One is the obligation to disclose an interest where there could be a potential conflict. We all accept that. It is not in the Senate Standing Orders, as I understand it, other than in a committee situation. That differs from the House of Representatives. Nevertheless, in our parliamentary business—we abide by the same standards in the shadow Ministry—we accept that if someone has a potential conflict of interest, they disclose that. Yet Senator Richardson knew that he was a director of this radio station and knew he was in a potential situation of a conflict of interest, and yet on no occasion did he disclose that interest. That was his first offence. He is guilty of that on his own admission. I forget his explanation for that; I do not think he gave an explanation. Anyway, that has been disregarded by the Prime Minister as well.

The second standard is this register of interests which in some way will enable not only the Government and the Prime Minister but also the public to make some form of assessment as to whether in this instance a Minister was in a potential position of conflict of interest. As I said, Senator Richardson defaulted on that because he failed to put his directorship of the radio station in his statement of interests. That position continued for about two years. Certainly he said that after he became Minister for Communications some little time afterwards he resigned by sending a letter to the Secretary of his political party, which is a rather quaint way of resigning from a directorship. Anyway, he did it, in that event. But that is not the point. The point is that for the previous two years he was a Minister of the Crown and a Cabinet Minister. He continually dealt with matters that could have provided a potential conflict of interest. On no occasion did he disclose to the public in his registration statement that he had that interest. That is his second offence. Again, he is guilty on his own admission.

Senator Richardson's only plea on penalty was that he did not appreciate the consequences of what he was doing because it was not a pecuniary interest. That is despite the fact that the document itself, which he signed, makes his obligations absolutely clear. Paragraph 4, headed `Directorships', of the guidelines specifically makes that clear. The explanatory notes to assist Ministers who apparently have trouble filling in their form were revised in June 1991. Paragraph 4 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers are reminded that they are required to resign directorships in public companies and may retain directorships in private companies only if any such company operates (e.g.) a family farm, business or investments, and if retention of the directorship is not likely to conflict with the Ministers' public duty (e.g. a Minister should question the retention of a directorship in a company in which shareholdings extend beyond the Minister's own family).

Not only did Senator Button boast about this new standard in 1983 and bring to the attention of Ministers such as Senator Richardson what their obligations are, but the document that Senator Richardson signed made his obligations absolutely clear. He chose not to include this directorship. We really do not know why he chose not to include it. Those closely associated with New South Wales Labor right-wing politics might have a better understanding than others.

PARA.TAB: The other day the Prime Minister said, `We all know'—`we' meaning the Cabinet Ministers—`that he was a director of that company'. One wonders whether that is the case, bearing in mind the way in which the Labor Party operates. It would be interesting to know whether all the left-wing Ministers knew that Senator Richardson was a director of this company, which I understand is owned by the Labor Party in New South Wales, at the time an which he was debating legislation that affected the interests of that particular radio station.

On both counts the Minister was guilty. The Prime Minister chose to take no action at all. He demonstrated his real attitude to this set of standards—that is, that we disregard them according to political expediency. That is the action he chose to take—to disregard it in this instance whilst at the same time saying, `It's about time the Senate faced up to this issue again'.
In such circumstances, it seems to me that I should move an amendment to the motion that we are debating tonight—and Senator Richardson might appreciate this for posterity. I move:
That a new paragraph be added as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. That the Senate condemns

(a) the Minister for Transport and Communications for failing to disclose a registrable interest, namely that he was a director of commercial radio station 2HD, in breach of the Ministerial Statements of Interest as adopted by the Government: and

(b) the Prime Minister Mr Keating for his failure to discipline Senator Richardson for his breach and his hypocrisy in demanding standards of Senators which he has demonstrated he will disregard according to political expedience.
I will continue to deal with the speech that Senator Button gave in September 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is fantastic stuff.
—These are the standards that Senator Button was setting for his Ministers, but when it serves his purposes he disregards them. That is the position. In 1983 Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers have to make a declaration at meetings of the Cabinet or its committees of any matter which may give rise to a conflict of interests.
Senator Richardson did not do so. Later in the same speech, boasting of the new integrity of his Cabinet, Senator Button continued:

I remarked earlier on the right of the public to have confidence in the integrity of its elected representatives. While that confidence demands particularly high standards of Ministers it also demands certain standards of each and every member of the Senate and each and every member of the House of Representatives.
`Particularly high standards of Ministers', but when it came to the test—as it did in this instance—the Prime Minister disregarded that.

PARA.TAB: It is true that this matter has come before the Senate on a few occasions since 1983. In 1983 it was debated very briefly. Senator Button spoke about it; Senator Chaney spoke about it. Senator Chaney did not oppose the resolution but raised a number of serious deficiencies in the drafting and said that they should be further considered by the Standing Committee on Procedure which deals with the Standing Orders of this Senate. Senator Chipp agreed with that. He looked in some detail at the deficiencies that he recognised in the draft. The matter was then referred to the Procedure Committee. It was not dealt with again until 1986 when that Committee, in effect, said that the matter was too difficult and that it could not provide any assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the John Button case.

—There was the John Button case that Senator Button has acknowledged tonight, but there were a number of other serious cases. Two of those related to the now Minister Dawkins: one where he failed to acknowledge a bottom-of-the-harbour interest that could have beneficially affected him; and the other when he was put in charge of a government committee looking at the take-over of BHP, and he failed to disclose a very substantial beneficial interest in the Bell group of companies—an amazing default. As I recall, the then Prime Minister took no action in that regard either. I guess Senator Richardson is not an orphan in this matter. There have been a number of cases where Ministers have failed to reach the standard that the Prime Minister has set for them, but in no case has any action been taken against them.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the matter came back to the Senate in 1986. Two speeches were made in relation to it in 1987. Senator Gareth Evans reintroduced the matter during his short period as Manager of Government Business in the Senate—a period which we all remember but would prefer to forget. Senator Durack responded to it in an interesting speech in which he detailed all the defaults by the Government on its own set of standards. Thereafter, the matter has not been dealt with. Since 1987 the Government has taken no action in pursuit of this matter.

When the Prime Minister wanted to create a distraction from his embarrassment last week by saying, `I am going to refer this matter back to Senate and test their bona fides', he did not tell the truth. He said in that press statement that the Senate had defeated this proposal on three separate occasions—1983, 1986 and 1987—but if one looks through the debates one will find that, in fact, the Senate has on no occasion defeated the proposal.

I come now to the issue of merit, having dealt with the politics of the matter—and for the Government, those are the politics of expediency. We have said before in this place that there are difficult issues to be debated on the merit side of the argument. We have no problem with the question of conflict of interest; that is quite clear. If one has a potential conflict of interest, we accept the obligation to disclose it. We will always do so and suffer the consequences of not doing so, which is more than the Prime Minister will administer.

We have always said that there are difficulties with the statement of registrable interests, and those difficulties remain. One of them was touched upon by interjection, and that is that this statement treats the owner of one BHP share in exactly the same way as the owner of 1,000 BHP shares. Which one is more likely to be influenced in a matter of potential conflict? The public cannot gauge in any way from this statement which one has a greater interest in the matter. This is an issue that has been addressed but has not yet been resolved.

Another question that was raised in the debates that took place in the 1980s was that of debt. For example, if a Minister is very substantially in debt—let us say, hypothetically, to a Mr Connell or one of his Western Australian associates—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the Commonwealth Bank.

—The Commonwealth Bank, perhaps, but let us deal with some of the better known names in Western Australia. One might well say that there is a much greater chance of that person being influenced or levered in some way by his creditor than a shareholder would be, but the extent of that interest is not disclosed.

PARA.TAB: There is a whole range of difficult issues in relation to spouses. For example, we had the situation in South Australia where a spouse of a member of parliament refused to disclose to the member what interests he—in this case—had. What is the obligation? Under this draft there is an obligation on a senator to disclose, even though the spouse will not provide the information and if the senator does not—

TALK.START.PARA: —Only those things he or she is aware of.
—We will have another look at the draft, but if the—
—That is not what we are debating.
—Well, this draft has been changed so many times over the years. Then come questions about what it is reasonable for a spouse to be aware of, and in what sort of detail.

PARA.TAB: Another example that was raised in earlier debates is that of the interest of minors, who might not be a member's children but minors in whom a member of parliament takes some special interest in providing sustenance and support. They are not included. That raises the definition of `family' and `children' and in these days of rather varied family relationships it becomes much more complex. These matters are not dealt with.

If one looks at the draft, one finds that a committee of senators' interests is proposed. That committee has not yet been set up, so how is it going to carry on its work if it does not exist? To whom is this disclosure to be made if the office bearers have not been provided for in this draft? The House of Representatives introduced changes in the Standing Orders at the same time to provide for these things, so that the office bearers who would have the responsibility of dealing with the information to be provided would be in place to so deal with it. However, in its haste the other night to introduce this proposal for its political purposes, the Government failed to introduce changes to the Standing Orders.There has been no indication tonight from Senator Button as to how he proposes to deal with that.

The haste with which the matter has been brought on was demonstrated by the fact that when Senator Button put forward last week the motion that we are debating today, there was a provision that the new obligation would not start until a month after a new Parliament was sworn in. On reconsideration over the weekend he realised that that was not achieving his objectives so he had to bring in an amendment today to provide that it would start 14 days after the date of passage.

So all of the signs are there of undue haste. There is no real urgency in this matter, as has been demonstrated by the fact that the Government has done nothing on it for the last five years. It is not the sort of matter that should be dealt with with undue haste. It should be carefully considered.

Since the last time that this matter was debated in depth in our party room in 1983 there have been very substantial changes in the composition of this Senate. We on this side of the chamber believe that it is only reasonable that senators who have come into this place since 1983 have an opportunity to look at the detail of what the Government is putting up and how it might affect them. They also need to look at the obligations that they will have in relation to disclosing matters that concern their families and the like.

One of the subsequent Opposition speakers will seek that this debate be adjourned for seven sitting days in order that we can have time for a proper party meeting to debate these matters. I would suggest that that is only reasonable. I understand that the Australian Democrats accept that that is a reasonable approach.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you might note that we are not seeking to cause any undue delay in dealing with this matter. It is simply that it has not been possible to have a sensible party room meeting within the time frame that the Government has suddenly provided for us in this matter because it wants a way to get off the embarrassing political hook that it got itself on last week. So, in due course, we will seek that adjournment. We will deal with this matter responsibly and we will come back with a responsible position.

I can tell the Senate that on the question of conflict of interests we will, as we have always done in the past, be prepared to stand up and acknowledge the potential for conflict. We have been prepared to take ourselves out of such a debate rather than to put ourselves in a position of conflict because we accept the merits of that argument.

I deplore the way in which the Government has reintroduced this matter in an effort solely to get itself out of a politically embarrassing situation. I accept that it is an issue that is deserving of proper and sensible debate. It will receive that on this side of the chamber and we will return with a considered position in the not too distant future.

Senator Button should not laugh at the standard that he and his government have set. Last week we saw a classic breach of the standard that his Government has set by one of the most senior Cabinet Ministers in the Government. All that the Prime Minister is prepared to do is turn a blind eye. That does not demonstrate any form or set of standards that can give any confidence to the Australian people of his bona fides in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will accept the proposal to adjourn this matter for seven sitting days. I understand that that proposal has the support of the Australian Democrats. It does not seem appropriate that we should debate it at length now. We would be happy to give Senator Hill leave to move such a motion. It could be that somebody else may wish formally to move such a motion. We will accept such a motion. We could then have debate on the substance of the proposal when it comes back before the Senate in seven sitting days.

—My remarks will be fairly short and to the point. The proper behaviour or improper behaviour of Senator Richardson in terms of his directorship of radio station 2HD is a matter that is of concern to many of us. We are also concerned about the lack of evidence that is available as to whether he did in fact disclose his interest, and whether he was part of the discussions that related to the ad bans legislation—and I will deal with that in a little more detail.

PARA.TAB: We started out to discuss apples—we started out to discuss Senator Richardson's behaviour pursuant to the ministerial code. We ended up discussing—at least, until Senator Hill introduced his amendments—oranges. In other words, this is yet another attempt by this unelected Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to divert the agenda and to distract the attention of people from the single and main issue.

Frankly, it would seem that Senator Richardson signed the undertaking that he gave for disclosure and the like with the same sense of good faith, or lack of it, that he signed the letter of introduction for his mate, Mr Gregory Symons. With the same sense of good faith, he rang up the Governor of the Marshall Islands, ostensibly just as a simple senator and friend of Mr Symons. He used and abused his title as a Minister of state to try to gain influence with the Governor of the Marshall Islands.

Reference has been made in this place to an article in the Good Weekend magazine of the Fairfax press which outlines the machinations and duplicity of Senator Richardson with regard to his dealings with his own party. According to the illustration on the front of that magazine, while promoting the cause of the unelected Prime Minister, Mr Keating, he was busy stabbing in the neck the then Prime Minister, Prime Minister Hawke. He was pretending to be a friend and dealing with his difficulties while at the same time knifing him and terminating his period as Prime Minister.

This is a man whose word one could say at best has to be treated with caution. It would seem that his word with regard to the signing of documentation in this chamber is to be similarly treated. How is it that we can have one standard for the Labor Party and another standard for others? How is it, for instance, that the unelected Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was able to get away with not filing a tax return when he was Treasurer? This is something that ordinary Australians are prosecuted for. Yet, all he got was a little letter from the Commissioner saying, `Please pop it in. You are a little bit late'. How is it that we have one standard for some and another for others? Is the expectation that members of the Labor Party can behave in not as high a way as others in the parliamentary process? Is it expected that their behaviour should be less than adequate just because they are members of the Labor Party? What an appalling situation it would be if that were the case.

We are discussing the fact that there is a ministerial code. Ministers are the people who form the government. Under our Constitution, they are the executive; they formulate policy. The rest of the members of the Labor Party simply make up the numbers. The Opposition is Her Majesty's loyal Opposition. We are here to uphold the Australian standard and to put the opposing point of view to keep checks and balances in the system.

Here we have a prominent and powerful member of the Government, of the Executive, who simply did not bother to disclose his directorship of 2KY—I beg your pardon, 2HD; they go hand in hand as they are both owned and controlled by the Labor Party. We have a situation where the Labor Party is in control of two stations that use the airwaves. Under the ad bans legislation we exempt editorial and so-called newsworthy comment but those stations cannot take paid advertisements from people who want to put an opposing point of view.

The Minister, the member of the Executive that makes and determines the policy, is a director of radio station 2HD. Yet the Minister did not bother to resign as he is supposed to be required to do by his own standard of ethics? So, instead of debating in this place tonight, as we should, whether Senator Richardson should be resigning, a quaint little motion is introduced on the suggestion of the unelected Prime Minister that we should be looking somehow at the Senate as a whole—that is, the people who do not make up the executive government. What a joke!

The main game in this debate is the behaviour of Ministers in the executive Government; the behaviour of this powerful man in the executive Government who managed to knife the previous Prime Minister to elevate his first best mate, the unelected Prime Minister. We are talking about the man who is powerful and who controls. We are talking about the man who has had so much to do with the ad bans legislation—the banning of freedom of speech. We are talking about the man who was the director of a radio station that can put editorial comment to air that favours the Labor Party side of politics.

As I listened to the so-called editorial that went to air in the lead-up to the Davidson by-election, I thought it was ludicrous that so much time was given to the side favoured by the Labor Party—to the so-called Independent who had been an endorsed Labor Party candidate twice previously in elections in that electorate and was trying to pretend that she was an independent. She is also the sister of a sitting Labor Party member.

So let us talk about the ad ban legislation and the banning of freedom of speech, a policy enunciated and deliberated upon by a man who had the power to see that editorials could go to air prior to an election but did not bother to stick to the disclosure requirements of the government of the day. And how about the explanation? He just forgot about it! This man of power, this man who had details of numbers, of who was voting for whom, of who had changed their minds. This man just forgot about it. He just forgot to tell the Prime Minister of the day and then he went overseas. When there was a change of government he got the portfolio he wanted. I have it on good authority that former Prime Minister Hawke said that he would still be Prime Minister today if he had given Senator Richardson the portfolio he enjoys now because that is what he wanted most. That is what the previous Prime Minister had to say.

We are debating whether this Executive Government, this Ministerial rank, has the will to impose its own standards upon itself; has the will to say that this man, Senator Richardson, broke that standard and should resign. But oh, no! Members of the Government have not got the courage to stand up and do that to a mate because that was the mate who put the dagger into the throat of Mr Hawke—all in the name of mateship.

Here we go with mateship in the extreme. Now we have Senator Richardson, who has not resigned as the standard of ethics required, being apologised for by this unelected Prime Minister, Mr Keating, who wants to set Australian against Australian over the symbols of nationhood; the man who does not know that he is Australian; the man who has to go on bended knee and apologise to a foreign nation for being Australian and for his own heritage. What a disgrace!

This is the same man who has not got the courage to say to Senator Richardson anything like, `You are admonished. You did wrong'. Oh no! Instead he says, `I accept your apology: this very powerful man just forgot'. Forgot to tell his colleagues, as he was required to do by law, that he was in fact a director of a company which came within the guidelines of those things that were necessary to disclose. In the context of the ad ban legislation, that cannot be excused.

So we set off to discuss apples. What do we get but the Leader of the Government, Senator Button—whose services I might say Senator Richardson wanted to dispense with. However, the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was heard to say, `If you think Senator Walsh is a problem when he is not on the front bench, just think what John Button would do to us'.

Let us consider what occurred. Here is Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in this place who cannot even sit here to discuss oranges when he is meant to be discussing apples. He cannot even sit in here to hear this debate because he is probably too embarrassed. Senator Button cannot turn his back on Senator Richardson, who sits behind him, because he might get the dagger in the back. Here was the man who was so powerful that he could control the numbers just forgetting to tell anybody about this important position he had.

Senator Hill has moved that this motion be adjourned for seven days so that it can be considered in all its ramifications. But the amendments are important because this Government cries that it wants standards and then denigrates its own standards. The article in the weekend press read, `Why should we be surprised?' Why should we, indeed, be surprised? The Government pretends it has standards, but we all know better. The sooner the election comes, and this unelected Prime Minister sees the wrath of the Australian public, the better. This is just one way in which the Government treats the Australian public. It speaks of standards and then treats the people with hypocrisy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not have spoken on this matter tonight if the Opposition had accepted Senator McMullan's invitation to debate this motion in a week's time because we do support the Opposition's procedural motion that the matter be held over for seven days to give everybody an opportunity to look at the motion in detail. The motion—to remind those who are listening on the radio because they may well have forgotten what it was about while listening to Senator Bishop—deals with the registration and declaration of senators' interests and it is titled a proposed resolution.

PARA.TAB: We would certainly agree with Senator Hill that the motion, as it is worded, shows all the signs of being very hastily put together. For that reason alone, it certainly warrants fairly careful consideration. It is not hard to find why this motion might have been hastily put together: because of the Government's embarrassment over Senator Richardson. Because of that very hasty composition of the motion before us, I think it certainly warrants a delay of seven days to look at the matter in considerable detail.

The reason I have chosen to speak tonight is to put before other senators precisely those matters in the motion as it is worded which are of concern to us. Let me state right at the beginning that the Democrats are fully supportive of the principal thrust of this motion. We fully support the notion that senators should declare their interests in a wide range of areas so as to either avoid conflict of interest or, where conflict of interest might arise, to make it quite clear to their fellow senators, and also of course to the public, where exactly they are coming from in terms of any vested interest.

I will briefly deal with eight areas that we have identified where the Government needs to look rather more closely at the wording. First of all, in clause 1 (1) the motion talks about notification within 28 days of making or subscribing an oath or affirmation of allegiance. It is interesting that, just tonight, the Government has itself put down a suggested amendment to that very first clause. That itself is a corroboration of my claim that the Government had clearly put this motion together in great haste. As it was worded, it would have meant that present senators would not have been required to make any declaration whatsoever. The declarations would have come into effect only after the next election. So that is something that the Government has already picked up.

In relation to clause 1(1)(b)—Senator Hill has already picked up on this to some extent. It is interesting to note that the spouse's interests of which the senator is aware means, contrary to some of the earlier proposals—the 1983, 1984 and 1987 proposals—that the spouse is not required to make a declaration. However, it does mean that the whole matter turns on whether a senator was aware of those interests held by his or her spouse. Any charge in relation to a conflict of interest will turn on that very difficult word `aware'—how one establishes whether a senator was aware of a spouse's interests. I guess it is easy to establish that a person was aware if there is some corroborative correspondence which is over the signature of the senator. However, to establish that the senator was not aware is a much more difficult task.

Clause 1(2)(c) states that the failure to provide a statement, to falsify a statement or to make a false or misleading statement shall make the Senator `guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate'. Exactly what is a `serious contempt of the Senate'? I take it that it is indeed a very, very serious charge. Rather than simply leave it as in the motion with the succeeding words `and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly', it seems appropriate that the Senate should set some more specific penalties in relation to a serious contempt of the Senate. Does it mean a fine of $100, or $1,000? Does it mean suspension from the Senate for a month, or gaol for six months? What exactly is meant by `serious contempt of the Senate'? Clearly, in the context of other contempts of the Senate, a serious contempt of the Senate is serious indeed, and the mind is left wondering exactly what sorts of penalties would fit such a heinous crime.

Clause 2 details those particular areas which require revelation and subclause (xi) speaks specifically of gifts valued at more than $250 received from `official sources, or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources'. I do not know whether other honourable senators are confused about this, but I am certainly confused as to exactly what `official sources' actually means in relation to gifts. I am not sure that I have ever received a gift from an official source. I would like to know just what an `official source' is and perhaps the Government could give some consideration to that.

Under clause 2(xii) we are also required to reveal any sponsored travel or hospitality. Clearly, that is far too broad. I would frequently receive a cup of tea from somebody, which would be hospitality under this clause. Do I have to come into the Senate and say that Joe Bloggs has given me a cup of tea or has given me a lift somewhere in his car, which would go to the matter of travel? Clearly, some qualification of this is required so that we know exactly how much sponsored travel and hospitality amounts to a sufficient amount to require it to be revealed within the statement or when we get to a particular vote.

Clause 2(xiii) speaks about revealing membership of any organisation. Again, this is an incredibly broad clause. I think most senators would be members of large numbers of organisations. Most of those memberships would be fairly peripheral and a number of them are associated with being a senator in this place. They would not be particularly close memberships; nor would they be ones which involved a great deal of support either for from the organisation. One wonders whether perhaps that clause could be tightened so that it is closer associations with particular organisations that need to be revealed.

Subclause 3(c) talks about the tabling of declarations in the Senate. Quite clearly, the tabling of the declaration in the Senate makes this document—which includes all interests of all senators—a public document. Why then should the motion go on to talk about making the document available to any person? It seems to me that anybody who gets hold of the Hansard would be able to get hold of the documentation. It is quite superfluous to then require that it be made available to any person.
Finally, the eighth point that we would draw the Government's attention to concerns clauses 4(a) and 4(b). Clause 4(a) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)at the beginning of his or her speech if the Senator participates in debate in the Senate, committee of the whole Senate, or a committee of the Senate or of the Senate and the House. . . the declaration shall be recorded. . .

That is quite reasonable, because a person who is indulging in a debate presumably knows what the matter being debated before the Senate is and can quite readily and summarily make a declaration. However, clause 4(b) goes on to state:

(b)as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the Senate, committee of the whole Senate, or a committee of the Senate or of the Senate and the House if the Senator proposes to vote in that division, and the declaration shall be recorded. . .

It seems to me that this is really quite impracticable. Can one imagine for a moment a division being called on some obscure amendment, as is often the case, senators trooping into the chamber, most of them—particularly those on the back bench—having not the least idea what the matter is before the Senate or what particular interests they may have which may conflict with the vote that they are about to take, and yet their being required to get up, presumably one by one, and declare their particular interests? I imagine that a division on a vote on a matter where a lot of senators had a potential conflict of interest—such as one involving shares in large companies, which was the example mentioned earlier by Senator Hill—rather than taking some 10 minutes, could take half an hour as senator after senator got up and detailed all those interests which had to be revealed before the vote could be taken. While in principle that seems an eminently sane and sensible thing to do, in practice it is quite impractical.

PARA.TAB: That is a number of matters at the edge of this debate which the Democrats have identified. We have not yet had a chance to debate them in our party room at considerable length. There may be other matters that we would like to raise later. But I wanted to put on the record those matters at least, so that the Government and other honourable senators could address those issues and come up with workable solutions. In principle, we support this motion. We believe that interests should be declared. We support Senator Hill's suggestion concerning a procedural motion to have the matter held over for seven days so that those matters at the fringe can be given a great deal more consideration. We hope that we will then be able to come forward with a motion which meets all the necessary requirements in terms of principle, but does not leave these ragged edges which will either produce problems later on or will prove to make the working of the resolution quite impracticable.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Senator Macdonald, before you proceed, Senator Hill suggested he was moving an adjournment to the motion, but nobody has actually moved it. Do you wish to move to adjourn debate on the motion when you finish? A couple of speakers have referred to a motion which has not actually been moved?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, at the conclusion of my speech, there are to be two other speakers from the Opposition side. I had occasion earlier today to talk about the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party, which controls the present Government, in relation to the matter of the national flag—a party which denigrates and trivialises the flag but still, in what I can only claim is a fit of hypocrisy, displays it prominently on that Party's logo. Here we are again tonight talking about further hypocrisy of the Labor Party and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in relation to the matter of disclosure of interests.

PARA.TAB: The question, of course, has come before us tonight because the Prime Minister had a fit of pique at one of his mates being questioned about his failure to disclose; about his business dealings; and about some representations he made to a foreign government, a head of state, on behalf of another mate apparently. Because the Opposition chose to have the temerity to question a Minister of the Crown about that particular matter, the Prime Minister came back and demanded that the Senate pass some sort of motion as to disclosure of interests. In the midst of all that hypocrisy, it really makes one wonder why we bother with these interest declarations. This Prime Minister and this Government just do not want to enforce the rules when they are laid down. Why bother to do this if the Prime Minister and the members of the Labor Party ignore completely the rules and regulations made as to disclosure of interests?

For this reason, I support the amendment Senator Hill will be moving later to condemn the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) for his failure to disclose; to condemn the Prime Minister for his failure to discipline Senator Richardson for his breach of duty and his hypocrisy in demanding standards of senators, which he has demonstrated he will disregard according to political expediency. I think it needs to be emphasised again tonight that there is this wilful hypocrisy, this wilful disregard, by the Prime Minister whenever it suits his political purpose.

I enjoyed Senator Button's quite interesting and entertaining little speech earlier today. I suggest to Senator Button that when Senator Richardson finally gets that knife into him Senator Button would do very well either in the theatre or possibly back at the Bar, because it was a cute little speech and demonstrated how he can twist and turn the words. Senator Button, as I understand it, said that Senator Richardson—or `Richo', as he called him—was not at fault because there is no penalty provided for in the rules requiring disclosure by Ministers. No penalty provided for! What about the Prime Minister exercising some honesty and discipline over his Ministers? Is that not a penalty? Should the Prime Minister not do what Liberal Prime Ministers have done on many occasions in recent history, and that is call for the resignation of Ministers that those Liberal Prime Ministers have believed have transcended proper rules and behaviour in this particular chamber? Could the Prime Minister not have done that? It did not have to be written in the regulations; it did not have to be spelt out. We expect that our nation's leading figure, the Prime Minister, will discipline his Ministers and will make sure that they behave with propriety and honesty.

Strangely, I agree with some of the comments Senator Coulter made in pointing out that this particular motion is very laxly drawn; it has holes in it a mile wide. One would not need to be a very clever lawyer to find the loopholes in it—and I want to mention some of those. I also draw the attention of honourable senators to the matters that Senator Hill raised and also to the matters which Senator Bishop very clearly and concisely put before this Senate on this particular issue. I noticed that Senator Faulkner was most vocal in his objections and interjections to Senator Bishop. He, of course, has the opportunity to speak. I doubt whether he will; he very seldom does. One can always tell when Senator Bishop is getting close to the truth, when the points are really starting to hit their mark. That is when we hear Senator Faulkner start with his mindless interjections and that is when we know Senator Bishop is on the right track. I congratulate her for getting to that point so soon.

This motion, as Senator Coulter has pointed out, is very loosely drawn and talks about `the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware' having to be declared. Of course, how anyone proves that an honourable senator is aware, except in the most obvious cases, is very much a matter of conjecture. The motion really means that these rules will not have any teeth at all. These rules will not in any way be able to be properly administered.

I heard with some horror Senator Coulter suggesting that there should be more particular details of the penalty to be imposed if a serious contempt is found. I am appalled at the thought of having my life, liberty or even a monetary penalty judged by the likes of Senator Coulter and others in the Australian Democrats.

I recall with some sadness the occasion when my colleague Senator Kemp was dismissed from the House for a very short period, and I recall also that that action was implemented on the motion of Senator Coulter. Even the Government, even the Labor Party, in this instance was prepared to listen to the reasons, to Senator Kemp's explanations. But while we were all considering this, honourable senators might recall that Senator Coulter jumped up and, without any consultation, without listening to the reasons or to what had happened, moved that motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —To Senator McMullan's horror!

—To Senator McMullan's horror and to everyone else's. To have one's future and the determination of fines left in the hands of people like Senator Coulter would fill me with absolute and abject horror.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson was a director of the radio station 2HD. There are serious and severe responsibilities put on directors. He says that he did not go to many meetings; he did not really know what was happening. I wonder what would happen if in some court case of some lesser mortal his role as a director of a company came up. Nevertheless, Senator Richardson was a director. He is also a very senior member of the Crown. He just happened to forget about this share. That is just incredible for a man who has to think of numerous things, as Senator Bishop pointed out, who knows all the numbers, all the legislation, who knows who is who in the broadcasting business, who supports the Labor Party and who does not—and he just happened to forget this particular instance. Madam Acting Deputy President, you can understand why we are a bit sceptical with that particular excuse. What sort of a Minister is this if he cannot follow the simple rules at all?

A look at Mr Keating's disclosure also amazes me. For example, where it says `Membership of any organisation', Mr Keating says that he was a member of the Federated Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union. That is pretty good, but he does not disclose anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —What arts grants has it received?

—I do not know about the arts grants it has received, but maybe I should ask Senator McMullan whether it is a fact that the Prime Minister is not a member of the Australian Labor Party. Is that Party able to elect a leader who is not one of its members?
—He hasn't listed it.

—He has not listed it; it is not there. Maybe one could say, `It does not matter, he does not get any monetary gain out of it; it is just an oversight'. That is not the point. The rules say that he has to list the organisations in which he is involved. What happens? Do we just allow the Prime Minister to choose those organisations that he wants to disclose and ignore the others? Is that how these rules work? What hypocrisy of Senator Button to introduce these rules when he knows that his Prime Minister does not even abide by them.

PARA.TAB: Under rule 2(b) of the proposed Senate rules—which I understand are the same as the House of Representatives rules regarding Ministers—Mr Keating would be required to disclose family and business trusts and nominee companies in which a beneficial interest is held, `indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust'.

Let us look at Mr Keating's disclosure and what he said. He said, `. . . trustees for our children's minority share interest in the previously mentioned Plueron Pty Ltd'. He is supposed to say the name of the trust, the nature of its operations and the beneficiaries of the trust. He certainly has not disclosed the nature of the operations. Perhaps that is not a major point; perhaps it does not mean much. Mr Keating is simply choosing to ignore the rules where it suits him. He cannot be bothered filling in the form which asks for the nature of its operations. Perhaps Mr Keating is too lazy; perhaps he does not understand. Whatever the reason might be, it is not particularly relevant. The fact is that Mr Keating chooses to ignore the rules that are laid down in disclosure.

Mr Keating says that he has some shares in Plueron Pty Ltd. What Plueron Pty Ltd does, owns, is involved in, is anybody's guess. It shows the stupidity of these rules that are put before us. Perhaps Plueron Pty Ltd owns all the television stations in the land. Who knows? I am sure it does not—I do not think Mr Keating would be that clever. But we never will know because under the rules it appears that one does not have to disclose the assets of any private companies in which one is involved. Where one is required to mention the nature of operation of trusts, the beneficiaries of trusts and the names of trusts, Mr Keating simply ignores that and refuses to do so.

I think this is another appalling hypocrisy by the Labor Party. It has brought this in as an attempt to intimidate the Liberal Party and National Party, to stop them from questioning Senator Richardson about why he failed to disclose, why he did not bother telling us about 2HD, the Labor Party radio station. That radio station must be worth a lot of money. The Labor Party in Queensland used to own 4KQ and sold that radio station for $16m. It must have been a fairly profitable station; it must have had some assets. Maybe 2HD, in the years that have gone by and taking inflation into account—which has been pretty tremendous since those days—is worth an enormous amount of money. Who knows what influence it has?

It is interesting that the Minister for Transport and Communications has chosen not to disclose that in his statement of interest. I am not suggesting anything untoward by Senator Richardson. There was a requirement for him to disclose that. He chose to ignore it; he forgot it; he overlooked it—whatever his excuse. It is a serious breach. The Prime Minister had the solution in his hands and should have disciplined the Minister. Because the Prime Minister has to look after his mates, because he is indebted to so many people for the position he holds in this Parliament, he looked after his mate and ignored it. Instead, he tried to intimidate the Opposition.

At the conclusion of this debate, when my colleagues have finished speaking, they will adjourn the matter and it will then be considered at a later stage. In the meantime I ask Senator Button and his colleagues to think very seriously about what they intend to do with this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion before the chamber. In particular, I wish to direct my remarks to the amendment moved by Senator Hill which states:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. That the Senate condemns

(a) the Minister for Transport and Communications for failing to disclose a registrable interest, namely that he was a director of commercial radio station 2HD, in breach of the Ministerial Statements of Interest as adopted by the Government: and

(b) the Prime Minister Mr Keating for his failure to discipline Senator Richardson for his breach and his hypocrisy in demanding standards of Senators which he has demonstrated he will disregard according to political expedience.

My colleagues have drawn attention to why this motion has come before the chamber this evening. It has come before the chamber because of Senator Richardson's failure to disclose his interest and role in radio station 2HD. It was very interesting to look at what happened when this issue first arose in the other place and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was pressed on this issue. The reading of the Hansard will show that at no time was the Prime Minister prepared to defend or enforce the rules. The Government has decided that Ministers have a responsibility to disclose interests and bring them before the Cabinet and, where needed, before the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: We can ask ourselves: why was this? Tom Burton mentioned in the Sydney Morning Herald that the Prime Minister had failed in his first test on ministerial standards. As my colleague Senator Macdonald pointed out, the Prime Minister failed to indicate in any way to the Parliament, to Senator Richardson, that he frowned on this considerable lapse by a senior Minister of the Crown. Mr Keating failed in his first challenge on ministerial standards. We can ask ourselves: why did he do this? Is it because our Prime Minister lacks standards himself? That is certainly a debate which has been joined many times in this chamber. In my view Mr Keating while Treasurer of this country lacked standards, and he lacks standards now that he is Prime Minister.

Mr Keating has shown time and time again that he is prepared to mislead the Australian people. For example, he has failed to ensure that the Australian people are properly informed about the nature of the crisis facing the country. We can see this in constant comments about whether there would be a recession. All of us can remember during the last election Mr Keating's constant promises that there would not be a recession. We can all recall the debate before the last election as to whether any agreement had been reached between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating with respect to the transfer of the great prime ministerial office of this country after the election. Of course, time and again the people were assured that no such agreement had taken place.

It is not that Senator Richardson is wary of disclosure in all cases. In fact, my colleague Senator Bishop drew attention, rather effectively, to an article which appeared in the Good Weekend last weekend. The cover story is entitled, `The Execution of Brother Bob'. If honourable senators have not read that article, I suggest that they read it. It shows that Senator Richardson is prepared to disclose an awful lot. He disclosed to the author of the article the role that he played in the execution of `Brother Bob'.

If we cast our minds back some years, we will recall that there was a problem in our own Party concerning the issue of a change of leadership. Some colleagues unwisely decided to talk about their particular roles. I suggest that what we have here is Four Corners with a vengeance because Senator Richardson has made these disclosures through sheer vanity and, as Senator Michael Tate would know, this does nothing to advance the cause of the Labor Party and the standing of the Prime Minister and it does nothing to console the former Prime Minister who has lost office as a result of the machinations of Senator Richardson.

A few particular sentences should be recorded in Hansard from `The Execution of Brother Bob' because I suspect they show that there could have been only one source of the disclosure in this article on how the former Prime Minister of this country was tossed out of office. I suggest that that source was Senator Richardson. This is an example of some of the choice paragraphs from this article:

SPEECH.PARA: WITH GREAT enthusiasm but extreme secrecy, Graham Richardson meanwhile set about organising the systematic isolation of the Prime Minister. He set out to deprive Hawke of the support of his innermost circle of political allies, of his Cabinet, of his political friends, even of his long-standing friends in the business world.
Remember that this is a senior man of the Cabinet. He wanted it to become utterly clear to Hawke that he was hopelessly, desperately and friendlessly finished.

PARA.TAB: We can ask ourselves, `Where did the author of this article get his information?'. It is not that Senator Richardson is sensitive about disclosure.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you debating?

—We are debating a motion condemning Senator Richardson. Senator Sherry is never fully briefed when he comes in here. I know that Senator Sherry is sensitive about this, and so he should be, because I believe that he was a Hawke man. He should want to learn how the man he supported was done over by Senator Graham Richardson.

PARA.TAB: This article goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: THE BREATHTAKING aspect of Richardson's campaign was that, at the very time he was orchestrating this ruthless political and psychological warfare against Hawke, he not only maintained a civil relationship with him—
how nice of him and how hypocritical—
but also took part in Hawke's counter-offensive against the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bringing roses to the funeral?
—Yes. Here again we see a man who, at the same time as proclaiming loyalty to the former Prime Minister, was working desperately to undermine that leader.The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The next day, Tuesday, it was Richardson's turn, and he duly and calmly held a press conference in his capacity as Minister for Social Security to say that the Government would outmanoeuvre the Opposition and its "cruel" welfare policy.
Again, let us reflect that this is a senior Cabinet Minister who, on many occasions, was invited to resign from this Parliament if he could not offer support to Mr Hawke. The article continues:
Then he returned to his office to resume the destruction of Hawke. Indeed, the most important fruit of his labour would become publicly visible for the first time the very next day.

The point I am making to this chamber and to members of the public who listen to Senate debates is that Senator Richardson is not a man who is shy of disclosure. In fact, the whole sordid story of the undermining of Mr Hawke was disclosed pretty much in full in the Good Weekend. I suppose Senator Richardson felt that the brilliance of his role in history and his great tactical manoeuvres would be faithfully recorded for posterity. As I say, it is not that Senator Richardson is a man who is shy of disclosure.

PARA.TAB: We can then ask ourselves why Mr Keating, faced with what Senator Richardson called an oversight—but something which others may call gross carelessness and have other vies on—could not bring himself even to admonish Senator Richardson in the smallest possible way. Instead, the Prime Minister decided to bring forward, as a matter of urgency, the motion which has now come before this chamber. I suggest that the Prime Minister will not admonish Senator Richardson in any way because Mr Keating owes Senator Richardson an awful lot. Senator Richardson was the chief of staff who, while serving Mr Hawke, conducted the campaign to ultimately ensure that Mr Hawke was removed from his great office by a small majority of the Labor Caucus, thereby installing Mr Keating as Prime Minister of this country without his ever having to face an election by the Australian people.

That is really why we have this debate in the Senate this evening on the failure of Senator Richardson to conduct himself properly in terms of the full responsibilities required of a man in his high office to disclose his interests. That is also why we have the Prime Minister of this country failing to admonish Senator Richardson in any way for his transgression. Notably, we understand that the reason he failed to do this is that Mr Keating sits in the Lodge now because of the work of Senator Graham Richardson.

As Tom Burton said in the Sydney Morning Herald, it is sad for this country that the Prime Minister could not even bring himself in the slightest way to deliver a public censure to a senior Cabinet Minister who had clearly transgressed his responsibility to disclose his interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Old Jellyback the second!

—The issue has been raised of whether the Prime Minister is Jellyback mark II. In my view, with the way he continues to back down on a number of important issues, that is certainly the case. As I say, when we leave this chamber this evening and when this issue is written up, no-one should go out believing that Senator Richardson is not a man who likes to disclose when he perceives that it suits his interests.

PARA.TAB: I doubt whether this article will suit the interests of the Australian Labor Party. I wonder what members of the public will think when they read about the activities of Senator Graham Richardson. I suspect that, for the most part, they will be absolutely horrified. As I say, let us not imagine that Senator Richardson is in any way sensitive about disclosure, because in this Good Weekend article he disclosed an awful lot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The experience we have had with ministerial disclosure and with House of Representatives disclosure requirements clearly demonstrates that we cannot legislate to enforce integrity. If some members of the Parliament and some members of the Government do not have integrity, it does not matter what requirements are introduced to require them to report. A lack of integrity means a lack of effective reporting on their interests. We have seen this over and over again. It is one of the reasons that Senator Hill has tonight moved the amendment to this Government proposal to require honourable senators to reveal their interests. The amendment reads:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate condemns

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the Minister for Transport and Communications for failing to disclose a registrable interest, namely that he was a director of commercial radio station 2HD, in breach of the Ministerial Statements of Interest as adopted by the Government; and

(b) the Prime Minister Mr Keating for his failure to discipline Senator Richardson for his breach and his hypocrisy in demanding standards of Senators which he has demonstrated he will disregard according to political expedience.

There is a simple fact that emerges out of this 2HD proposition; that is, that Senator Richardson should simply not have been a director. It was improper for him to be a director of 2HD, let alone to fail to disclose that directorship. It is totally improper for someone to be a director of a company which has a vested interest in the outcome of Cabinet decisions. It is certainly improper for that person to be in attendance at such Cabinet meetings and for that person not to formally state his interest. But the key thing is that he should not have had that interest in the first place. The lack of standards that is evident in this Government is overwhelmingly revealed in this situation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson simply does not understand propriety. He does not understand what it is right to do. Apparently, he cannot tell right from wrong, having been involved in so many curious activities in the past. It is like Rex Jackson, the imprisoned and former New South Wales Labor Minister for prisons who sampled the consequences of his own establishment. He was quite genuinely shocked that he should be attacked and imprisoned for doing what he understood everyone in the Labor Government at that time was doing anyway.

I must say that Senator Richardson is not the only person who apparently does not understand the difference between right and wrong, who does not understand the requirements that the Government has theoretically imposed on its members. For example, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr McLeay, when asked to disclose in his register of members' interests shareholdings in public and private companies, including holding companies, indicating the name of company or companies, alongside the word `spouse' wrote the words, `Nil known to me'.

We have had some discussion tonight about the extent to which a spouse has the capacity to know whether his or her partner has interests in various companies. The clear indication given by Mr McLeay on the basis of `Nil known to me' is that it is not necessarily so that Mrs McLeay has no shares but that it is not known to him whether she has shares. That is an interesting situation.

In the matter of John Brown, a former Minister, the principle was quite properly established by his wife that there was no reason why she should be required to reveal the interests that she had acquired as a result of her own efforts. It seems grossly unfair that women who have worked hard and effectively to build up assets—assets which do not impinge necessarily on the activities or determinations made by their husbands—should be obliged to reveal what they are. Why should a woman be disadvantaged even more by being married to a politician than she already is disadvantaged by being married to a politician? That applies equally to males who are married to female politicians. It seems quite extraordinary. But apparently it is not so extraordinary as it is difficult for people like Mr McLeay.

Much to his chagrin, no doubt, an article appeared in the Eastern Herald of Sydney on Thursday, 16 April relating to a former mayor of Marrickville. We hear a lot about mayors and activities of Marrickville. Marrickville is in Mr Leo McLeay's electorate and it is where the Enmore conspiracy took place and where Senator Richardson's great friends Messrs Domican and Meissner were heavily involved—both of them criminals, of course. The Eastern Herald reveals that $72,000 in rates is owed by a company, B.R. Jones and Bros Pty Ltd, to the Marrickville Council and that it was threatened with legal action last year to recover the debt. The interesting thing is that B.R. Jones and Bros Pty Ltd is the company of which the principal executive officer and the major shareholder is Mr Barry Jones, the former mayor of Marrickville and now an alderman of Marrickville, whom Senator Richardson has described as a close friend. He is also a close friend of Mr McLeay.

When Mr Jones was initially asked whether Mr McLeay's wife had shares in this company, he denied that the McLeay family had any involvement in B.R. Jones, saying, `They've got no involvement whatsoever'. Asked whether Mrs McLeay held shares in the company, Mr Jones replied, `Ah, I'd have to check that'. The fact is, of course, that documents lodged with the Australian Securities Commission list as one of the company's six shareholders Mrs Janice McLeay, the wife of Mr Leo McLeay, the Federal MP for Grayndler and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Mr Jones, the proprietor of this company, just happens to be one of Mr McLeay's mates and, of course, one of Senator Richardson's close friends.

Is it not incredible that Mr McLeay can say in his declaration of interests that he had no knowledge of shares held by Mrs McLeay in a company run by his close mate, Barry Jones? It is absolutely incredible, yet we are asked to believe this document signed by Mr McLeay. By golly, his word must be worth a lot if he is prepared to sign something like that. He expects anyone, everyone, to believe that he did not know his wife had shares in the company run by one of his best mates.

This is the sort of thing that brings this Parliament into disrepute. It underlines the disrepute of the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales and it underlines the hypocrisy of the Government presently proposing to impose the same sort of non-standard on this chamber. It is hypocrisy in the extreme. We have to ask ourselves: what is the Government really about? For example, it seems to me that if Senator Richardson wanted to give us a token of his bona fides and if the Labor Party wanted to give us a token of its bona fides, we could perhaps have Senator Richardson and Mr McLeay going back through their declarations of interests and telling the truth—saying what these interests really were.

Mr McLeay can say, `Yes, my wife Janice did in fact have an interest in my mate Barry Jones's company'. By the way, Barry Jones was also involved in a company that was sold to Mr Keating, but that is another story which I suppose we can save for another day. The right wing of the Labor Party is very incestuous in New South Wales.

As a token of their bona fides they could perhaps now correct their registers of interests. We could see what sort of free accommodation and free meals these people have been receiving and not revealing in their declarations of interest.We could find out what alterations to houses have been done free, and not stated in the declarations of interests. We could have a couple of people up on that score, I imagine. It would be interesting to see whether the former Prime Minister would be prepared to reveal how much it cost to renovate his Elizabeth Bay property and who paid the bill. It would be interesting for Senator Richardson to say how much his North Shore property cost to be substantially renovated, who did the work and what the bill, if any, was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking a leaf out of Norm Gallagher's book.

—Yes, and Norm Gallagher went to gaol on that issue for accepting, as I understand it, what was called a secret commission. Unfortunately, we cannot tell whether there are any secret commissions in this chamber or in this Government or in this Parliament. Not because of the absence of requirements to disclose interests in the House of Representatives or in the Government but because of the failure, firstly, of successive Labor Prime Ministers to require Ministers to fill in those statements, properly; and, secondly, the absence of any sanctions against Ministers who misbehave, like Senator Richardson, who deliberately misled the Parliament by failing a clear requirement to state a matter of public interest and make a report that he was a director of radio 2HD, which benefited from significant decisions made by the Cabinet relating to his holding in 2HD.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. In so far as Senator Michael Baume has said of Senator Richardson that he deliberately misled, that is an imputation against the Senator who has said, as I understand it, that it was an oversight on his part that he failed to record that particular matter in the appropriate way. It has just crossed the border of personal reflection on a senator and it ought to be withdrawn.

—I am happy to withdraw the word `deliberate'. Senator Richardson who has such an effective memory in so many other things obviously had, strangely, a defective memory on this occasion if the point made by Senator Tate is accurate, and it may well be. To that extent I certainly acknowledge that it may simply have been a remarkable loss of memory.
—A bit like Burke.

—That interjection is worth noting. Yes, it was a bit like Mr Burke from Western Australia; he kept on forgetting things too. It is interesting that the key influences, the key sanctions, the key pressures on so many right wing Labor Ministers in this Parliament, do not come from the interests that they own in various things. That is not revealed in their declarations of interest and, anyway, if they do have those interests through their wives, they do not reveal them, so what does it matter.The real pressures, the real conflicts of interest, emerge from something far more sinister. For many of them, it is their involvement with the standover men and thugs of the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales—the criminal interests that have been allowed to participate in the Labor Party, particularly while Senator Richardson was the Secretary.

PARA.TAB: I now have to withdraw something that I said earlier. In the May 1991 statement Mr McLeay has at last declared that his spouse has a shareholding. In the May 1991 statement, which I do not have yet—I was relying on the last one—Mr McLeay declares that his spouse has a shareholding in B.R. Jones & Bros. I withdraw the comment I made about Mr McLeay not having released that statement. All we need to do is ask Mr McLeay when his wife acquired that interest. It is certainly not in the latest statement that I have. If Mr McLeay's wife had taken that interest some time before the May 1991 statement was released, that is another matter. I apologise to Mr McLeay; he has declared that his spouse had a shareholding at that time.

I continue with Senator Richardson. It is interesting to note that Senator Richardson has declared the Tattersalls Club among his memberships. That interests me because I noted among the various documents that I have seen that Mr Casey of Balmain Welding nominated Senator Richardson for membership of the Tattersalls Club. This leads me to this particular point that I was trying to make. The most significant influences on members of the Labor Party are clearly not necessarily in their declarations of interests when they are revealed but are from their associations with people of very poor repute.

I asked a question of Senator Richardson at Question Time today. I referred Senator Richardson to the testimony he gave on 4 March this year in the Meissner case. He had met Mr Joe Meissner as recently as 1986 at the arrangement of Mr Warren Anderson—that name seems to keep cropping up all the time; he is Mr Keating's mate—and Senator Richardson had driven Mr Meissner around Sydney's eastern suburbs in his own car while having a discussion. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What interest could a senior Cabinet Minister possibly have in meeting in such a clandestine way a known criminal and standover man who, to the Minister's certain knowledge, had been convicted of stealing Army machine guns to sell to the underworld and who, the Minister—
Senator Richardson—
claimed in this chamber, had been thrown out of the Australian Labor Party six years previously at the Minister's instigation?

Frankly, I feel that there is very little merit in requiring members of the Labor Party to state their investments, to state their wives' investments, and to state their interests, particularly when they seem to be able to avoid doing so with such ease. It would be much more important for us to continue to have before us the reality of the associations they have of a much more serious and much more sinister style. As a result, I strongly support the proposal that this matter be adjourned for seven sitting days. Was that the arrangement?

TALK.START.PARA: —What we said we agreed to, if someone would get on with it.

—I stress the point, in conclusion, that it is grossly unfair that the spouses of members of parliament should be required to reveal their interests. It is grossly unfair that an interest may be minor or major and there be no distinction made between them. The whole proposal is ludicrous. I strongly support the amendment moved by Senator Hill, which is critical of Senator Richardson and underlines the fact that the Labor Government has treated the disclosure requirements with utter contempt.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the debate be adjourned till 7 sitting days after today.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—I call Senator Chapman, but I remind him that he must speak to the adjournment motion, not to the matter under debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concern I have with the motion for the adjournment of this debate is that it will adjourn this debate for seven days. We have no guarantee from the Government about the length of time it will devote to this debate in seven days. Therefore, there are important issues to address with regard to this motion which need to be addressed this evening.
—Such as?

—Such as the absolute hypocrisy of the Labor Party in proposing this registration of senators' interests. That needs to be addressed this evening because we have no guarantee from the Government that we will get the chance to address that issue in seven days time. That hypocrisy is particularly revealed in that it is—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. As I am advised—and as I think you ruled—Senator Chapman can only speak on the question of the length of time for which the matter should be adjourned. He cannot speak to the subject matter at all. He is and he has been out of order entirely.
—It is the adjournment in general.
—My understanding of the advice of the Acting Deputy President, which I think is correct, is that the only matter for debate is the length of time for which the matter has been adjourned.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Senator McMullan is correct. Senator Chapman can explain why we also think that seven days are necessary in order that senators on our side can give proper consideration to the substantive issues at stake.
