—On this point of order, I have already indicated that the motion that is before the Chair is that this matter be adjourned until seven sitting days hence. As I said at the beginning, Senator Chapman and any other speaker on this motion need to address their remarks directly to that motion.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. That is exactly the point. It is important that these issues are addressed. While some remarks can be made with regard to those issues this evening, an enormous amount of research and discussion needs to be taken over the next seven days to highlight and bring to the attention of this chamber the sort of hypocrisy to which I was just referring on the part of the Labor Party. The Labor Party is the party whose members are continually offending against the proprieties of this issue. This evening we have already heard, and incorporated into our amendment to the motion, the situation of Senator Richardson as far as his directorship of the radio station in particular was concerned while a Minister of the Crown and not having declared that interest. That is just one example of the sort of hypocrisy we see on the part of this Government as far as this issue is concerned.

PARA.TAB: The Government brings forward this motion to the Senate seeking registration of senators' interests when it is only members of the Government that have continually offended against this principle. There is no evidence that the Government can bring to us to indicate that Opposition senators have offended against this principle in the present or in the past.

I cite another example on which we will have to do some very detailed research over the next seven days—and that is why this matter should be adjourned for seven days—and that is an issue that is very current in South Australia. It concerns the Minister for tourism in the South Australian Labor Government, Barbara Wiese MLC. Her hypocrisy has recently been evidenced by her failure to disclose the interests of the person she describes as her partner for life—quaint terminology but that is the description she uses—Jim Stitt, who was engaged as a consultant to certain poker machine interests at a time when the State Government was considering the introduction of poker machines into South Australia. There is evidence that the money which Mr Stitt earned as a consultant in this regard had actually passed from his account into a joint account which Minister Wiese shares with Mr Jim Stitt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Chapman has had your ruling pointed out twice yet he is speaking in flagrant abuse of that correct ruling. I ask that it be brought to his attention again and that he be sat down.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to speak on the point of order. Quite clearly, Senator Chapman is making no remarks relevant to the motion. He is using words which amount to a personal reflection on a member of another house of another parliament. He is using the opportunity to smear a member of another parliament who, as I understand it, is facing an inquiry constituted by that parliament where the matters to which he refers will be properly examined with all the authority and force of the rules regulating that Parliament's approach to the problem. I think that Senator Chapman is engaging in a terrible abuse of the process and should be called to order and told to desist.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I have great difficulty in seeing what relevance the matter which Senator Chapman referred to as happening in the South Australian Parliament has to this matter being held over for a further seven days. By no stretch of the imagination can the matters under inquiry by the South Australian Parliament be ruled to be dealing with an adjournment of this matter in this Parliament for seven days.

—As I hear it, there are really two points of order from the three senators who have spoken. Senator McMullan's point requests the Chair to reinforce the ruling that I have already given that any senators speaking now, including Senator Chapman, must address themselves to the element of seven days in the adjournment. I will clarify that. In more correct procedure the Senate would have had two motions before it: one, that the matter be adjourned, which is not debatable; and the second, that the adjournment be for a period of seven days, which is debatable. Strictly speaking, the only element of the matter before the Chair at the moment is the question of the length of time of the adjournment. On that point, I reinforce the earlier ruling. Listening to Senator Chapman, I noted that his argument, which was beginning to become rather lengthy, was related to the seven-day period and events that might occur in the seven days.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the second matter of referring to a member of a State parliament, it is quite in order for a member of this chamber to refer to a State parliamentarian but not to question the bona fides of, or impute any improper motives or activities to, a State member. On neither matter have I heard any offence from Senator Chapman. I reinforce those parliamentary precedents and ask Senator Chapman to continue—but very concisely and very much to the point of the period of seven days; if not, I will intervene myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you for your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I will be very mindful of the points that you have made. As you have indicated, the issues that I have raised in relation to the particular South Australian Minister in no way impute improper motives. I am simply pointing out facts that have been generally accepted and widely reported in the press and, as the Minister himself indicated, have now become the subject of an inquiry set up by the South Australian Government.

PARA.TAB: I repeat that the reason why the matter before us needs to be adjourned for seven days is so that we can conduct further investigations. As I was pointing out, this is yet another example of the hypocrisy and double standards that we see on the part of this Labor Government. Not only at the Federal government level but also at the State government level we see that the requirements already in place for the registration of interest have been flagrantly abused. Therefore, we need to research all of these issues over the next seven days to see whether the Government can justify in principle the motion it is putting before this chamber. Its own practice would indicate that it cannot be justified because of the double standards that it applies in this regard.
We have seen an inquiry set up in South Australia to look into the affairs of Minister Wiese on the basis of allegations that have been made with regard to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Chapman, I ask you to relate each element of your speech to the seven-day period.
—You are just an ordinary, grubby South Australian Liberal politician.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask Senator Tate to retract those most ungenerous comments about Senator Chapman.
—I withdraw them.

—We will need all of these seven days to research those sorts of issues and establish whether the motion that the Government has brought before the Senate today is worthy of support. The issues that we investigate and the research we undertake will not only relate to the double standards that have been applied in this Parliament but also to the double standards that apply in other parliaments.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by reinforcing the need for seven days research so that we can look at some of the documents previously tabled in the Parliament—the return of Ministers' private interests and the return of interests of members of the House of Representatives—just to see what they contain and to determine, as Senator Baume said earlier, whether they are complete and full disclosures of the interests of those Ministers and members.

It seems to me that at first glance there are severe shortcomings in those documents in the extent of the disclosures, because there are very few Ministers who seem to have any assets whatsoever. One would logically come to the conclusion—although, I suppose, we all believe that we are underpaid and overworked as parliamentarians—that on the reasonable salaries that Ministers earn they would have the opportunity to acquire at least some assets over the period that they have been in office. If they have not, it probably indicates that they are as poor managers of their personal finances as they have been of this nation's finances over the last 10 years.

We will need seven days to investigate some of those matters and also to determine whether this proposal which has been brought into the Senate by the Government can be justified in any way. That is the reason why I support the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed from 26 March.
Clause 1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since December the issues encompassed by this legislation have been of paramount importance in the area of Tasmania in which I am domiciled. The amendment to at least change the name—which was part of the agreement arranged between the industry, the Government and the Minister for Tourism, Mr Griffiths—is tremendously important. To an area where jobs are extraordinarily difficult to get, where the unemployment rate is at 30, 40 and even 50 per cent among juveniles, where the number of bankruptcies is absolutely astronomical, the possible construction of a pulp mill is of great consequence.

PARA.TAB: For almost five months I have been constantly talking to people. I have been discussing the various aspects with them in order to try to effect any sort of possible resolution to make the legislation acceptable in some form or another. Right from the start it was a matter of trying to ascertain whether this legislation was going to be equitable and workable. Clearly, as everybody will concede, it is neither.

We accept the fact that the Australian Democrats opposed the legislation right from the start and that they have not changed their position. The position taken by the Government is based on the way in which this matter was dealt with in the first place. I understand that the Labor Caucus approved the legislation some time early in 1991. This was part of the Keating deal. Votes were bought on the basis of this proposal not going ahead. I am almost reticent to repeat an old saying that an honest politician is one who, when bought, stays bought. It looks as if this situation is a perfect personification of that comment.

The actions of the Government do not take into account at all the questions of employment or unemployment. They do not take into account the use of the renewable resource on which this project is based. They do not take into account the question of the effects on northern Tasmania or even on the legislation itself. No genuine considerations are being given at a time when the national economy is at a 60-year low. This whole proposal has been sunk on the factional Keating-style deals that are dominant at the moment.

My colleagues and I have been criticised by our friends and by people all over the State. Most of these people desperately want to support the project. They would like us to do so. But, one by one, they, too, have come to realise that the project is not worth a row of beans in the form that it is in. The various business groupings, members of the industry and, in most cases, the newspaper media, have now started to read the documents and find out how absolutely worthless this legislation is.

It was a great achievement by Mr Griffiths last Monday week ultimately to meet and discuss with various people the various aspects of this matter. That meeting gave everybody considerable hope that there was still time. I say to the Minister that even at this stage there is still time. I would implore Mr Griffiths not to let the opportunity get away to provide some sort of reasonable working condition, even to the extent of accepting the agreement that he was a party to last week.

On the last occasion that this matter was debated the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) said that we were intending to cut Mr Griffiths down, or words to that effect. As far as I am concerned, nothing could be further from the truth. I found Mr Griffiths's approach to this matter to be honourable and reputable. I wish I could say that of all the parties, but I can certainly speak that way as far as he is concerned. It would be interesting to ask Government senators who supports Mr Griffiths and who does not; who has gone off on some romp with Minister Kelly, for instance, and so on?

An offer was made in good faith and accepted by the parties at the meeting that was held last Monday week. It is history now that some people ratted on it and that does not do them any great credit. I regret to say that that starts with the Prime Minister. We know that we are now not able to take any notice of what the Prime Minister says.

I have spoken with many of the people who were involved in that meeting and the processes that went with it. There is not the slightest doubt as to what happened at that meeting and what the arrangements were. The sort of men that I talked to do not lie about a thing like this. However, we should remember that people who lie about small matters will also lie about big ones. I believe that Mr Griffiths and those with whom he had the meeting were in agreement.
Various people have entered the debate as a result of the discussions that we had in this chamber last week about changes. I believe

SPEECH.PARA: that Mr Bacon, who is well known in union circles in Tasmania, also genuinely wants a pulp mill to be built. But why does he not ensure that the Prime Minister is aware of what is involved? Why does he not ask the Prime Minister more often what he is doing about getting the mill going?

PARA.TAB: I am not satisfied that anything in this legislation either is going to cover up the lack of goodwill and bona fides that the Government has so far exhibited or is necessarily going to result in the establishment of a pulp mill. The Government has not been able to satisfy us on either of those counts and the legislation does nothing to take away our concerns. It is not good enough to have this type of arrangement.

The other night we did not cover the important question of the Resource Assessment Commission report. Why is it that the Minister for Resources, the Prime Minister and other Ministers have absolutely refused even to comment about the fact that there has been a Resource Assessment Commission report? How can the Government proceed at a time like this without even mentioning this report, without even coming back to the recommendations which are totally in conflict with the legislation?

What is the answer? We expect to be able to get answers. We cannot tolerate this type of legislation, which the Government claims to have been the subject of a great deal of discussion, when the main body of information which it has—the Resource Assessment Commission report—makes all sorts of recommendations which are totally contrary to what is mentioned in the Bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —It says that the legislation is not necessary.

—It says that the legislation is not necessary. That is the first point that we in Opposition made. It means that it `should not' be necessary, but it actually says that it `is not' necessary. It is only necessary because the Government cannot be trusted. If one could take the word of the Government in this, it would not be necessary. But it has been shown, and I will come back to that shortly, that it is necessary.

PARA.TAB: What about all those various agreements in Tasmania? I have here this memorandum of understanding, for instance. It is a very interesting document to have before us. The memorandum of understanding was supposed to be the last and final document, the be all and end all. It was going to resolve all the problems. How long did it last? The ink was still wet at the time this Government moved in and started chopping and changing it around. I will give just a few examples. Page xxxviii states:

SPEECH.PARA: Conflict over forest use will not be reduced if governments continue to rely on ad hoc reactive mechanisms for accommodating the interests of more than one government in the forest use decisions.

What does the Minister propose to do about that? The Commonwealth Government's Forest Conservation and Development Bill is largely irrelevant to the majority of producers in the forest industry since it applies only to projects of more than $100m. What about that? Will the Minister make sure he answers that? The next part reads:

The inquiry's preferred approach to resource security is to strengthen and advise agreements between forest management agencies and industries, particularly through the development of enforceable contracts with clear provisions for compensation.
What about that one? I would like to have an answer to that. It goes on:
Providing financial compensation if a land use change resulting from the Commonwealth policy or decision causes disruption to industries reliant on the forest resource.
What are we going to do about that recommendation? The next one reads:
For improved intergovernmental institutions and decision processes that would support comprehensive forward planning for forest use.
Are we doing anything about that? Let us just find out how this ties in with this crummy bit of second-hand legislation that we have before us at the moment. The next example I have here reads:
To bring together all Commonwealth responsibility for forest policy within a single organisation.

All I can see in this is that we have more organisations. I am very happy to be advised by the Minister to the contrary. It is not good enough for us to be still dealing with this when the Resource Assessment Commission recommends to the contrary.

PARA.TAB: I was lucky enough to be able to get to a meeting the other night with Phillip Glyde, who was a member of the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry team. He was able to tell us quite a lot about that. I am sorry that neither the Minister, nor anyone else from the Labor Party except Mr Jim Snow was there to hear him because it was really a very good expose on what was going on and on what the recommendations were. If the Minister will, for a start, give me a run-down on where we stand in this legislation in relation to the various points I raised, I will be very pleased. I will come back to him with some more questions then.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 and we are in the committee stage of the debate. The second reading stage of this debate has been exhausted. This Bill was sent to an inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs and that inquiry heard public evidence and the evidence of the various interested parties and has reached its conclusions.

PARA.TAB: We have now returned this Bill to the Senate to debate the committee stage. We did that, in parliamentary time, about three or four hours ago. We spent last Thursday in the committee stage debating it all morning and part of the evening. The farce is that we have not yet dealt with clause 1 in committee. We have not yet dealt with clause 1, Short title, despite the fact that the Opposition has foreshadowed that it intends to move an amendment to that title. It has not yet moved its amendment. I invited it to do so on Thursday evening before we rose for the weekend and it declined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did too.

—Senator Coulter is right. I should respect the honour of the Greens. Senator Coulter did it before I did. He made the plea before I did. So the Opposition was invited twice to move its amendment to clause one, Short title, and it has refrained from doing so.

PARA.TAB: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
(Senator Jones did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Olsen.)
Question so resolved in the negative.
Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the last division I was making the point that Senator Coulter and I had invited the Opposition to move its amendment. It specifically declined to do so on Thursday night. We have spent three to four hours debating in the committee stage, but we are not yet past the first clause. I think this makes a mockery of the procedures and turns this into high farce.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I move the following amendment to this Bill, which is the amendment circulated in my name:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 1, page 1, line 4, omit "Development", substitute "Major Projects".

I understand that is the amendment that Senator Tambling indicated he would move.I move this amendment in order to end this stand-off. As I said in the debate last Thursday, what is in a name? A rose by any name would smell as sweet. Again, that is not an accurate quote from Shakespeare. In case Senator Winston Crane comes in here and says that I have again misled the chamber, I wish to indicate that the quote is near enough but is not quite dead accurate.

PARA.TAB: The point is that the Opposition was standing on what it called a principle in insisting that the name must change. We will not hold up the passage of this legislation or the opportunity for job creation that it will bring to northern Tasmania. We will not hold up the opportunity of rebuilding the northern Tasmanian economy. We will not thwart the wishes of the Tasmanian Government or our own intent. We will not thwart the intent of the industry. We will make the change ourselves if the Opposition is not prepared to do so, because the change in its nature is not a significant one which fundamentally affects the intent of the legislation. That should pacify the Opposition and cause it to vote for the legislation.

The second point I make is that last Thursday I was interjected on several times by senators saying, `It is not just the name, you know. There are undertakings'. I understand that, in a debate in the House of Representatives on Thursday afternoon, Mr Griffiths, who has just been lauded by Senator Archer—and I agree with the praise heaped upon his head—made the Government's position clear in terms of the undertakings sought. I refer honourable senators to the Hansard debate last Thursday and to a passage in it in which Mr Griffiths said:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be a sin of omission on my part were I not also to say that there are differences in terms of the Opposition's desire to see the Government embrace, in a written instrument to itself, undertakings relating to the ongoing monitoring of the legislation and, in the event of the legislation being found wanting, indicating a preparedness to review within a reasonable time frame any shortcomings in the legislation. As a mirror image of that policy position, I might say the same thing in relation to enhanced intergovernmental agreement processes.

PARA.TAB: I am quite happy to indicate in this chamber, on the record, that any legislation for which I have responsibility either as Minister for Resources or, for that matter, as Minister for Tourism would, in the normal course of events, be subject to such ongoing monitoring and review.

That means that, if this Bill becomes an Act, Mr Griffiths is committing himself, as the responsible Minister, to monitoring its operation and, if necessary, in view of the whole situation, review its operation and, in reviewing its operation, to consult all of the relevant players in this debate as a normal process of prudent and good government. The undertakings sought by the Opposition are in a similar vein. I put it to the Opposition that, if I have the opportunity at the third reading stage of this Bill—should it reach that far—because that seems to be the appropriate place for Government undertakings, I will indicate that this passage in the MPI, which was debated in the House of Representatives on 30 April, is interpreted to mean a commitment to monitor, review and consult and should meet the requirements of the Opposition as it has put them forward. I will say this again at the third reading stage of the Bill. If, for whatever reason, I do not get an opportunity to say that in a third reading speech, I am sure the Minister will make that clear undertaking to all of the players in the industry, and I have his authority to say that.

On the questions of title and undertaking, the Government has moved some distance to meet the Opposition's requirements. Alas and alack, that does not appear to satisfy it, because I am advised—although I must say I have not actually seen the document myself—that Mr Bruce Lloyd has issued a statement indicating that it is the Opposition's intention to oppose this Bill. I understand that the Opposition intends to move laboriously each one of its amendments and, if they are defeated, as I expect they will be, to defeat the Bill.

I would counsel the Opposition earnestly not to do that and to take pause and reflect on what that course of action is likely to lead to. I have understood all along that the Opposition's consistent position has been in fact to follow the policy position of the National Association of Forest Industries and that if the National Association of Forest Industries reflects a view that will tend to be the Opposition's view. If I am correct in my understanding about that, then I am here to inform the Opposition that it is also my understanding that the National Association of Forest Industries supports the passage of this legislation. If the Opposition thinks to the contrary, then it should contact it and ascertain the truth.

My understanding is based on a facsimile of 18 February 1992, under the masthead of the NAFI, National Association of Forest Industries, which is signed by Robert Bain, the Executive Director, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: At a meeting of the NAFI board on 17 February 1992, the NAFI policy on resource security was unanimously re-endorsed as follows:
1. The current legislation is not supported by NAFI in its current form as it will exclude most of the industry. However—
I direct the Opposition's attention to the word `however' because this is the pregnant qualifier in these circumstances—

TAB.TAB: members would not be opposed to its passage if this is a necessary step to the establishment of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I am prepared to table this document or, indeed, seek leave to have it incorporated so that the Opposition can have in the record for its knowledge and perusal the words, `However, members would not be opposed to its passage if this is a necessary step to the establishment of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania'.

PARA.TAB: I go now to a quotation which appeared on the front page of the Hobart Mercury last Thursday morning where Mr Chris Oldfield, a spokesman for the proponents, North Broken Hill Peko Ltd, who has gained some notoriety over recent weeks, said of the pulp mill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but no resource security legislation, no pulp mill.
I refer back to the words of NAFI:
However, members would not be opposed to its passage if this is a necessary step to the establishment of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania'.

`No legislation, no pulp mill'. Even the Opposition surely understand that if it defeats this Bill the proponents of the pulp mill in northern Tasmania will not proceed. So to defeat this Bill is to defeat that project—a project which has been described by the proponents as one that would provide 2,000 jobs in northern Tasmania in the construction phase alone and a pulp mill which would have provided the impetus for an economic revival in northern Tasmania. Those were not the Government's words but the words of the proponents of the mill—to defeat the mill and to defeat those social and economic implications.

PARA.TAB: If the Opposition does that, the Opposition has absolutely no clothes in pretending, in the synthetic way in which it does, that it has concern for unemployment or people out of work in northern Tasmania. Here is a single opportunity whereby the Opposition can actually do something that will create jobs. Given that the Government has moved on the title and on the undertakings, here is a single opportunity whereby the Opposition can do something to create jobs. If the Opposition defeats it, it will be defeating job opportunities for people in northern Tasmania, the economic revival of the northern half of that State and the advantages to the current account deficit, the development of this industry and all of the implications about industry development that flow therefrom.

I have taken a moment to clearly and starkly point out the choice before the Opposition at this time. I now recall the words of Senator Archer, who spoke before me just a moment ago, when he said he supports Mr Griffiths and what a good bloke Mr Griffiths is. I say to Senator Archer, `Here is an opportunity for you to show support for this Minister and, despite what your Party might say, cross the floor and support the legislation'.

Let me now go to the next point that I wish to make. As I have said, what now faces this chamber is the chance to give employment and economic revival to the northern half of Tasmania. If this chamber were to defeat that aim, let me make this position very clear: I would hold no animus or opposition to the role of the Australian Democrats. They have been consistent in their principle and they have conducted themselves honourably in this debate. Even though I oppose them and even though they know I will oppose them—and that will be an ongoing argument of principle between us—we will conduct ourselves as honourable people in that debate. That is not a position that is open to the Opposition which, as I say, with all this synthetic concern for the unemployed, pretends that it can turn this whole debate now into a circus, a farce and a charade. I return to the point: if the Opposition's advice is from NAFI as to what it should do, then it is under a misunderstanding. It should in fact do as NAFI wants it to do and support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, did you wish to incorporate a document?

—I indicated a willingness to do so, Mr Chairman. I never responded to the interjections, but several senators opposite said that they know of it. My intention in incorporating it was to draw it to their attention. Since they know of it, I do not think there is any need to proceed with the incorporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well might the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) describe the debate which we have had so far in the committee stage on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill as high farce. Here we are, about four hours into the debate in the committee stage, and the Minister has had to take egg on his face and move the very amendment that he spent hours last Thursday arguing against.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I would draw to your attention the fact that Senator Coulter has just made an allegation that we are four hours into the debate in this Committee. Prior to the comments of Minister Cook a few moments ago, the actual committee stage of this Bill was in fact only two hours 54 minutes old. The Minister has just spoken, so that is only three hours into the debate on this Bill. It would seem that we again have these fabricated figures of the Australian Democrats. Mr Chairman, I invite you to ask Senator Coulter to correct his record.
—Order! That is a point of view; it is not a point of order.

—I am delighted to accept what Senator Tambling says. All right, we have been going for three hours. The Opposition was invited twice to put its amendment to clause 1, refused to do so, and the Government has now had to put its amendment. That is high farce by anybody's stretch of imagination.

PARA.TAB: But I must say that I am achieving somewhat more respect for the Opposition in its position on this legislation now, because we have from the Opposition repeated claims that without all 17 amendments this legislation will not pass. At least it seems to me that the Opposition is sticking firm with its position. As early as 5 November 1991, Mr Bruce Lloyd and Mr Fred Chaney, in a joint statement, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Given that no amount of tinkering with the draft Bill is likely to produce an acceptable outcome, the Opposition urges the Government to consider alternative approaches—
and it goes on to make it quite clear that the Opposition without those amendments would not pass it. It continues:
The Federal coalition had decided to oppose the Forest Conservation and Development Bill that was due to be debated last night in the House of Representatives—
and it goes on to say that the coalition are seriously concerned, et cetera. On 24 March this year, the Opposition—again under the names of Bruce Lloyd and Fred Chaney—said in a press release:

PARA.TAB: The future of the resource security legislation rests with the Government.
If it accepts and moves the amendments proposed by the National Association of Forest Industries, the amended legislation will be supported by the Federal Opposition.
If not, the legislation is doomed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has made it absolutely clear all the way along that it will not pass the legislation without these amendments. On 29 April, Mr Bruce Lloyd stated:

PARA.TAB: The coalition will oppose the Forest Conservation Development Bill which will be debated in the Senate tomorrow if the Government refuses its amendments to provide genuine resource security.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the Opposition is at least developing an element of consistency in relation to its stand on this legislation. Given that level of consistency, that repeated undertaking that it will not pass this legislation without those 17 amendments, let us stop this high farce. Let us get on with putting those amendments, vote on them and get rid of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: It seems absolutely clear that the Government's position and that adopted by the Opposition is intransigent. The outcome of this debate, however late we go tonight, is already well known. For the standing of the Senate, it is time to truncate this high farce, to get on with voting on these amendments as quickly as possible and to dispose of this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 an urgent Bill and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be considered an urgent Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 15 standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent debate taking place on the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight has been a farce, but not in the terms that have been put by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) or by the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter). The farce started when we spent the whole of the evening, almost until the time for the adjournment, debating a matter with respect to which the Government has seen no urgency for the past five years. The matter has been left languishing for five years. It has been five years since it was last thought to be of any relevance to this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Because the Government got itself into such an appalling mess last week over Senator Richardson, who abused the standards that the Government had set for its Ministers, and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did not have the courage to discipline him, it needed a diversion. The diversion was to introduce as a matter of great urgency the so-called disclosure and standards provisions and require that they be debated in this place immediately. How much time did that take tonight? It took two and a half hours before the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), having demanded that it be debated today as a matter of great urgency—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. My point relates to relevance. We have just had a debate on what Senator Hill is talking about and he took part in that debate. That is not the subject before the chamber. He should direct his remarks to what is before the House.
—I am trying to explain why this Bill is not urgent and why the Government tonight has wasted so much time on its business—business that has not been urgent for the past five years.
—It wasn't our fault.

—It is the Government's fault; it put the Bill down to be dealt with today. The Government put the Bill down purely as a political diversion, with no objective other than to waste the time of this chamber. The Government has wasted several hours tonight, yet Labor senators have the gall to stand up and say that this should be dealt with as an urgent Bill. This is one of the most important pieces of legislation to be dealt with in this chamber for a long time. There is no reason at all why it should not be dealt with properly according to the processes of this place—which it has until now. It has had a second reading debate and has been dealt with properly by the Committee according to the Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: The Government is unhappy about something—which I will get to in a second—and wants the Bill disposed of this evening. It is doing so by means of the Standing Orders and by declaring the Bill urgent. Why does the Government want to debate this Bill tonight? Because it is afraid of what will happen in Caucus tomorrow. There are those in the Government who actually want to see a mill go ahead in Tasmania. There are those in the Government who are opposed to it to the last breath—namely, the Left and those supporting the far Greens. The one thing the Government does not want tomorrow is a debate within Caucus on this important issue—a debate which might have a chance of bringing the Government to some commonsense and to the point of agreeing to a reasonable compromise that would enable us to support the legislation. It is not just the compromise of the Opposition—the Minister for Industrial Relations should not shake his head—but is the compromise as of last week of the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) which would enable passage of this legislation.

Let us look at this in its proper sequence. The proposal for compromise was put by the industry—by NAFI. The Minister entered into discussions with Mr Lloyd. The Minister said, `I am prepared to buy the compromise, but I want you to take it to your leadership first because I am not going to go to Mr Keating and find that you are going to let me down'. We did the right thing and took it through our processes. We said, `Yes, we will bear the compromise because it will achieve the objective of reasonably project-specific legislation, plus a commitment to the regional plans which will give a chance to the small players in the industry to get protection as well'. It was a reasonable compromise in all the circumstances.

When Minister Griffiths did the right thing and took it to Mr Keating, Mr Keating, for purely political reasons, said no. The story is that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) was phoned and said that she would not wear the regional plan because the Greens say that they do not want development in other areas of national forest in this country. Mr Keating said, `We are not going to take that back into Caucus and debate it again because we will be in all sorts of trouble'. This Government is not really interested in this development; it is not interested in proper project management in this country. There is no reason for this Bill to be declared urgent tonight. The processes can continue in a proper way, they will be dealt with in a proper way and voted upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industry want it.
—The industry want it?
—They said so at the Committee.
—Yes, I have read every word of that Committee—it was a good Committee.
—It had a good Chairman, that is why.
—It was not chaired too badly, either. Senator Burns ought to tell the Minister why this thing could be dealt with in according the proper processes of the Parliament.

—This debate on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 is being elevated beyond high farce; this is taking it further than in any sense is credible. Senator Hill is arguing that this Bill is not urgent. He is arguing that it is not urgent after—let me get the figure right; I do not want to mislead or I will have a motion aimed at me from Senator Winston Crane if I say one word out of place—one hour and 52 minutes of debate in the Committee stage. The point is that we have not yet moved off the first clause. What would any reasonable person think about that? Any reasonable person would think that a filibuster is being pulled here. What evidence do we need to establish that proposition? We do not need to go any further than what was said by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Robert Hill. He said—this is his conscientiously held warped view of the future—that the Government will be defeated in Caucus tomorrow and therefore the Bill will somehow be withdrawn by the Government. That is not true.

PARA.TAB: For the sake of fairytales let us believe for a minute that that might be true. What is Senator Hill's reason for delaying it? He is colluding with the people he is accusing and is therefore engaging in a manoeuvre to prevent the Bill coming into existence, to prevent the 20,000 jobs being created, to prevent the extra advantages to the current account deficit being achieved and to prevent the development of a major pulp mill value-added project in northern Tasmania which will revive the north of that State's economy. If we talk about clean hands, sincere purpose and principle here, let us not use Senator Hill as a measure, because none of the things he has said about this legislation indicates sincere purpose.

Nor does the behaviour of his Party indicate sincere purpose. While we may have spent only two hours and 52 minutes considering this Bill, we sure as hell still have not got off the first clause. The Opposition, invited by Senator Coulter and myself on Thursday afternoon, would not move its own amendment. The Government has come to a position of moving it for the Opposition and thereby embarrassing the Opposition. The Government has declared its commitment to the undertakings that the Opposition wanted achieved.

What does the Opposition do? It applies the salami technique of one slice at a time. It pockets all that and says, `We are still opposed', flying in the face of NAFI, of the Tasmanian Government and Premier Groom in that Government, of North Broken Hill Peko, which is the company that wants this development, of the ACTU, which argues strenuously for it, and of this legislation of the Federal Government. If anyone has any explaining to do, it is the Opposition. If it has any explaining to do, it is now that there is clear apprehension in this chamber that it simply wants to delay, obstruct and prevent. The Opposition's role is that of spoiler.

This legislation is urgent. We have to face up to it one way or another and declare where we stand. There should be no more foxing, ducking and weaving. The Opposition should come out of the woodwork and say exactly where it stands. It should either support or defeat the legislation, and be judged by the electors accordingly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who cants hypocrisy should look at today's Order of Business. This morning's meeting of the Government Whips listed the agenda program of this Senate for this day as follows: No. 3, Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Bill 1992; No. 9, Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1992; No. 6, Ozone Protection Amendment Bill 1992; No. 4, Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1992; and No. 1, Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991, in committee. This matter is at the bottom of the list on today's agenda for the Senate. Was the Government's priority set this morning? If this matter was so damned urgent, as the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has just said—the Government has had the weekend to think about it, and it has known the pressures that it has been under in the media—what is it really reacting to?

PARA.TAB: We all well know that the response of making this matter urgent and of priority in the Government's program has only happened this afternoon because it has read today's media. It has come to grips with where the community is going and what the interest groups and everyone is saying. The only urgency on this issue is to keep the matter off the Caucus agenda tomorrow.

Senator Sherry ought to know, because he spoke to a group of forest people here at lunchtime today in a meeting room. He said that the agenda was proceeding very well and that he hoped the Government would get down to that area and make further considerations. I am probably making a precis of that meeting, but nonetheless he indicated that there would be reviews. The Government now comes in here tonight demanding urgency. Why? The question needs to be asked so very seriously as to what has changed.

We have seen the scenario of how the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, has become a political eunuch in the last week. He is now subservient to the politically promiscuous tart, Mrs Kelly. That is the factor that is now worrying the Government, as is the collusion between the Prime Minister and Mrs Kelly, between Kuala Lumpur and Canberra, last week on the reasons why Prime Minister Keating does not want this on the Caucus Notice Paper tomorrow.

There is really a degree of hypocrisy about this motion that the Government now claims is urgent. Sure, I accept that we have already spent three hours in the committee stage; and, yes, the Bill has had a very good second reading debate; and, yes, it has been to a standing committee. But people should read the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs from cover to cover and look at the evidence that was tendered.

Senator Cook had the audacity to come in here a while ago and table a NAFI letter of 18 February this year in support of his arguments. He sat through most of the NAFI evidence to the Standing Committee—or if he did not, he ought to have read the Hansard—when its witnesses appeared before that Standing Committee, much later than 18 February, and said very pointedly that unless the amendments that were being considered were incorporated the legislation would not be relevant. But the Minister again has the audacity to come in here and say, `Here, consider this. Look at a date'. It is a matter of selective quoting: pulling out bits of letters and going back into the archives. It is so typical of the management of the Labor Party—even when it tries to manage its own troops for debate.

It is interesting to note that not one member of the Left in this chamber has entered this debate in any of the long hours we have already given to the discussion. Senator Zakharov might be sitting there now, but she has not piped up once. Where have the rest of the Left been? They have been in collusion over this whole problem with Mrs Kelly and Senator Bolkus with the phone calls to Kuala Lumpur and back, and the conniving and deals that have gone on the last few days.

Now we have this problem. The legislation is so urgent that it has to be considered tonight. The Government tells us that it has to be done! He says that we have to be here and we have to impose a time constraint upon the whole debate. That is not the way in which we wish to consider this matter. It is an important piece of legislation. There is a lot more debate to be had yet with the Democrats and the Labor Party on this particular issue. Just declaring it urgent, doing a fiddle late at night and thinking we will be fooled—no way in the world. This legislation demands and needs proper consideration clause by clause, and it should have it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of reasons why a matter might be considered urgent. For instance, the country might be at war and we might be being invaded. That might make a matter urgent. There may be a time when a piece of legislation must begin because people are perhaps in dire poverty and so on. I remind the Opposition that more than one million people are unemployed. That is a very important consideration.

PARA.TAB: The other reason why matters might be considered urgent is that the Senate is simply wasting time. That is precisely what is going on here. I remind the media people who are sitting in the press gallery that every word which is spoken in this chamber costs $23. The Opposition made its position absolutely clear as recently as 29 April—I do not have to go back to February. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition will oppose the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. . . if the Government refuses its amendments to provide genuine resource security.
It continued:
However we were prepared to pass the Bill with the three elements of the agreement. This has not happened. This gives us no choice but to oppose the Bill.

We know what the outcome of this legislation will be; we know what the vote will be at the end of it; and we know that the Government will reject the 17 amendments that we have debated ad nauseam through the second reading stage, the committee stage and now back here for more than three hours. We know what the result will be. Let us get on with really important matters which deal with things such as those one million people who are unemployed at present: the people who could do with the $23 for every word that is spoken in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to oppose the Forest Conservation and Development Bill being declared urgent, I remind Senator McMullan, Senator Cook and Senator Coulter that while we may have spent two hours and 54 minutes discussing this Bill, many members of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs—including myself—have had a very minimal contribution. I have had only six minutes. Yet we spent three days taking evidence. I also remind honourable senators on the Government side that when the Committee came to vote, it required the casting vote of the Chairman for it to be carried. It was a totally split committee.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators opposite come in here tonight and use such words as `farce' in terms of the debate which is taking place. This piece of legislation relating to resource security is one of the most important pieces of legislation ever to come before an Australian parliament, because it is resource security in this country that has become a farce; it has been destroyed. There is no confidence in this country of ours right now in terms of investment and getting major projects off the ground. If we get this piece of forest legislation wrong—and the Committee was divided fifty-fifty on it, albeit for different reasons, in the case of Senator Bell—the implications for the future are quite enormous. One only has to look at the mining industry in Western Australia as one example.

It is our right in Opposition to debate every single word and every clause of this particular Bill because of the implications that will flow from it. It is about time the Government turned around and had a look at the agreement that Minister Griffiths reached with NAFI and the distance to which we were prepared to go. The Government is not prepared to go that distance.

I am glad that Senator Sherry stayed in the chamber because I took some notes today on what he said at the meeting at which he spoke. Senator Sherry said to the people sitting at the meeting that he supported their position. He said that he was more hopeful today than he was yesterday. He also said, `Who knows what tomorrow will bring?'. He stood there and misled those people at the meeting.

As my colleagues explained, this Bill has to proceed, to use your term, `urgently', not for the purposes of the Bill but to save you from having to face the music at tomorrow's Caucus meeting. That is the urgency as far as you are concerned. It was totally irresponsible of you to give those people false hopes when you have been overridden. I can understand why you did it. It has been outlined by Senator Tambling. It was listed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane, please direct your remarks through the Chair.

—Certainly, Mr Chairman. Through you, Mr Chairman, I say that I can understand why it has suddenly become urgent to pass this Bill as far as Senator Sherry is concerned because he will have to back away from that position in Caucus tomorrow or he will have to have his position carried. That is why this urgency motion has been brought on—not because it was urgent at the time of the listing of Government Business today.

PARA.TAB: I end by turning to Senator Coulter's position, which centres on the fact that the Democrats want the whole of this legislation to be defeated. They believe they should be more concerned with having the legislation totally defeated tonight than with working to the correct position and getting the best results for the forest industries.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a motion on whether the Forest Conservation and Development Bill should be declared an urgent Bill. In the course of the debate, Senator Tambling said that we should not try to make fools of the Opposition in regard to this matter. I assure Senator Tambling that we are not trying to do that; we do not need to as those opposite are doing a very good job all by themselves.

PARA.TAB: There has been a great deal of emphasis on the Caucus meeting tomorrow, something that the Opposition appears to be fascinated with. It may be said that there are a lot of things which go on around the Senate that I do not know very much about, and sometimes perhaps people accuse me of talking about them in spite of that. But one thing that people generally accept that I know a bit about is the way the Labor Party works and its rules and things. I have been sitting here trying to think of the procedural process by which this matter would be on the Caucus agenda tomorrow if this Bill were not passed. I cannot see what it would be. It will not be on the agenda. How would it get there? Can Senator Tambling explain to me how it would be on the Caucus agenda?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it so urgent that nobody can raise it?

—Someone might ask a question about it; of course that is the case. Someone can ask a question about anything, but that does not change the legislation. I think those opposite are inventing shadows for other people to jump at.

PARA.TAB: Let us talk about why this Bill should be urgent. What are the criteria that indicate whether a Bill should be urgent? Firstly, one-off legislation such as this Bill needs to be important. Then we need some likelihood or reasonable apprehension that the Bill will not be passed in a reasonable time under the normal processes of the Parliament. I do not think there is any great disagreement around the chamber concerning the first of those two criteria—that is, this Bill is important. People might have different views about its merits, and even about how vitally important it is, but overall I think all 76 senators agree it is an important piece of legislation.

Is there a likelihood or a reasonable apprehension that this Bill would not be passed in reasonable time in the normal procedures of the Senate? I think it is reasonable to draw that conclusion. We have had a lengthy second reading debate and a lengthy committee review. We have now had at the committee stage more than three hours of debate on the first clause, without an amendment being moved or anything being put to the vote, and there has been an indication of many more amendments. At that rate, quite clearly, it would be a very long time before the Senate, through its normal processes, would come to a conclusion with regard to this Bill.

By any normal measure of what is an indication of why one ought to move to declare a Bill urgent, this Bill clearly meets those criteria. For that reason, the Government proposed that it should be declared urgent. I think we have had confected outrage from the Opposition. I gave Opposition members notice of my intention to move this, so they all went off and manufactured their outrage. But they know it is a good idea. They probably will be absolutely relieved when this motion is carried and the Bill is off the Notice Paper, however they eventually choose to vote, so we can get on with the rest of the important business before the Senate.

We have heard this sort of debate by numbers before, with people reiterating their concern about urgency motions when they are in Opposition and moving them with alacrity as soon as they get into government. Let us not have all that manufactured outrage; let us get on with the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a very high element of cynicism in this urgency motion before us tonight. The chamber has before it a Bill which is quite improper and inadequate, and full of loopholes for an unscrupulous government to exploit. We have seen a sad history of exploitation in Tasmania. But for some reason the Labor Party's agenda suddenly changed today. As my colleague Senator Tambling said, the first indication of that change of heart came when the Notice Paper itself was changed. Evidently, the Government realised it was going to face some embarrassment from its own back bench, probably at tomorrow's Caucus meeting. So why the change? Why the urgency?

PARA.TAB: The virtuous words of Senator Cook about wanting a pulp mill have come seven years too late. We all know that Mrs Kelly wants to skittle any successful legislation, which is the second prerequisite demanded by North Broken Hill. If that legislation is killed now, she will be spared that embarrassment. So there was no urgency in 1986-87, when the ALP refused to back John Kerin in his memorandum of understanding, because within six months of that memorandum of understanding being signed, it was broken. The environmental impact statement stated that Jackeys Marsh and the Lemonthyme areas were to be logged. However, the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, overruled his Minister—a familiar story—and stopped the logging that was to occur in Jackys Marsh.

The Helsham inquiry was a consequence of the Jackys Marsh decision. Mrs Kelly will go through this whole ritual again. The Government will try to spare that option. I remind the Senate that there was no urgency then. The Helsham inquiry ran for 12 months and led to the Cook agreement of 1988. I remind the Senate that Senator Cook, the then Minister for Resources, and Mr Ray Groom, the then Minister for Forests, again ratified a forest management system in the areas outside the World Heritage area. The agreement also declared that the Government would not unilaterally impose any more World Heritage areas on Tasmania.

What is the urgency in situations such as we have today? This surely demonstrates the hypocrisy of the Government not to put proper legislation in place. It is always looking for the loopholes. We are saying, `Get it right. There is no urgency about it'. The Government will have a very long environmental study which will amount to absolutely nothing. Its track record has been very poor. I submit that there is no urgency on this issue.

The Government has taken its time in the past. It has skittled legislation, it has skittled memorandums of understanding and it has disregarded commission inquiries. We, the Opposition, are saying, `Get it right. You need time. There is no urgency. Don't press the matter. Get it right to save all those poor people who are likely to lose their jobs'. We need that mill in Tasmania, but we need it under the right conditions. With the right legislation, the Government will not walk away from it and cause further dismay and anger in Tasmania.

Under this legislation the forest industry will continue to be in a continual state of uncertainty, crying out for proper resource security legislation. This Bill will not deliver it. The coalition will deliver it. We have promised proper security legislation when we come to power. I submit that this legislation is inappropriate and there is no urgency for it to get through. I call upon the Government to bring in proper amendments in order that the coalition can make sure that we have appropriate legislation to enable a pulp mill to be built not only in Tasmania but also in Western Australia and in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
(Senator Jones did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Olsen).
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question put:
That the Bill be considered an urgent Bill.
(Senator Jones did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Olsen.)
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That 90 minutes be the time allotted for consideration of the remaining stages of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 16 standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent the motion being debated without limitation of time and each Senator speaking for the time allotted by standing orders.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion relates to the time that will be allowed for debating the remainder of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) has been telling us tonight, we are still on clause 1, and the Government has the view that the whole of the Bill can now be disposed of within just an hour and a half. In other words, each of our various amendments can be dealt with, the amendment that the Government is putting can be dealt with, and the arguments for and against each can be disposed of within an hour and a half. It is the view on this side of the chamber that that is totally unreasonable and it does not lead to good legislation.

PARA.TAB: I might say in passing how disappointed we are again with the Australian Democrats. They were elected here to keep the bastards honest, but on each occasion when it comes to the crunch they say, `We'll pass the guillotine this time, but never again'. Each time it recurs they say, `We'll pass the guillotine this time, but never again'. What happened at the end of last session has happened again. We are prepared to sit here as long as is necessary to do the job properly. Why will the Australian Democrats not do likewise?

It is not such an arduous task to do the job properly—to finish a debate which is of such serious consequence as this one and deal with our amendments. Our amendments were put in the first instance before the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs—I agree—and they attracted widespread support. As Senator Coulter will agree, our amendments attracted the support of the industry; they attracted the support of NAFI, the national body; they attracted the support of FIAT, the State body; and they attracted the support of the unions. They have, in effect, attracted support from everybody except the Government and the Australian Democrats.

Why can we not have the opportunity to put them properly to this chamber and have the arguments in favour of them debated? Why are the Democrats restricting us from that opportunity; restricting our right of speech in this the only chamber in the Parliament where there is any right for proper debate? The Democrats are not prepared to allow us that opportunity. Why? It gets back to the fact that I suspect that this Government actually does not want this Bill to pass. Its dream is that this Bill will be defeated and that it will be able to blame us—straightforward political motives. There is no interest in the people of Tasmania; no interest in the development of resources in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be explaining why you seek the suspension of Standing Orders.

—I remind Senator West that there has not been a major development approved in this country in the last five years. Those opposite do not want that to change. They do not want the development of forests consistent with proper environmental standards. It is the same as all of those other debates. They do not want the development of Coronation Hill, they do not want the development of uranium mines and they do not want development in this country. They want this Bill to fail but Mr Keating and the others who make decisions for them want to be able to blame us.We have taken a consistent position and—
—Why should we suspend Standing Orders?
—Order! Senator West.

—We have taken a consistent and principled position in relation to this legislation from the start. We support the development of a mill in Tasmania. We support proper, reasonable legislation. But we have said from the start that this legislation is fundamentally flawed. You will remember, Mr Chairman, that when the Bill was debated in the other place, we said that what was necessary was for the Bill to be withdrawn and then redrawn in order that small industries can be incorporated and given proper protection, there can be proper project protection and so forth. The Government would not accept that very reasonable suggestion.

PARA.TAB: When the Bill got to this end of the building and went before a committee, we went one step further and drew the amendments for the Government ourselves. We put each of those detailed amendments during the committee hearing. As I said, the industry and practically every party who appeared before that Committee supported what we were doing, but the Government would not accept it. It said, no, it was not prepared to accept that reasonable compromise.

So we came back again with yet another compromise and that is the compromise we are talking about tonight which was put first by NAFI to Minister Griffiths who picked it up. We helped the Minister draft it into the form of an agreement—an agreement which the Minister was prepared to support—but when it came to the crunch, Mr Keating was not. So for the third time, we looked for a way in which, consistent with principle, we could allow the passage of this Bill. We want resource security legislation and we want a development to go ahead in Tasmania, but this Government is not prepared to allow it to occur. I think that is appalling. Why can the matter not be debated out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, once again we have a perambulation of convenient reasoning around this chamber by Senator Hill under the guise of a cry from the heart that the Senate has not had enough time to debate this legislation. Anyone who has studied the record knows that the Senate has had more than enough time to debate this legislation. Let me remind the chamber what has happened.

PARA.TAB: We have had an exhaustive second reading debate. We have had a committee inquiry. All the issues were canvassed in that Committee, yet the Bill has been stalled for two hours and 52 minutes in the committee stage without even getting to the first clause of the Bill. The Government has pre-empted that process and broken the log-jam by moving the amendment that the Opposition had foreshadowed it would move, and by giving the undertakings that the Opposition claimed it needed.

One would have thought, in the normal course of events, that would have ended the matter. We would have been left with the opposition of the Australian Democrats—an honourable opposition throughout all this, I might say. We would have been left with that difference of principle and difference of argument. But we now find, despite the Government's moving to accommodate the position of the Opposition, that the Opposition position has changed. The closer we move, the further the Opposition backs away.

Senator Hill raised three arguments. His first argument was that we cannot debate the clauses in 90 minutes. I remind Senator Hill that that is 90 minutes plus two hours and 52 minutes that we have been debating the clauses, and in the two hours and 52 minutes in which we have not moved past clause 1, all of the amendments have been canvassed in one way or another—not necessarily in a very structured way, often in a very slipshod way, by the back bench of his Party in the contributions that they have made. They canvassed them as well in the legislation committee. So let us not have this false pretence that somehow the democratic process is being circumvented by a lack of time. That is a false argument.

The second argument that Senator Hill raised was that the Government does not want the development. I say again that the Government has moved the Opposition's amendment. We have given the Opposition the assurance that we want this development. It is the clear understanding of the Government that the Tasmanian Government also wants it. That is a Liberal government, and it wants it. If this is a States House and the interests of the States are to be considered here, then surely the cry of the Tasmanian Government needs to be considered. Not only that, but judging from the resolution of NAFI—the one I referred to before—it wants it. That is our understanding of NAFI's position. If those opposite have a different understanding of NAFI's position, perhaps they had better tell me I am wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —NAFI has said support the amendments, right!
—Is that what NAFI said?
—Yes.
—NAFI said support the amendments, did it? Is that what NAFI said?
—That is right, yes.
—That is not what NAFI is telling the world in its own resolution. I suggest that the Opposition goes back to that organisation's resolutions, rather than what is necessarily conveyed to it.

PARA.TAB: Now I come to the third point: this continuing argument that the Opposition makes that somehow Minister Griffiths has reached an agreement. I am advised quite clearly that Minister Griffiths reached an agreement subject to—and always subject to—a decision by the Government; that he engaged in a discussion and canvassed different points of view and different considerations, but that he did so on the basis that he would take those back for consideration by the Government for a united Government response. All of the crocodile tears that those opposite are crying about Minister Griffiths are in fact disingenuous. They are meant to undermine him. They are meant to pretend that he has somehow done something that he has not done. He has not reached an agreement. He said he would refer those matters back for a Government response, which is what the Government has done.
Finally, I go to the editorial in the Hobart Mercury of Friday, 1 May—May Day. It was mayday for Opposition senators in Tasmania. The editorial said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania's Liberal Senators should have their pens ready to fill out their application forms to join the state's Green Independents.

PARA.TAB: For unless there is major change of attitude, they will join the Greens in having killed off a pulp mill planned for Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not the Government speaking. This is not a partisan point of view. This is the independent commentators in the press. I know that now the press disagree with the Opposition, they are called the gutter press. I have heard those words uttered. This editorial shows how the press see the actions of the Opposition. I again say to the Opposition, `Why do you not just change your position and vote for the legislation?' (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Giles)—I call Senator Coulter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut it out! He has had a go beforehand. I have been trying to jump up here and you have not given us a go. For crying out loud!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will only speak for a few moments and I wish to make only two points. Again the implication has emerged in this debate tonight from both the Government and the Opposition that if this legislation is passed, either with or without amendments—and both forms have been put—somehow or other a pulp mill will miraculously appear in northern Tasmania. It is on the record that no guarantee exists for a pulp mill to be built with or without any amendment, and that needs to be made absolutely clear.

PARA.TAB: To bring this issue right up to the minute, the second point I wish to make is that the following statement appears in this evening's AAP:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal coalition tonight decided to scorn the Government's latest compromise on resource security legislation and vote against the Bill when it came up in the Senate later tonight. Mr Lloyd said the Opposition would vote against it unless it was accompanied by a five point agreement thrashed out by resources Minister, Alan Griffiths, last week or the Opposition amendments which failed to get past the Senate Standing Committee.
It then goes on to say:
The move signals the final death knell for the Bill.

Any journalist out there can read the signs. What we are doing here brings this chamber into disrepute. The Opposition has made its position clear and the Government has made its position clear. To continue to waste time in apparent debate—and I stress the word `apparent'—when really all that is going on is shadow-boxing, brings this chamber into disrepute. For that reason I believe it is absolutely appropriate to set a time limit. Ninety minutes is more than enough to deal with the 17 amendments that the Opposition wants to put, considering the number of times they have been debated already. Therefore, the Democrats will be supporting that 90-minute limit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important Bill. Nobody is denying that it is an important Bill. Because it is such an important Bill, we believe it deserves proper attention. The Government will try to suggest that the Opposition is filibustering, ably helped by Senator Coulter, who is more than using up his own entitlement to time on this legislation. He does not have much to say, but he is perfectly prepared to say it.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the chamber believe that it is very important to get this right. We have tried for months to do something about this legislation. We are continuing to the death knell to try to get it right. We still believe that people on the Government benches would dearly like the opportunity to get it right, too, but they have been silenced by this deal between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Left faction of the Party which put him into the Lodge.

The Opposition has 17 amendments and has struggled over months to try to get those amendments accepted. They were accepted by the industry, but not by the Labor Party. Eventually, we were persuaded to accept an agreement negotiated by the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, with the industry. After Easter, on his initiative, the industry met with the Minister and settled on an agreement after a couple of days of negotiation. That was then brought in writing to the Opposition to see whether we would give it in-principle support, and we did so.

Is anybody in this country entitled to accept the word of a Federal Minister? It is a pretty serious question that goes far beyond this Bill. It is not just a question of resources security legislation; it is a question totally of the credibility of this Government and the ability of any one of its frontbenchers to negotiate with credibility on behalf of the Government. The industry understood that when it was negotiating with the Minister, he was operating within the parameters of his own portfolio and was entitled to conclude those negotiations with it.

The Minister had the rug pulled out from under his feet and we find that the Government is now rushing to dispose of this legislation before Caucus has a chance to express its view. On Friday on the ABC news the member for Eden Monaro, Mr Snow, said there were two groups who mucked up this legislation; one was the left wing of his Party and the other was the executive of his Party, which would not take the legislation back to Caucus. Obviously, Mr Snow would like to have got it back to Caucus.

What about Senator Sherry, who has been making kind and consoling noises to the industry? I have the distinct impression that Senator Sherry would like to have that legislation taken back to Caucus too, but he seems to be either ineffectual or silenced. What is it with Senator Sherry? We know that the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, Mr Field, also wanted it to go to Caucus. Perhaps it is Mr Field's evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs that really puts its finger on what is happening. He said in his evidence:

SPEECH.PARA: What I see is that the Left of the Labor Party has grave reservations about the principle of resource security, and there are some in the Right who think that it would be politically expedient if it did not succeed.
The evidence of Mr Field to the Committee was several weeks ago. Clearly he was right; he could see what was happening. Mr Keating had a deal with the Left even then.

PARA.TAB: One has to ask: why is the Government so afraid of its own Caucus? Let us not misunderstand what happened to this agreement. The agreement between the Minister and the industry was not just on a change to the title of the Bill. It also included an agreement that he would monitor its effectiveness together with industry and trade unions; that he would develop the concept to cover regional agreements and smaller industry players not included by the $100m plus projects; and that he would develop a national forest strategy. That was the agreement that we were prepared to support, not just a change of title to this legislation.

Let us be quite clear: when the Government is prepared only to go down the line of changing the title to the Bill, we believe all bets are off. If the Government is not prepared to stand by Mr Griffiths' agreement, we want our amendments to this legislation. Why is it that we cannot get this through? The Australian Democrats are ready to agree that the Bill is urgent. They do not support the forest industry; they would not want to see a pulp mill in Tasmania, as we do; and they do not want this Government to take this Bill to the Caucus. We have taken a very consistent line on this legislation. We have been prepared all along the way to try to find a solution to this legislation. The Minister has been dumped and now the industry will pay the price. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time that I have spoken on this matter.
