I regard the comments that are being made around the chamber about the Forest Conservation and Development Bill having been thoroughly debated to such an extent that it should be declared urgent and that the committee stage should now be truncated to 90 minutes as a denial of the rights of those senators who have not yet spoken on the matter. We have attempted to listen so far as we can to the debate. I have observed what has been said in the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs that considered this Bill. If one has a look at that report, one will note that this Bill seems to be a most extraordinary creature because all of the major players—the unions and the industry—desire to see amendments to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances, it seems to me that it is extraordinary to declare this Bill urgent and, in particular, to truncate the committee stage so as to prevent a proper explanation being given by the movers of the amendments for the reasons that those amendments ought to be carried. I will not go through them, because I think that might border on being contrary to Standing Orders, but in fairness we ought to debate the amendments in the committee stage. I would like to hear some debate across the chamber. I would like to hear in detail from the Government why it opposes these amendments.

I have a feeling that, in the long run, the Democrats want to see this Bill not so much declared one of urgency as one doomed urgently. That, I think, is the distinction. I am very disturbed, frankly, that the Democrats have again sided with the Government to support the guillotine. It is an extraordinary situation. We have had the Government and the Democrats saying, `The fate of this Bill is known'. How do they know that? There may be people from the Opposition who will in the end join in voting for the Bill. How do they know that it is doomed?

The Democrats want this Bill doomed. That is why they are supporting the Government in these procedural motions. But, if the Government suspects that there is any chance at all of this legislation being supported, what it ought to do is withdraw the Bill; not to make it one of urgency in the full knowledge that it will be doomed tonight. I say to Senator Cook that we are at a threshold point. In Senator Cook's negotiations, as in my union negotiations, he should be backing off or withdrawing at this point in time to allow things to settle down.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have for the last three weeks.

—But there is a bit more to go yet, and Senator Sherry knows that as well as I do. If this Bill were given a further chance by the Government proceeding as it decided to proceed this morning—that is to say, have it down to the last matter, which has an ice-cream's chance in hell of getting up today, anyhow—it could have been debated tomorrow afternoon. Of course, we are past that now, but I believe that we ought now at least to do the decent thing and allow the committee stage of the Bill to proceed uninterrupted. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose very strongly the placing of a guillotine on the debate on this piece of legislation, the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. As I have said previously, this is one of the most important pieces of legislation to come before this chamber in a long time. Its ramifications extend far beyond just the forestry industry. Getting this right is essential to resource security across a large range of industries.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal first of all with the comments that have been made by the Democrats. Very simply, their position is not about getting the legislation right; it is about their own political agenda—nothing else. Senator Coulter would do himself a favour if he were to stand up and be honest about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been.

—No, they have not been honest about that. They have said consistently here, `It should be got on with because of the position that we're in'. It has nothing to do with the legislation; it is about their public agenda—and Senator Sherry knows that.

PARA.TAB: I now want to deal with the Government's position. I particularly want to address the point that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) raised when he asked where NAFI stood. Senator Sherry was sitting in at the hearings when NAFI spelt out its position clearly. Its President, Mr Don McFarlane, said, `We support the amended legislation and we do not support the unamended legislation'. What the Government is doing, in terms of the position it has adopted, is preventing—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not right.
—That is what he said. It is there in the evidence and it is in Hansard. Senator Sherry knows that is the position.
—That is not right.
—It is. It is there.
—You are selectively quoting.

—I am not selectively quoting. That is what he said, and Senator Sherry knows it. I will move on. Senator Sherry can misrepresent the position as much as he likes, but that is what he said. He should go back and read it.

PARA.TAB: Let us now look a little further. Another reason the Government wants this guillotine is to take the heat off itself from its own people in the ACTU. It wants to take the heat off itself from the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union. I support very strongly the comments made by Senator Harradine in that regard. What did the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union say? In a letter to Mr Richardson, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . desires that the ACTU represents this organisation at the above enquiry on the basis that the existing legislation be amended to include:
(a)Resource Security based on regional forest management plans . . .
(b)Resource compensation in the event of future resource withdrawal for conservation reasons
(c)Enhanced inter-governmental agreement supported by legislation.
I emphasise the next point, which members of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs sitting on the other side heard:
Anything short of these amendments will severely injure the potential for the value-added development of Australia's sawmilling industry.
As we go through this document we find the same position adopted by the State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't support the ACTU all the time.

—Nobody is suggesting that the honourable senator does, or that he should. He is denying their right to have the position that they put properly debated in this place. That is what the honourable senator is doing. It is an infringement on their rights, the rights of NAFI and the rights and positions of the State Premiers. In Western Australia, this legislation will do little for all the sawmillers and the people in the industry. The honourable senator knows that. The position here is absolutely untenable.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely untenable that the Minister at the table should be restricting the debate on this matter, one of the most important pieces of legislation before us. It is done for the wrong reasons and he should hang his head in shame.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to speak briefly in support of Senator Harradine, because Senator Harradine is quite right. The Labor Party is playing politics here in a very sordid and underhand way. The Democrats want this Bill defeated and they want it defeated urgently. The Labor Party must want the same objective; it must want this Bill defeated and defeated quickly. If the Labor Party did not want the Bill defeated, it would not provide the vehicle for the Democrats to achieve their aim. This chamber should be—
—We are voting for it. Are you going to do that?

—Yes, but if Senator Sherry were not so impetuous with his tongue, if by accident he listened instead of talking—which would be a radical change in his behaviour; I am not sure, even if he did listen, that he has any neuronal equipment to assess the input from his auditory nerves—he would realise that I am telling him that his people want this Bill defeated. So stop being hypocritical and go down that path!

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Giles)—Order! The time for the debate has expired.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Jones did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Olsen).

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to make the last of my comments. The procedural options are starting to run out, which is regrettable because debate on the substantive motion will be unreasonably curtailed. When that occurs in the Senate it is a sorry day, yet it seems to be occurring regularly now with this Government with the support of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: I take up the point that was made by both Senator Newman and Senator Harradine. I must say that, as an outsider, I nevertheless have looked at this legislation, travelled down to Tasmania, visited APPM and talked to Tasmanians. I find it very difficult to understand why the Government has not been prepared to accept the very reasonable amendments that have been put as a compromise at each of the stages. Why was the Government, in the first instance, not prepared to withdraw the Forest Conservation and Development Bill and redraft it in a way that was requested and would meet the requirements of small industry and enable it to be incorporated within regional plans so that one would not have to have a duplication of environmental protection? That is not in any way reducing the environmental standards. Why would the Government not accept a responsibility to do that in order that a Bill might be passed and a Bill might maximise the opportunity of development in a State such as Tasmania, but yet development that is environmentally satisfactory? That was difficult to understand.

Of course, we appreciate that governments do not like to be told how to do things, and perhaps the Government was simply being obstinate. But in the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, when the amendments were put by the Opposition in detail accepting and developing this Bill as a project specific Bill but additionally providing for the sanctioning of regional plans that had gone through the State Government processes and protection assessments, why would the Government not accept those very reasonable amendments when practically every witness, perhaps with the exception of the now Tasmanian Opposition, supported them?

As I said, I read the Committee report. The union leaders came along and supported what the Opposition was putting before the Committee, and the industry came along and supported it. Even APPM said that it would support it, although it will live with the Bill in any event. It understood the merit of the amendments that were being put. Why was the Government not prepared to act reasonably in that regard? Unless it is as I suspect—and I put this some little time ago—that really the Government does not want the Bill to pass but wants to be able to blame us for it, I cannot see any logical reason for the position that it has taken.

From the start we have said that we want the Bill; we are prepared to compromise; but we are not prepared to vote for a fundamentally flawed piece of legislation. We want the Government to come to the party, as it is prepared to do in so many instances in this chamber, through the Committee process, which facilitates the development of a piece of legislation that is basically satisfactory. Why is this Bill an exception? Why does it have to be dealt with differently if there is not an element of political expediency?

Even so, when the Government refused the amendments that had been worked up professionally for the Committee—and which I would have thought met any reasonable standard—we still went out searching for a compromise that would allow us to get the Bill into a reasonably satisfactory form that we could support. As a result of discussions, a whole series of appointments were set up.

On the first Monday back here after Easter the industry came to Canberra to talk to Minister Griffiths, as did APPM and the Tasmanian Government. The Minister at last said that he was prepared to talk to us about the matter. We on this side of the chamber were saying that, with all that goodwill, there must be a way to put this Bill in a satisfactory form that both sides of the chamber can support.

With the Government saying that it was not prepared to legislate for regional plans, the breakthrough seemed to come with the letter from NAFI—the National Association of Forest Industries Ltd—to the Minister dated 23 April 1992. It put two alternatives. One alternative was the amendments that had been put in the Standing Committee, which the Government said it would not accept. It put the other alternative in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: request the Government to retitle the Bill for major forest projects and agree to pursue resource security for the rest of the industry in the context of the RAC recommendations—
I remind the Senate that the RAC had by that time put down its report, which also supported the Opposition's and the industry's amendments put before the Committee—
and the National Forest Strategy.

In other words, the Bill would become major projects legislation. Government would be requested to agree to continue negotiations with the industry on resource security on the basis of regional assessments backed by legislation in the context of developing the National Forest Strategy.

NAFI was saying to the Government, `If you will not agree to legislate for the regional plans, at least agree to pursue the negotiating process that ultimately will give protection for regional development plans and, therefore, for the small players within the industry'. NAFI said, `If you are not prepared to legislate, let us accept this Bill as project specific, make it a little more certain in that regard, but agree to the regional plan in accordance with your own developing national forest strategy', which is the Government's strategy in accordance with its RAC committee. How would that be unreasonable? As has been said, Minister Griffiths accepted that that was a reasonable compromise which would allow both sides of the chamber to vote for a package.

PARA.TAB: As a result of that, the relevant spokesmen got together to fill out the package and put it in a form that could become an agreement. That is the form of agreement that Mr Griffiths was prepared to stand by and the one by which the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, ultimately pulled the rug from under his feet.

What is that agreement? As has been said earlier tonight, it is in five parts. Basically, there are three parts of substance. The first is to change the title of the Bill so that it is more specifically project orientated. There was no problem with that. The next two parts of that agreement, parts three and four, flesh out this concept of proceeding with negotiations to develop regional plans. It was put in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: .agree to consult with industry concerning the development of the concept of enhanced inter-governmental agreements designed to provide resource security on a regional basis for those forestry industry investments which would not otherwise qualify under the Forest Conservation and Major Projects legislation.

What could be unreasonable about that? The plan was to agree to consult with industry concerning the development of the concept of enhanced intergovernmental agreements designed to provide resource security on a regional basis for forest industries that will not come within that Bill. How could anyone knock that? How could one argue against that? Secondly, it states:

.agree to ongoing discussions with industry and trade unions regarding the provision of certainty and security for investment related wood supplies in the context of reviewing ESD, National Plantations Advisory Committee and RAC recommendations prior to developing the National Forest Strategy.

So it will negotiate with these very relevant bodies in the development of this strategy. How could that be unreasonable? That is really the nub of what this Government has now reneged upon. The other parts of the agreement involve undertaking to continue to review its effectiveness. The Government has already said it is prepared to do that—it said it in here again tonight—and, lastly, to announce these commitments, which is an incidental matter that follows.

PARA.TAB: Apparently, the Government is really bucking at the two clauses in this agreement that would require it to continue to negotiate on regional plans consistent with its own forestry strategies and to take into account the views of the relevant industries. How could this Government object to, and refuse, that part of this agreement? Basically, Mr Keating pulled the rug from under the Minister in relation to that part. It does not make any sense at all—unless the Government does not want a fair compromise but simply wants the Bill to fail and to be able to blame us. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that 90 minutes be the time allotted for consideration of the remaining stages of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. I gave considerable leeway to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), which is not unusual; but I remind any other speakers to this motion that the question is why or why not it should be 90 minutes. I ask honourable senators to keep their remarks to that question.

—The Government has decided once again to gag a most important piece of legislation. I do not know whether the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who represents Tasmania, agrees with this. I have no idea, because he has not spoken at all in this debate. I would be most interested if the Minister was to get to his feet this morning and say whether he believed that this legislation that is so important to his State ought to be gagged and whether the gagged debate ought to be for 90 minutes. We have not started the committee stage yet; we have not even passed clause 1. I would be most interested if the Minister, instead of just reading the Sydney Morning Herald throughout this important debate, were to get up and say whether he believed that his Government should gag this debate.

PARA.TAB: He knows how important this legislation is to our State. He knows that the whole of the north-west coast is relying on the building of a pulp mill in that area. He knows that his Government, through the recession we `had to have' which was engineered by his Government, has done disastrous things to the north-west coast. He knows also that Senator Richardson, just for a handful of votes from the greenies' preferences, destroyed the chance of a pulp mill on the north-west coast when the proposal was first put up. But we do not hear one word about resource security from the Minister, who is the only Minister representing Tasmania. That cannot help making every Tasmanian wonder why, because surely he has an interest in the subject. As I have already said, I would be interested in his views. I wonder whether we will hear from the Minister tonight.

I also wonder whether Senator Devereux will come in here and say that he believes 90 minutes is plenty of time to debate this piece of legislation in Committee stage when the Opposition has 17 amendments. We have read a lot about Senator Devereux back home deciding that the Left of the Labor Party and the Greens ought to be closer together. We have heard a lot back home about his reinstating the feeling between the Left and the greenies and his remarks that they should get together.

Surely Senator Devereux wants more than 90 minutes to debate this Bill in the Committee stage because he did not say one word during the second reading stage of the debate, nor did Senator Tate. So surely those two Tasmanians will want more than 90 minutes to voice their views. Senator Sherry at least had the decency to stand up here and put his views. He has agreed with us that the legislation is not perfect. He said publicly that he believes the Government ought to get together with the Opposition and pass the Bill through this place. It will take more than 90 minutes to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wants to take it to Caucus tomorrow.

—Yes, Senator Sherry wants to take the Bill to Caucus tomorrow. If we cut off the debate after 90 minutes, what chance will there be for it to go back to Caucus tomorrow? Quite frankly, there is Buckley's chance of that happening—in other words, no chance. Why is it that we are being given only 90 minutes to pass the Bill?

PARA.TAB: Mr Field, the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, made it very clear in the evidence he gave to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs that the Bill cannot go back to Caucus because the whole thing is a factional debate. It is a factional problem for the Labor Party—nothing more, nothing less. Mr Field said that the Left has always been opposed to this legislation and some of the Right are now becoming divided on it. So the Government will not be willing to take the Opposition amendments back to Caucus, and he told us we could be assured that it was nothing more than a factional fight.

What a tragedy it is that, because of a factional fight in the Labor Party, we are allowed only 90 minutes. We have 90 minutes in which the Government can change its mind and give Tasmania a mill that it desperately needs. It is a mill that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, who now sits at the table, knows our State desperately needs. I do not believe that 90 minutes is long enough to debate a Bill such as this—not when there are 17 amendments to be put by us alone. The Government has its own amendment and that will probably be the first one to come up.

If we are not permitted to debate in this place in a reasonable fashion the legislation that is presently before us that so vitally concerns investment in this country, then do not tell me that we are living in a democracy. I say that this is true Labor Party democracy. How many times have I spoken about the particular brand of democracy that the Labor Party has—the show and tell brand? Labor Party members when they vote do not trust each other, so they have to show their own faction which way they have voted. That is exactly what is occurring in this legislation. The factional deals are ruining a perfectly good piece of investment that APPM tells us it wants. I object very strongly to yet another guillotine being placed on legislation that I consider so important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The imposition of a 90-minute debate for the committee stage of this legislation is absolutely ridiculous. Many issues that have been raised so far in the discussion have highlighted this fact.

PARA.TAB: Probably the best speech that has been made so far this evening on this issue has been by Senator Harradine, who brought out many salient points with regard to the necessity for a comprehensive, ungagged debate, and the fact that we have to come in here and be subjected to the gag by the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party, which have obviously different motives and different reasons as to why they suddenly want to constrain the debate completely.

It has come to our attention that what is going on is just political football because of the deals that are being done outside this Parliament between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), Mrs Kelly, Mr Toyne, Senator Richardson, the Greens and all the rest of them. It is just the ALP playing its usual games of cheap politics and trying to predict and control what is going on at all times.

Senator Cook, who represents the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) in this chamber, came in here this evening and foreshadowed the amendment he proposes to clause 1, which we have not yet debated fully. It is very interesting that in the debate in this place this evening, when we started to talk about clause 1, Senator Cook took the lead. He was quickly followed by Senator Coulter. We then went through the charade of formal motions.

As the shadow Minister responsible for primary industry legislation in this chamber, with a proper stance and policy view to put and response to make to the amendment proposed by Senator Cook, I was not given the same opportunity to participate in the full debate in the proper way before the gag was put, because of the torpedoing tactic of the Labor Party to come in and score points and get even and constrain the debate in whichever way it wanted to go.

I pay credit to the Resources Minister, Mr Griffiths, who obviously wanted to negotiate a proper agreement a week or so ago. He was approaching the Opposition, the industry groups and everyone else with substance. But what have we seen? The usual tawdry party-political Labor Party politics that this Prime Minister is so intent on carrying out. It is not back to the genuine issues of resource security, of jobs for Australians throughout Australia and, in particular, the project rich areas that ought to be sustained by this legislation. We have gone through a comprehensive series of stages in attempting to get good legislation on the books. Now this Government wants to deal with it in 90 minutes.

There were two sets of amendments. This debate, on clause 1 and the title, is linked only to the issue of the agreements that we wanted put in place and that Minister Griffiths agreed to give. That was a narrowing of the options in order to achieve the success of the appropriate way of getting, in particular, a project in northern Tasmania off the ground.

We presented a broader option in the second reading debate and canvassed it, with the circulation of a series of 17 amendments. If the Government was not going to go down the track that Minister Griffiths intended to take it, there would need to be full consideration of the 17 amendments. In 90 minutes tonight there is no way this Senate can give due and proper regard to those 17 amendments, which are so fundamental and will require particular attention.

I hope you noted, Mr Chairman, that when Senator Cook started his comments tonight he said, `I'll be prepared to go along with a certain commitment, with a certain statement'. It was similar to what Minister Griffiths said in the House of Representatives on 30 April last week. He said, `I'll say this and I'll say that and then I'll incorporate it in the third reading stage of the Bill where it can be properly facilitated and the Acts Interpretation Act can interpret that'. In a very cheap and nasty little dig, Senator Cook went on to say, `If I don't get the opportunity in the third reading speech'. That was before he even came in with any of these formal motions to bastardise this legislation in this place this evening. He already intended to put on the table this proposal to cut off the debate and bring in the 90-minute time limit.

Then Senator Cook played the cheap tactic of trying to put an industry organisation, NAFI, on the record with a letter of 18 February—before this chamber sent off the 17 circulated amendments to the Senate Standing Committee for proper consideration. We have to give regard to the Senate Standing Committee's report and we should give full regard to the dissenting report to that very important report. It was really carried on party political lines. The vote was three-all and the casting vote of the Chairman took it out. We do need to look at that report again.

As I said, in this place tonight Senator Cook resorted to a letter that was part of earlier considerations on 18 February. He did not refer to the letter that Senator Hill mentioned in this debate—the letter of 23 April from NAFI—which went into a whole range of things. It was a letter to the Minister, Mr Griffiths, on that particular date setting out a new track. What about the press statement of NAFI?

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate it.
—It has already been incorporated; I do not need to do it again. NAFI issued a press release yesterday, 3 May, entitled, `Labor left must answer to workers', which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The future of Australia's forest industries rests tomorrow on whether the left wing faction of the ALP will honour the agreement on resource security, sought and reached by their own government, the Executive Director of the National Association of Forest Industries, Dr Robert Bain, said today.

There was no reference to this from Minister Cook; no reference whatsoever that he is up-to-date, across the issues or consulting with the appropriate organisations. If he cannot get himself up-to-date in nine weeks, how the heck does he expect the Senate to get itself up-to-date and properly involved in this debate in 90 minutes tonight? The way in which the Government is treating this legislation is a joke.

PARA.TAB: I can assure the Minister that I have a statement to make this evening about the Opposition's policy position on where the Government has reached today. I have not yet had the opportunity to make that statement. When we get back to clause 1, I want to make that statement on behalf of the Opposition because it is a considered, detailed statement that certainly recognises that the most important issues we should be addressing are jobs for Australians, support for the industry base and proper legislation that is not so fundamentally flawed.

We have a priority to see that people are put back to work, not resorting to these cheap politics of predicting what the motives and the actions are of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, Mrs Kelly, Senator Bolkus and the other bundle of lefties who now obviously have the Labor Party in their tight control. This Government is divided. It cannot face up to a Caucus meeting tomorrow that in any way will allow a debate that will reflect on the credibility of the Prime Minister. It is the Prime Minister's credibility that is at stake. He made a wrong decision, he backed the wrong horse and he has been called up by Mrs Kelly who has said, `Hey, buster, you got my vote for the leadership; it's time to pay'. If that is the sort of government this country has—

TALK.START.PARA: —With interest.

—As Senator Schacht has just interjected, with interest. It is obvious that his factional mate, Mrs Kelly, is calling the tune, certainly with interest. There is just so much interest that has had to be paid on this particular issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to speak on the question of the 90-minute debate. I am disappointed because last time I was on my feet I raised some questions with the Minister at the table at the time, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who not only did not answer them but is no longer at the table. I have given him time to take advice on the answers to these questions, I feel sure.

PARA.TAB: The reason that we have this problem tonight is twofold. Senator Button, acting under the most extraordinary arrangements or instructions that we could imagine, picked today to open up a wide and hairy debate on pecuniary interests in a rough and rambling way, as such debates are always conducted, and as he knows they always have been. He then proceeded to wonder why it did not go according to his little plan, which was to have about one speaker and then conclude it—again in good Labor Party form. But all it really showed was that it was more important to get up another of these sideline issues, distraction issues, so that we can fly this pink flag with bananas or something like that on it, I suppose. Some sort of a crazy flag is exactly the same thing.

Because we went on with that for some considerable time, we now have the guillotine applied to important business. We have to get it through tonight because of that, and tomorrow being Caucus meeting day, it has to be over before that too because the Government cannot allow the members the opportunity to talk at a Caucus meeting, as that has already been determined.

I do not know why it is that the Government members seem to be satisfied with their restrictions on discussions on matters such as this, but out there in the real world I think we will find that there are a lot of people who want a lot more discussion on the actions of the Government in this particular instance. It is a most extraordinary state of affairs, and I really fail to understand what it is that has the Government so determined not to even consider doing something that is sensible.

The best summary that I have seen of the situation was probably the editorial in today's Burnie Advocate. This is the paper that covers the area which is primarily in the firing line when it comes to the pulp mill question. I will quote just two parts of it. One part says:

SPEECH.PARA: The bottom line is that although the Bill would pave the way for a Tasmanian pulp mill by guaranteeing North Broken Hill-Peko a wood supply, it is flawed. It is discriminatory. It does not protect the interests of the forest industry's smaller players, such as sawmills.
The article continues:

There needs, in effect, to be two bills—one for North Broken Hill and others in the same league and one for the smaller players. It will remain the hope of many pulp mill supporters in Tasmania that if the Forest Conservation and Development Bill collapses, North Broken Hill's plans will not come down with it. The chief executive of NBH subsidiary APPM, Mr Bill Paisley, has said that the Bill's defeat would not doom the mill so long as an alternative means of providing resource security took its place.

Given the economic issues at stake, it is amazing that Federal resource security should have become such a battleground. But it's not as though the Bill's only critics exist in Opposition and Democrat ranks with political axes to grind. The forest industry also wants it improved. And the Resource Assessment Commission's forest and timber industry inquiry found it largely irrelevant to the industry, and recommended it be replaced by something better.
I offer the Government that piece of good advice from a very independent source. The article finishes by saying:
For the sake of all concerned, that is what should happen.

What should happen is that there should be a re-think on this matter. We cannot do that in 90 minutes. We have no hope of doing it in 90 minutes if we just batter it around, trying to get it through as fast as we can without the opportunity for proper debate. I am fortunate in having had the weekend to re-read much of the information that has come forward. There is not one redeeming feature about the legislation as it stands. There is not one thing that could not and should not be improved. I do not know who produced it, but if it was the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, it certainly does not do her any credit to say so. If she did not do it, then she should immediately discharge whoever it was that did do it. It is bad and it is ineffective. It cannot do what it says that it is supposed to do, and it will not, because there is no goodwill and no bona fides on the part of the Government.

PARA.TAB: We have demonstrated this over and over again. We have read into Hansard the comments of all the industry people connected with it. Every one of them has had his say; every one of them has come up with the same conclusion that this is a rotten piece of legislation. There is no way that we can support it—no way at all. We have been looking for ways around it. We have been looking for possible alternatives, but at this stage, to go through the clauses in 90 minutes, I regret to say that it will not be possible to reach a satisfactory conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators have been protesting their concern regarding the 90-minute limit to the debate. I wish to express my reasons for supporting it. I see it as a very serious matter. I am a patient person and I would not support it without significant justification.

PARA.TAB: In his last speech Senator Hill was asserting the reasonableness of the Opposition's amendments to this legislation. He asked, `How can the Government refuse such reasonable amendments?'. As someone who has listened attentively to the entire debate, I have not heard the Opposition put even one of its amendments during the debate, yet Senator Hill insists that the Government has refused them. If the refusal of which he speaks simply applies to deals outside this chamber, he demonstrates how futile and cynical anything is that has been said or would be said in this chamber, and there is therefore no need to extend the time for debating it. That is my first reason for supporting the 90-minute time limit.

If Senator Hill acknowledges any validity at all to committee discussion of each clause, and if he genuinely believes in the importance of the amendments, as he has so often emphasised, why does the Opposition not get on with it, present those amendments and speak to them? Why has it not bothered to do so up to this time?

I have strong feelings about this legislation. I am opposed to it and have expressed my views in my speech in the second reading debate. I was more than happy to continue debating it clause by clause, but there was nothing to debate. No attempt was made to utilise the Committee's time effectively. That is why I support a time limit. I am prepared to accept the vote of the Committee, even if it goes against my personal beliefs and those of the people who support me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have no option.

—It is true that I have no option. It appears to me that the Opposition is not prepared to accept any position but its own; that it is prepared to stall indefinitely to achieve its own ends. Therefore, my second reason for supporting the 90-minute time limit is that the Opposition senators have failed to demonstrate any sincerity in their attempt to debate this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating whether in the committee stage we should debate the amendments and all the other aspects of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill for 90 minutes or whether we should have a decent debate on it for longer than that, as we normally do in the chamber—a good, complete and thorough debate on the issues that are brought up in the course of a Bill being discussed in this place.

PARA.TAB: Earlier tonight Senator Cook said that we had had more than enough time to debate this Bill. I would ask Senator Cook or anyone else in this place whether we should debate things right through in a proper way, not just, as is the case now, for 90 minutes. Why could we not have proceeded with this Bill as we have proceeded with so many other Bills in this place? Why could we not have a good and proper debate in order to arrive at some decent legislation at the end of the day? That has not come about at all. We are approaching the stage of a guillotine on this Bill.

We are debating the credibility of the Government in the way it is trying to slam this Bill through tonight. It is about the credibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and the credibility of all the evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. We are asking everyone to throw all that credibility out the window just because the Government is scared that if this legislation is allowed to go to the Caucus tomorrow it may be overturned.

Let us just look at the Prime Minister's credibility. Some time ago in the Australian newspaper Lenore Taylor made the point very clearly that Mr Keating, then the Treasurer, vehemently argued against the legislation at a Cabinet meeting. After he became Prime Minister, Mr Keating announced during the Tasmanian election campaign, where the State ALP supported the plan, that the previous Cabinet decision would stand. What sort of credibility does the Prime Minister have? He has changed his mind a couple of times.

We should have been able to debate, for much longer than 90 minutes, whether that was right, whether it was wrong, and all the other facets of what it was about. The Prime Minister has been against the legislation; he has been for it. However, I believe that his big mistake occurred when this legislation could have had the approval of everyone in this place, but when Mr Griffiths went to him he did not take the opportunity. Mr Keating was rolled by the left wing and by Minister Kelly. On that day as a Prime Minister he was left wanting.

We still want to discuss and to debate in this place for longer than 90 minutes submissions that were made or evidence that was given by Robert Richardson, the Industrial Officer of the ACTU, who attended our inquiry as a witness. He also represented the Combined Forestry and Mining Employees Union. In giving evidence, Mr Richardson summed up the view of probably everyone on all sides of the debate when he said:

Now in terms of the legislation, the ACTU and unions are really appealing to both sides of this debate in the Parliament—the Opposition and the Government—to get together and get a result. The ACTU wants a Bill, an Act. We want resource security. We do not want it to die because of lack of negotiation between the parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we want more than 90 minutes to debate this issue is exactly that. Here is the guy from the ACTU saying to the Government and to the Opposition, `Negotiate it through—let us try to get an agreement'.

PARA.TAB: We did have an agreement. Minister Griffiths, having taken his thoughts to the Opposition and the industry, had an agreement. Then he took the agreement to the Prime Minister and it failed. Where have the negotiations failed? Unfortunately, the negotiations have failed at the Prime Minister's door. The Prime Minister is the one who is responsible.

We should have had longer to discuss and ram through this legislation—not just 90 minutes, maybe ending at three o'clock in the morning—which has far-reaching consequences not just for Tasmania. This legislation has far-reaching consequences for the timber industry in my State of New South Wales. It is not getting resource security because of this legislation. I would have liked to make more than just a little speech talking about whether we have 90 minutes to debate the matter; I would have liked a decent time in the committee stage to really bring those points home.
In the evidence of Mr Richardson was a letter which was included in the submissions. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I confirm that CFMIEU-ATAIU Division desires that the ACTU represents this organisation at the above enquiry on the basis that the existing legislation be amended to include:
(a) Resource Security based on regional forest management plans supported by value adding investment proposals.
(b) Resource compensation in the event of future resource withdrawal for conservation reasons.
(c) enhanced inter-governmental agreement supported by legislation.
Anything short of these amendments will severely injure the potential for the value-added development of Australia's sawmilling industry.
Yours faithfully,
Chris Northover,
ASSISTANT FEDERAL SECRETARY
CFMIEU/ATAIU DIVISION

Could we not have had a little bit of time, longer than 90 minutes, to discuss whether that is right or wrong? There are many other people in this chamber who have not had a chance to speak. Senator Harradine, I thought, summed it up beautifully. He has had one chance of 10 minutes to speak on this debate of a Bill that really affects his State. In fact it is a Bill that affects more than just his State, as I have just said, and he has not been given that chance.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Labor senators have tried to suggest that the industry was divided on the Bill, yet we pointed out in our report that even the APPM director, William Paisley, admitted to the Committee that the legislation did not go as far as his company would like. In fact, he said in answer to a question from me:

SPEECH.PARA: So we are really saying to people that even as it stands the legislation will be satisfactory for us, but we freely admit it does not suit the rest of the industry.

Therefore, it was project specific. Why could we not have a decent amount of time to debate whether it is project specific or not? We believe that it is project specific. If the Government had said, `We will make this legislation project specific', we could have come to some sort of arrangement. That was really what the Griffiths agreement was all about. I believe that the Government stands condemned for not debating this right through, for not giving it a fair airing. If it had taken two or three days to achieve good resource security legislation, this country would have been thankful to everyone in this chamber. As it is, this Labor Government stands condemned because it would not negotiate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to oppose the guillotining of this Forest Conservation and Development Bill and the curtailing of the debate to 90 minutes, I want to deal with two aspects. The first point I make is the appropriateness of giving this Bill its full spectrum of debate. One has to make the point that this concept of a proposal for resource security is not something new; it has been around in public debate for years—at least five years and maybe longer. But it also raises the broader issue of when guillotines should be used. One has to first examine that to make a comment on this particular Bill.

PARA.TAB: A guillotine should be used only in certain circumstances, one being where there is a security risk. One has to ask whether there is a security risk. The answer is no. Is there a natural disaster such as a cyclone, a flood, a bushfire or an earthquake? The answer to that is no. Are people's lives at risk? The answer to that is no. So we go on down the list. Will States' rights be protected by the position that is being adopted with the 90-minute restriction? The answer to that has to be no. Will the people who were involved in giving evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs have their interests protected by restricting the debate? Will their interests be given a proper airing and proper consideration? The answer to that is no.

It is worth looking at the evidence and the information that was given to us on pages 71, 72 and 73 of Hansard where there were some 17 organisations listed on a document which I incorporated. It is very instructive to see what was said by organisations from all States. I look at the Victorian Forest Industries Association's letter to Mr Griffiths where it wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . strongly support a regional approach to the legislation. . . I find it distressing that it has not been possible, so far, to negotiate what seem to be fairly straight forward amendments that would satisfy all industry sectors and gain unanimous industry support.
Will their considerations be taken into account by applying the guillotine? The answer is no. The Western Australian Forest Industries Federation wrote to Premier Lawrence. The document stated:
The letter to the Premier says that without the amendments the legislation does not offer long term security or the confidence for industry to invest in projects throughout the south west.

I am referring here to my own State. Will applying the guillotine protect its interests and allow its position to be debated in this chamber? The answer is no. We then move to the Forest Protection Society of New South Wales. The document stated:
Australia's . . . tree plantation owners today joined calls for the Federal Government to adopt proposed amendments to its resource security legislation as a matter of urgency.

Will its point of view be debated properly in this chamber, and will its interests be put in the 17 amendments? The answer is no. We go on and look at what the Queensland Timber Boards Public Affairs Manager, Christine Bongers, said:
. . . the Federal Government's Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 was woefully inadequate.
Will its interests be taken into account? Will its interests be debated in this place? The answer is no. We then look at the Forest Protection Society of Western Australia—my State again—and it said:
The CALM/AHC agreement on forests will be strongly opposed if industry amendments are not included in Resource Security Legislation to be debated in the Federal Senate tomorrow.

Will its interests be taken into account? Will its position be debated? The answer is no. One can continue going through these. We look at some of the organisations that are directly involved. Ford Timber stated:
Ford Timbers, today urged Federal Parliament to approve amendments to its controversial Resource Security Legislation to ensure that the future of the forest industry is secure.
Hardys Tumbarumba said:
Hardys urge all sides of Federal Parliament to adopt the industry/Union amendments to the Federal Resources Security Legislation.

Will the interests of Hardys and Ford Timber be considered? Will they be properly debated? The answer is no. It is worth noting what Hardys had to say there. It urged `all sides of Federal Parliament'. We on this side of the chamber have said that we will take into consideration its point of view. We are prepared to support its particular position. If we go through the document, we see the various organisations, including the union movement—particularly Bob Richardson of the ACTU and the associated unions—involved which gave authority to Mr Richardson to represent them.

PARA.TAB: As one goes through this piece of legislation and, first of all, looks at the criteria of where the guillotine should be used, one sees that this legislation certainly does not fit into that criteria. It is not an issue of security, national disaster or the types of things that one would think the Federal Parliament would class as absolutely essential to be dealt with on the minute. That is not what this is about. Debate and consideration should be about looking at all aspects of the arguments put forward, the evidence given and the positions of the various people in the forestry industry. Because of this 90-minute restriction, consideration will not be given to these organisations' points of view, and there are 17 of them in the three pages of the Hansard report.

One has to ask the question: what is the motive behind the Government's move to guillotine this legislation? Its motive is quite clear. The Government's motive is to protect the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) from having to face a Caucus revolt and face up to the things that Senator Sherry raised today at the lunchtime meeting. It is about the man who stabbed Mr Hawke in the back. If the matter has to go back to Caucus, Caucus will debate it and, despite what has been said in this place tonight, the matter will be raised if it is not dealt with tonight. Of course, that will put people like Senator Richardson on very shaky ground, because he is the person who engineered the stabbing of Mr Hawke in the back.

One must comment on the support given by the Democrats to this legislation. Senator Harradine summed it up precisely when he said that this legislation was doomed tonight. It is most improper of this chamber to restrict debate on a piece of legislation which has been around for so long and has had so much public debate. However, when it comes to the crunch, the Government does not want to have all the arguments and positions put regarding the 17 amendments that the Opposition wants to put before this place. That shame will be on its head for a long time.

One cannot help wondering why the Democrats and the Left of the Labor Party do not get together and sit alongside one another. They are the real culprits in this debate. They are the ones who will doom it to failure and will stop proper resource security legislation in my State. I shall continue to remind the electors in Western Australia what they did and how they got in the way of the development of proper resource security legislation for the forest industries in Western Australia and the rest of Australia. My concern is for Western Australia in particular, and I will continue to put what they have done on the public record. It was the Government's stated intention that it would not support a sensible, rational, reasonable position as put by the people in the industry, and it also has put at risk the future of the AHC-CALM agreement which has been agreed to in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now 19 minutes past one and I appeal to the Government and to the Democrats to adjourn this debate until such time as we can discuss it properly tomorrow. We need 90 minutes, but we need 90 minutes of alertness. What they are denying to us is that opportunity to hear and consider the amendments put to us by the Opposition. That is fair, and it would be fair to understand the situation that we have now reached. I appeal to the Democrats and the Government to see that and ensure that this matter is discussed at a later hour of this day.

PARA.TAB: Original question put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
(Senator Jones did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Olsen)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the amendment to clause 1 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that we return to addressing the major issue as raised in clause 1 of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. The Opposition has consistently said that this legislation is fundamentally flawed, as a number of my colleagues have adequately demonstrated, in the process of this Senate in referring the matter to the Senate Standing Committee, where the evidence was overwhelmingly consistent with out view. In particular, I would refer the Government and the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) to the evidence given to the Standing Committee by the ACTU and the importance that the unions placed on the need for necessary amendment to the legislation. It is, therefore, hypocritical of the Government to come in here and argue at this stage that it cannot agree to those amendments.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal and National parties have offered to work with the Government and industry to produce a Bill which would give genuine resource security to the whole industry. This offer was never taken up by the Government. We then worked with industry to produce detailed amendments which provided for regional forest plans on a basis which protected environmental and all industry interests. We then had a Senate inquiry at which industry and union witnesses agreed that the legislation would be improved by our amendments. The Government has refused to entertain these amendments, despite support from industry and the trade union movement, as well as the Opposition.

We then took up in good faith a belated offer of discussions with the Government. The Minister for Resources offered the Opposition an amendment to the title of the Act, in similar terms to that which Senator Cook has presented here this evening, to demonstrate

SPEECH.PARA: that it applied only to large projects in the context of undertakings from the Government as follows—and there are the important principles that need to be committed and fully endorsed by the Government.

PARA.TAB: The first principle is an agreement to retitle the Bill the Forest Conservation and Major Projects Bill, and all provisions of the Bill would remain unchanged. The second principle is to undertake, monitor and review the effectiveness of the legislation to ensure that it achieves its objectives of certainty and security for the industry and generates value adding investment and jobs in the forest industries. If it can be demonstrated that the legislation has not achieved its objectives within a reasonable timeframe, the Government would, in consultation with industry, consider what action might be appropriate.

The third principle is to agree to consult industry and trade unions concerning the development of the concept of enhanced intergovernmental agreements designed to provide resource security on a regional basis for those forest industry investments which would not otherwise qualify under the forest conservation and major projects legislation. The fourth principle is to agree to ongoing discussions with industry and trade unions regarding the provision of certainty and security for investment related wood supplies in the context of reviewing ecologically sustainable development, national plantations advisory committee and RAC recommendations prior to developing the national forest strategy. The fifth principle is to announce these commitments in the resumption of the second reading debate in the Senate.

Today, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has introduced the retitling clause to the amendment but has not gone down the track of those five major agreements. The Minister referred to a statement by the Minister for Resources in the House of Representatives on 30 April. He picked up a few adjectives and phrases from those commitments but did not endorse them, did not fully accommodate them, did not recognise them, in a way which is satisfactory. Obviously, this is where the debate is now raging inside the Labor Party with respect to the commitment to those very important five principles that, importantly, the unions, the industry and anyone else connected with this legislation would want to see.

As we know from the media and events of recent days, the Government has reneged on Minister Griffiths's offer and made it quite clear that its agenda is to see the legislation defeated on the combined vote of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The Opposition has consistently expressed its support for genuine resource security and for a pulp mill in northern Tasmania, based on the resource identified by the Tasmanian forest plan. It is quite clear that the Government is simply playing politics with the whole issue at a time when—as a number of speakers have already mentioned—one million people are unemployed. The Government's only object is to try to show that its failure to create employment, by promoting value adding in the timber industry, is the fault of the Opposition.

The Government's having rejected our substantive amendments and having refused to give the undertakings offered by Alan Griffiths last week, the name change is meaningless. The Opposition is not interested in a cosmetic change. We have fought consistently for the 1,200 smaller saw mills around Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made it clear in Question Time today that he would do nothing to provide resource security for small saw mills and projects involving less than $100m.

When in government we will put in place genuine resource security legislation, based on approval of regional forest plans, which will provide resource security for large and small projects with the proper protection of both environmental and economic interests. I mention that the saga of events has been in the Senate, in the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, and in the various negotiations between people. We had hoped that those discussions had taken place in good faith.

Stage 1 of those discussions was obviously when we proposed to look at genuine umbrella legislation. We put forward 17 amendments that would go down the track in broadening the legislation and making it project specific, but we did not accept the shoddy legislation that the Government has had the audacity to put before the Parliament. In stage 2 of those discussions—when certainly there was a degree of compromise, goodwill and discussion between Mr Lloyd, Mr Griffiths and the industry representatives—an agreement was written. It was established; it was put down. I mentioned earlier the five very important fundamental points that were essential to undertaking this particular area. In that sense, we were prepared, and we indicated that very clearly.

Obviously, the Government is not serious. It has reached some sort of agreement with Mr Toyne and the ACF. Therefore, the issue unfortunately comes back to the internal politics within the Labor Party. It comes back time and again to why the Government is not prepared to give the undertakings and the full agreement that are so important to a company the name changed.

This whole debate, which now centres on clause 1, can be so simply accepted if the Government will give a commitment to endorse the full agreement that was struck between the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths; the National Association of Forest Industries; the Tasmanian Government; the Forest Industries Association of Tasmania; and the Forest Protection Society. That agreement, dated 28 April 1992, is what the Government has reneged on. That is the area where the Prime Minister and Mrs Kelly are obviously frightened, for political reasons, about moving and not backing up the proper and appropriate decisions. It is a challenge to this Government. I again throw that challenge to the Minister: give us that full agreement—that full commitment without equivocation, without amendment, without weaselling out of it, without trying to change it—and we will give you your amendment. Without that full and comprehensive agreement, there is no way that we can march down and accept.

There are many other areas that need to be put in place—areas of review for all of the smaller sawmillers, and work on better legislation. Certainly, in government, the Liberal and National parties would have an alternative proposal. We would have far better legislation in this specific area, but we have to live with the fact that the Government is only prepared to put on the table shoddy legislation, flawed legislation, dangerous legislation. There is an opportunity here for the Government on clause 1. We make our support for any amendment to clause 1 totally conditional. If the Minister cannot deliver in that particular area, it is a real pity for the industry. There will be other opportunities in the future, but it certainly compromises these major projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an extraordinary situation. It defies logic. If the scenario being played out in the Senate now was written as a novel, it would be pulped and remaindered because it would not be believable. Anyone who tried to script this would be laughed at. We have a situation here where the Government, in order to break the stand-off, has actually moved the amendment that the Opposition foreshadowed.
—Without the agreement.

—It is the Opposition's amendment on the first clause. We are dealing with the clauses seriatim, one after another, in the sequence in which they come up. This is the first one; it is clause 1. This is the amendment that Senator Tambling circulated in his name and foreshadowed, and we are moving it. The farce—the unbelievability of all of this—is that he is rejecting it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling is rejecting this amendment after making, may I say with the greatest respect to him, a sanctimonious speech about why he is entitled to reject the Opposition's own amendment. All I can imagine is that somewhere in the infantile mind of someone who is advising him in all this lurks the sneaking suspicion that the Opposition can pursue what is frequently styled in political debate as the salami approach: take one slice off and pocket that; push a bit harder, take another slice; and slice and slice until one finally gets one's desired position.

The Government has said that it has a responsibility to give long and strong and clear and open signals about where it is going. We have made a movement towards the Opposition's position. The next expectation on anyone's behalf would be that it would make one towards ours. But, instead, it moves further away. Every time we come closer to the Opposition, it backs away further. The stridency and sanctimoniousness of its position heightens the further it backs away from us as we come towards it.
A line has to be drawn somewhere. The line is that we have gone about as far as we can go. It is the sort of `everything is up to date in Kansas City' theme. We have gone about as far as we can go.

There is now a fundamental requirement on the Opposition to bend. I remind the Opposition that it really surpasses belief that it is dinkum. Senator Tambling could have said in three minutes that the Opposition was not going to accept our amendment and sat down. Then we could have all turned to the other 17 amendments that the Opposition wants to move. But he did not; Senator Tambling took all his time to make this sanctimonious speech.

If Senator Tambling were serious about the Senate dealing with the Opposition amendments and if he were serious about all the things that were said on his side a moment ago in the procedural debate as to whether 90 minutes was sufficient, he would have very quickly indicated his position, as is frequently done when we are all in a hurry to get through the committee stage of a Bill. We would have all flagged it, had a vote, determined that issue and gone on to the next matters. We could have had a longer debate about them than is now allowable because the Opposition has simply talked out time yet again. As I say, this must be a late hour of the day or an early hour of the morning because, if someone told me in the clear light of day that the Opposition was doing this, I would not have believed it.

Since the Opposition has made a number of remarks, I am bound, as the obligation rests on me, to answer them. This argument is now getting about as tired as that old joke about people in prison calling out the numbers of jokes and everyone laughing. This was because all the jokes had been told so many times that everyone knew what numbers they all were and people did not have to tell a joke any more; they just called out its number.

This matter is getting about as tired as that. I can say, `I am now going to use arguments 8, 14 and 27 and I am going to add arguments 6, 3 and 4 into it as well'. Everyone has heard all the arguments. It has now got to this position in which we are simply recycling them and citing them back. There is no effort here to meet the argument; there is only an effort to try to bypass it and dodge the point.

Firstly, in logical and sequential order, this amendment is the one the Opposition foreshadowed; we are dealing with this clause, and I have moved that amendment. The Opposition has foreshadowed that it will defeat it. What was the purpose in raising it in the first place? If the Opposition does not believe in it, why did it bother? Why did it bother to indicate that this was something that it wanted if it does not want us to pick it up?

Or is it that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Question Time today actually exposed the Opposition? When he was asked about this—I have not read the Hansard; I saw only a snatch of Question Time on television tonight—he said something like, `The funny thing about this is that we can actually amend the title to "major projects", but what the Opposition wants is all the minor projects'. If plain English is to mean anything, the title of a Bill ought to express what the Bill is about. The reason why we can move this title change is that the Bill is about major projects. If that accurately describes the Bill, this amendment should be carried.

The Opposition, however, does not want the Bill to be about these major projects, although it wants this title. It wants it to be about all the other projects as well. There is a complete answer to the question of the other projects which is a satisfactory, reasonable, moderate and convincing answer and is one that should be accepted by the Opposition. So with regard to the title, I simply say that it ought to express the type of Bill this is and name it accurately. This title does that. It is the Opposition's amendment in the first place, and those opposite should vote for it.

The second point is that in his speech Senator Tambling made the question of title dependent upon other assurances, which he read out. I have given the answer to that question before as well. I quoted a passage in Hansard of 30 April from the matter of public importance debate on the afternoon of last Thursday, during which the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) gave an undertaking to monitor, review and consult in the application of this legislation. He has said frequently what it means, what its purpose is and what it aims to do. He has said all of that and he has said, `I will monitor it to see whether it achieves this. If it doesn't, I will review it and I will consult with the various parties in that review to make sure that my objectives are met'.

Senator Tambling is saying that is not good enough. What is he calling Minister Griffiths, whom he has elevated—rightly, in my opinion—as a man of honour? And he is a man of honour. But the honourable senator cannot have it both ways; he cannot say out of one side of his mouth that the Minister is a man of honour, but out of the other say that he does not accept his assurances. The honourable senator cannot do both. Perhaps the Liberals can, I do not know; but normal people cannot.

The position is that the Minister has given a satisfactory assurance that he will meet the issues that the honourable senator has raised. The difference is that he has given a blanket assurance, and the honourable senator wants to enumerate the issues. Is that the pedantic point upon which the fate of this legislation rests—that the Opposition does not like the way in which the subclauses are expressed? That is pretty much what the blanket assurance covers.

Let us get some of these facts on the board again. The National Association of Forest Industries, which speaks on behalf of the industry, has said that it likes the legislation we have put forward. It has said in its note of 18 February that the legislation is not supported by NAFI in its current form as it will exclude most of the industry; but it then goes on to say, `However, members would not be opposed to its passage if this is a necessary step to establishment of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania'.

We have been through this debate. We have the proponents of the pulp mill saying, `This is a necessary step'. We have now come to the crunch. There is no dodging this point; this is the point of decision. The proponents are saying that this Bill is necessary; NAFI is saying that if it is necessary in order to get the pulp mill up, we should vote for it. It speaks for the industry, but those opposite are proposing not to.

Then there is the situation of the State Government of Tasmania. It is not a government of my political stripe; it is a government of those opposite. It has made its position clear: it wants the legislation. Those opposite are voting against the interests of their own State Government. This is the States House; this is the chamber in which the interests of the States are held as being important. There has been a clear expression by the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania and the Premier of Tasmania that they want this legislation. But Opposition senators, who have a clear responsibility to reflect their State interests, are voting against those interests.

Is this a case of the Premier of Tasmania and the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania being out of step with a handful of Tasmanian senators in this place? Is this a case of the Government and the Opposition of Tasmania—members of which actually live and work in the State all of the time—not knowing as much as those few senators who come to Canberra and spend only part of their time in the State of Tasmania? Someone is out of step, and it is not the State Government or the State Opposition.

Then there is the question of the ACTU. I am frequently lectured in this place about the ACTU. I am told that I am its tool and its dupe. Senator Winston Crane, who is one of my major critics, is sitting there smiling in recognition of these words. I am now lectured, for the sake of argumentative convenience, that, essentially, I do not know what the ACTU position is. It just so happens that I do know what the ACTU position is; it supports this legislation. So honourable senators opposite should not insult my intelligence, the intelligence of the ACTU, and their own intelligence, by pretending that the ACTU's position is different from that. It is not; that is its position. The honourable senator knows that that is its position.

Then we come to the proponent company. It made its position clear in last Thursday's Mercury, in which it said that it wants this legislation. The company made it clear that that was in its own interests and in the interests of the economic development of northern Tasmania. So that is a review of the formal organisations. What about those people who do not have a voice here directly through a formal organisation? What about the unemployed people in Tasmania? This is not an idle question. If this project goes ahead there will be job opportunities for them. Why do those opposite hate them? Why do they want to vote against them? Why do they want to deny them an opportunity for a livelihood? Why do they want to deny their families some sort of income? I put it to those opposite that they should reconsider in view of overwhelming public demand now.

There is the further question. We can monitor, review and consult about the application of this legislation and we will do that. Through this legislation, we as a government are delivering our commitment to the industry. The industry will, however, flourish if because of what we do in this legislation the road is cleared to make it easier for the industry to make investment decisions. We are therefore in an informal partnership, in the sense that we are proposing to facilitate expeditiously the clearances of major projects dealing with sensitive environmental, ecological and Aboriginal concerns. We are proposing, at some political cost to us, to expedite those proceedings so that development can flow. I know, because the industry has told me, that there is some $5 billion in investment in this industry around Australia—not just in Tasmania, but elsewhere as well—that would flow at a critical time for the economy.

What I am going to put to those opposite is a very hard proposition because it is a proposition that does occur to the Machiavellian mind at a time like this. When there is no reasonable explanation for their behaviour, we look for other explanations. Is it the case that the Opposition wants to defeat this legislation to prevent that investment from flowing so that the unemployment figures and the economic outcomes are worse, in the expectation that somehow, if it can worsen the economic climate, prevent people from getting employment, we will be voted out of office? Is that the Opposition's real motive? If it is, please get up and be honest about it and get on to a constructive wavelength with us.

Finally, the Opposition intends to move 17 amendments to this Bill. They all revolve around the single question of the $100m cut-off figure. We know from the industry's figures that if the $100m cut-off applied, something like 94 or 95 per cent of the projects in anticipation would be covered. We also know, through the proposal we have in this legislation to aggregate smaller projects, that in fact 99 per cent of proposed projects could go ahead.

So what the pedantry in this debate is about is the remaining one per cent and those projects can be covered by the enhanced inter-governmental agreements. Garry West, the National Party member and Minister responsible for natural resources in New South Wales is prepared to enter into an enhanced inter-governmental agreement with this Government. So that takes care of New South Wales, the soul mates of those opposite. But of course what the Opposition seems to be about is rejecting parties of its kith and kin in an effort to crawl over their economic interests and the interests of their own populations, to get at us, to crawl over them no matter what, just to get at us. I conclude that this amendment should be supported. I am astonished that the Opposition is not going to do so. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering the first amendment that has been moved by the Government, that is, the amendment to the title of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. I remind the Committee that this amendment proposes to substitute the words `major projects' for the word `development' in the title of the Bill. I suggest that it is reasonable for Senator Tambling to adopt the view that he expressed because he has no certainty that the Opposition amendments will be carried.
—It is all or nothing. You get your lot or you get nothing.

—All I am saying to the Minister is that I do not know, the Minister does not know and they do not know what will happen with those other amendments. We have a fair idea. If those other amendments go through, clearly the word `development' should stay, and not `major projects'. It is a matter of commonsense, I would have thought. If the Opposition's amendments are carried, clearly it is not only a major projects Bill. If they are not carried, it is a major projects Bill.
—This is their amendment, though.

—I know. I am not arguing for the Opposition. I am just making the simple point that I believe it would be better for this clause, which is merely a description of the Bill, to be determined after we know the outcome of the other amendments. That is all I want to say at this stage. It seems to me just a matter of fact as to whether it is a major projects Bill or a development Bill, and that depends on whether the Opposition's amendments are adopted or fail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can clarify the matter. Our agreement with the Minister for Resources, Mr Alan Griffiths, was that we would agree to change the Bill title to `Forest Conservation and Major Projects' on condition that there was a commitment given by the Government. The agreement said:
