All provisions of the Bill would remain unchanged.
The Government was to give certain commitments, the first being:

.undertake to monitor and review the effectiveness of the legislation to ensure that it achieves its objectives of certainty and security for the industry and generates value adding investment and jobs in the forest industries.
The second commitment was:

If it can be demonstrated that the legislation has not achieved its objectives within a reasonable time frame the Government would, in consultation with the industry, consider what further action might be appropriate.
The next commitment was:

.agree to consult with industry concerning the development of the concept of enhanced inter-governmental agreements designed to provide resource security on a regional basis for those forest industry investments which would not otherwise qualify under the Forest Conservation and Major Projects legislation.
That was the next commitment given by the Government. The next agreement was:

agree to ongoing discussions with industry and trade unions regarding the provision of certainty and security for investment related wood supplies in the context of reviewing the ESD, National Plantations Advisory Committee and RAC recommendations prior to developing the National Forest Strategy.
The last agreement was:
announce these commitments in the resumption of the second reading of the Bill in the Senate.

Instead of supporting with us the agreement of the Minister for Resources, all the Minister for Industrial Relations has done is to be extra smart and say, `All they wanted to do was to change the name of the Bill'. It is not just the name of the Bill; it was all the other commitments that have just been listed that the Minister for Resources had come to an agreement about. We have had Senator Cook here this evening saying—

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening?

—I wish it were this evening. He has been saying, `We'll change the name of the Bill. Of course, we'll monitor it; we always do. And, of course, we'll have ongoing discussions with industry; we always do'. But he leaves out the crux of the commitment that the Minister for Resources had promised. When we went through all these weeks of negotiations, the Minister for Resources, Mr Alan Griffiths, did a fantastic job.
—Yep. A good Minister.
—Senator Sherry would agree with us. He would say, `Yep, a good Minister'. Senator Sherry agrees with him entirely. Senator Sherry said tonight or today some time that he agreed entirely.
—But can Mr Griffiths deliver?

—That is the only thing wrong with the Minister. He was able to give the promise. He said, `I'm sure I can deliver this', but he was unaware of just how badly the Left was involved in these shenanigans. We do know that Senator Bolkus was objecting to it very strongly. Because APPM is presently involved with industrial relations problems with its employees, Senator Cook said, `To heck, we'll give them anything'.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. That is an absolute falsehood and ought to be withdrawn. It is a sad reflection on what the Senate is prepared to stoop to. I never said those words and I have always supported this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Senator Cook, that is not a point of order. You will have an opportunity at the end of Senator Walters's speech to intervene if there is a matter to be corrected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not saying that Senator Cook said that publicly. Of course, he did not.
—He thought it.
—It was not the case that Senator Cook thought it.

—Yes, he ratted on the deal. He said that it will not go ahead. Senator Bolkus rang Mrs Kelly in Kuala Lumpur and said, `Don't you dare agree with this'. Senator Cook absolutely backed it to the hilt.
—Are you tapping the telephone calls?
—Senator Sherry knows what is going on in Tasmania. He knows what his colleague Senator Devereux is doing.

—I am not squirming. Senator Sherry knows as well as I do what Senator Devereux is doing. He knows that he has said the Left ought to get back into bed with the Greens and get a closer liaison. Senator Devereux is opposing this legislation. I admit that Senator Sherry is supporting it, but he is supporting an agreement that Alan Griffiths agreed to. Senator Sherry is supporting the industry. He told the industry today that he is supporting it, and I do not blame him, but it is a pity the Minister, Alan Griffiths, cannot deliver.

PARA.TAB: Let us get quite clear just what is going on. The Government has said—and do not forget that we have a new Prime Minister in charge of this legislation now—`We have this you-beaut legislation for all investments over $100m'. It does not help all the lower investors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it does.
—It does not help the lot down at Geeveston. It does not help Risby. It does not help Gunns. It does not help them to invest.

—Not at all. Indeed, the company has said, `We need security before we are prepared to invest $32m'. It does not help Gunns and Risby at all, and they want to invest $32m.
—You have to understand joint ventures.

—Minister Cook says it does. Let me quote from the group that he believes we should support—APPM. In their evidence before the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, APPM witnesses said:

SPEECH.PARA: North acknowledges that the Bill does little to help the majority of the industry.
Later they said:
We are also aware that other parts of our industry have a different view of this Bill from that of North Broken Hill Peko.
That follows the fact that APPM said it wanted our amendments, but if we could not get them it would rather half a Bill than none, so would we please pass this flawed Bill. They said:

PARA.TAB: We have the situation that if we want project specific legislation then, okay, we are prepared to put up that sort of legislation. Senator Cook agrees. He says yes. —No, this is not project specific. This is a $100m investment. Senator Sherry knows what I am talking about. I will be interested to know that. Does he want that sort of development in our State? Does he want the mill as well as the Risbys and Gunn investment? I believe that he does. I do not believe that Senator Devereux does. I believe that Senator Sherry does, but I do not believe that Senator Cook cares one iota. All he wants to do is to get back at APPM for daring to consult with its—
—That is a lie, and you are a liar!

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not mind, Mr Temporary Chairman.
—As Chairman of the Committee, I mind that Senator Cook made an unparliamentary remark, and I ask him to withdraw it.
—I withdraw the word `liar' and substitute the fact that Senator Walters cannot tell the truth on this point.
—All Senator Cook is concerned about is that APPM dares to talk to its employees—that is all; not another thing. All he wants to do is get at APPM for daring to talk to its employees.

—That is not your position.
—His position is the same as mine.

—Order! Senator Walters, your time has expired. —I wish to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I have been misrepresented. In the speech that Senator Walters just gave she made allegations about what I intended. The allegations, as I recall them, were that I intend to prevent this legislation because I am pursuing some sort of agenda against APPM because of industrial relations matters. That is not true at all. It never was true and it will not ever be true, as far as I am concerned. —It has not.
—It has not.
—It supports this legislation.
—It does not. The ACTU gave evidence, and you should read the evidence.
—The ACTU wants it amended. It is in the Hansard. It was before the Committee. You keep misrepresenting the evidence.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. What Senator Cook has just said is not true. The ACTU gave evidence before our Committee—
—Order! Senator Walters, please resume your seat. That is not a point of order.

—To conclude my explanation, I can rely on no other authority than Robe River in this matter. At that time I did whatever I possibly could to open markets and help Robe River in price negotiations. I am sure that it will testify to that. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a number of points about what has been said to this point in the committee stage of the debate. —You can't keep bleating about them if you don't move them.
—Are you going to support them?
—I am not going to support them.

—You come into this place and say that we have not moved in our position in terms of this agreement and the discussions that have gone on. Minister Griffiths has moved, and is still supportive of this position, as you well know. All you have to do is to get up and read those points, as the Minister in his place, into the Hansard. That is all you have to do.

PARA.TAB: It is not correct to say that the Minister in the House of Representatives, the other place, represented all those points in what he said. He did not. You referred to people being able to understand English. If you interpret what Minister Griffiths said in the other place as representing those five points on that piece of paper, I am very sorry but you do not understand English.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not said that.
—You did say that.
—I did not. No.
—Yes, you did. Look at Hansard in the morning.
—Order! I ask honourable senators to address the Chair.

—I take the point. The next point that I want to make about the position put to us by the Minister is that we have to take the evidence that was given to us when the hearings were held. Tonight we have had here a movable feast in terms of the Minister's position. He quoted the position of NAFI as at 18 February.
—Yes.
—You said that.
—Yes.
—NAFI gave evidence on—what dates were they?
—Thirty-first.

—On 31 March, 1 April and 30 April—it was in that period; I think they were the dates—NAFI gave in evidence its position on this legislation. That is what we have before us. In addition, we have the position of the ACTU. It is all very well for the President of the ACTU to have a little chat or to hand Senator Cook a letter in this place tonight. However, at those hearings, as Senator Sherry will know, Mr Robert Richardson appeared. I have already complimented him on the position that he adopted there.
—It was sworn evidence that he gave to the Committee.

—Yes, I will pick up that particular point. I will again quote what he said when he represented the Construction, Forest and Mining Employees Union. This was quoted to us in sworn evidence at the hearings. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . desires that the ACTU represents this organisation at the above enquiry on the basis that the existing legislation be amended to include:
(a)Resource Security based on regional forest management plans . . .
(b)Resource compensation in the event of future resource withdrawal for conservation reasons.
(c)Enhanced inter-governmental agreement supported by legislation.
Anything short of these amendments will severely injure the potential for the value-added development of Australia's sawmilling industry.

Once again, I make the point that in those hearings Mr Robert Richardson represented that position absolutely accurately. I know that other people wish to speak on this particular debate, but I just want to sum up what I have had to say. It is totally inaccurate for the Minister to represent our position as not having moved, because we have moved to that agreement. All the Minister has to do is get up and read that into the Hansard and we will vote for this legislation. That is the position. The Government knows that that is the position and it also knows that Mr Griffiths wants that done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak amongst other things to a couple of points raised by Senator Walters in this debate in reference to the positions of Senator Cook, although Senator Cook has largely outlined that, and the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths. Senator Walters referred to him saying to them that, `He was sure he can deliver this', in reference to this agreement that is being flashed around by those opposite. As I understand, the Minister did not say that. In the conversations I have had with him he did not say, `Sure, he can deliver this'.
—What did he say?
—I do not know what he said any more than you do because I was not at the meetings that took place.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Order! Senator Sherry, I ask you to direct your remarks to the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not believe that Senator Walters was there. I do not know how quotes from a Minister can be bandied around the Senate with such surety; it is just not correct. In reference to Senator Cook's position and the accusations made by Senator Walters, I share Senator Cook's position. I share Senator Cook's concern about the industrial dispute at APPM; indeed, the Liberal Premier of Tasmania shares that position. He in fact congratulated the union movement and in particular named the President of the ACTU, Mr Ferguson—
—Oh, heavens. Come on!

—This is from a Liberal Premier. He congratulated the union movement on its handling of the industrial dispute with APPM. It is good to see some commonsense from at least a small section of the Liberal Party in this country.

PARA.TAB: In dealing with the evidence before the Committee—I was on the Committee; I sat through all of the hearings over three days—the first preference of NAFI, ACTU, APPM and the State Liberal Party as represented by Mr Evan Rolley and Mr Tony Rundle, the Minister for Forests, was for some amendments to this legislation. That was their first preference.

What was their next preferred position if those amendments were not carried? Their next preferred position was for this legislation to be passed. Why? In the case of Tasmania, Mr Rundle, the Minister, so competently outlined to the Committee that there was $1.673 billion worth of projects that would be covered by this legislation in its unamended form. In addition to that, the ACTU outlined that there was an integrated plantation project and a Maryvale project that would quite definitely be covered by this legislation. That is the reason why. If the amendments to this legislation are not carried, the fall-back position logically should be that the legislation is carried to accommodate those projects that were outlined before the Committee.

I think the position of the ACTU is to be commended. Since those hearings before the Committee in late March common law writs have been served on a number of trade union officials, including the President of the ACTU. I think the ACTU is to be congratulated for differentiating between the future of this industry in terms of investment and developing export potential and the industrial dispute it has with APPM. It is to be commended for that.

I deal with this issue of the threshold of $100m because, unfortunately, this issue displays the lack of knowledge that those opposite have on this issue of the nature of forestry and integrated projects. Firstly, the Government made it clear that this legislation would cover large scale or major projects; hence, we are very happy to acknowledge that in the amendment to the title. It is simply acknowledging what is a matter of fact. From day one, the Government has indicated that this legislation would cover major projects in excess of $100m.

The Federal Government has always indicated that it is not interested in buying into disputes and evaluations of projects of a smaller size than $100m. That includes investment in mill projects of maybe $100,000 or $500,000 or $2m or whatever. It simply does not have the bureaucratic resources or the time to be running around the country evaluating hundreds of potential developments in the forest industry.

But there is another important reason. Because of the integrated nature of the forest industry, there is an indirect guarantee to resource through the $100m developments—or greater developments—that are proposed. Should an area of resource allocated to a new mill in Tasmania go ahead, a significant proportion of resource in that mill's catchment area presumably will be used for conversion of chips into pulp, and hopefully paper further downstream. A significant proportion of that resource that is logged and taken out of the catchment area will be too good because of its quality and its value to be chipped for pulp; it will be used for other purposes. The timber that is available will be able to be used by other operators in the industry. Hence, we have an indirect guarantee of a resource to other operators in Tasmania. That is the other reason why the Federal Government is not interested in removing the $100m threshold.

This Government has tried its utmost with this legislation to ensure development of major projects, not just in northern Tasmania but in Western Australia and at Maryvale. In its One Nation package the Government has outlined a special depreciation regime of some 10 per cent to encourage development in this area. This Government is bending over backwards to ensure that major projects such as are proposed in northern Tasmania get off the ground; that the processing of our raw materials is downstreamed; that we reduce imports and become a net exporter of forestry products. We can do that.

Why is the Opposition getting so worried and so concerned? Members opposite have been making some fairly extreme attacks on the media during this debate. Senator Archer referred to the Tasmanian media as `the gutter press'. I note that we have a member of that alleged gutter press from the Hobart Mercury in the press gallery tonight. Given the situation in the past 15 or 20 years, it is interesting that for once in this debate on forestry members opposite are being held accountable for their position. They are a little worried because at the end of this debate they may—I hope they do not—vote with the Australian Democrats and the Greens to defeat this legislation. That is why they are so worried. They are getting a little desperate because they are being criticised in Tasmania for their position. Hence, we have the desperate and rather emotive abuse of the Tasmanian media. Those opposite cannot take it. That is the problem with the Liberal senators from Tasmania; they cannot take the criticism that is being handed out to them in the Tasmanian media.
Senator Cook has quoted from the editorial in last Friday's Mercury. There are a number of quotes here that refer to the Liberal senators from Tasmania:

SPEECH.PARA: In their intransigent adherence to a party line, Tasmania's Liberal senators are ignoring the needs of all the major players. . . . They were elected by Tasmanians. . . . If the mill plan falls through because resource security legislation is lost, the Tasmanian population should regard the Liberal senators as more culpable than the Greens. . . . They are to be tested on their commitment to the philosophy that the Liberal Party regards the Senate as the defender of the states against centralism, and they look like they will fail.

It is no wonder that the Liberal senators from Tasmania are getting more than a little worried. They are about to combine with their perceived arch enemies, the Greens/Independents, to defeat this legislation, just as they entered on that unprincipled course last year when they attempted to defeat the State resource security legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is no wonder that the Opposition is getting a little worried or squeamish, and that is the reason why there is so much in the way of protest in this debate this evening. Why have those opposite locked themselves into an intractable opposition to this legislation? The reason is that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was conned by a letter from the Montreal Bank which alleged that the resource security legislation currently before the Senate was worthless and totally unbankable. This view was rejected by the Australian Bankers Association, but unfortunately Dr Hewson rushed in and recommended that the shadow Cabinet oppose this legislation. I wonder how much consultation there was with Tasmanian members. The Opposition locked itself in, implacably opposing this legislation without giving the matter adequate thought.

It is like a number of other decisions made by Dr Hewson. He is not big enough to admit that he was wrong, that he made a mistake, and to change his position. We will have to wait and see how he gets himself out of the consumption tax, or the GST, if he ever manages to do so. That is the basic reason why the Opposition got locked into this position; it was conned by this bank letter. Now it is trying to back-pedal. Unfortunately, with the best efforts it can muster, that is simply not enough.

The Government has adopted the words `major projects' in the legislation before us tonight. There is no harm in that, because it simply reiterates what the legislation is covering. Earlier in his remarks Senator Cook referred to the endorsement given by the Minister for Resources in respect of a number of processes that will be followed in the implementation of this legislation and Mr Griffiths outlined those processes in a speech during the MPI debate last week. That represents the position that the Government is willing to concede, which is a lot more than the Opposition is entitled to, given its performance in this area.

Before concluding, I reiterate that the evidence before the Committee—except that from those groups in the environment movement, such as the threatened species group, the Wilderness Society and the Conservation Foundation, which are implacably opposed to this legislation—was that the other industry organisations and people, including Mr Tony Rundle, the Liberal Minister for Forests in Tasmania, would certainly like some amendments. They do not necessarily want all the amendments put up by the Opposition. They were supporting some, but not necessarily all of them. However, at the end of the day, they wanted this legislation passed. If the amendments are defeated—and it appears almost certain that they will be defeated—the legislation should be supported.
I conclude by quoting the Tasmanian Liberal Premier, Mr Groom, in reference to this legislation even if the amendments are not accepted. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't mind saying I want the coalition in Canberra to support the legislation. I think they are wrong in taking the stand they are taking. Obviously you need good arguments to reject that legislation if a pulp mill depends upon it.
That comes from none other than the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Groom. It is good advice, and those opposite should take it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start, there are two matters I wish to raise with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). Firstly, I asked him for some answers to some questions, which do not seem to have come through yet; I wonder whether he is now in a position to answer those. Secondly, without stretching the friendship too far, perhaps we might have time to look at this exhaustive list of all the things that the Government has given, provided or done as far as the legislation is concerned. Those things seem to have escaped me and I just feel that it may be an opportune time to have a better look at that list.

PARA.TAB: It is really quite important to ensure that we are all talking about one and the same thing. I will repeat the things that Mr Griffiths said in the other place, as it is quite clear that the Minister is not quite on the same wavelength with what he reads or believes that somebody has said. On page 2162 of the House of Representatives Hansard of Thursday 30 April 1992, Mr Griffiths also was trying to do a bit of what I suppose we would call `Keatingtalk' these days. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me to be an extraordinary position that we have now reached, where the Opposition will apparently vote against this legislation in the Senate as a response to the Government not being prepared at this point to change the title of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: It would be a sin of omission on my part were I not also to say that there are differences in terms of the Opposition's desire to see the Government embrace, in a written instrument to itself, undertakings relating to the ongoing monitoring of the legislation and, in the event of the legislation being found wanting, indicating a preparedness to review within a reasonable time frame any shortcomings in the legislation. As a mirror image of that position, I might say the same thing in relation to enhanced inter-governmental agreement processes.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that both Mr Griffiths and Senator Cook were trying to give the impression that that was the same as the now well-known and well-recognised `Griffiths agreement'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't conclude the quote there. I went on and said what it meant. I refer you to my remarks.

—Having achieved an agreement of this form, it seems quite extraordinary that Senator Cook and Mr Griffiths are now not prepared to say, `Yes, that is it'. That is what we are discussing. Mr Griffiths went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I am quite happy to indicate in this chamber, on the record, that any legislation for which I have responsibility either as Minister for Resources or, for that matter, as Minister for Tourism would, in the normal course of events, be subject to such ongoing monitoring and review. There is no legislation for which I have responsibility that I would not review in the event of shortcomings being established. So if we have now a position—
and then there was a little bit of interjection. He continued:

So presumably that strips away the Opposition's requirement to have, by way of correspondence, the identical undertaking. The undertaking is there, as I indicated to the Opposition in our discussions—

I ask Minister Cook: with the record that the Labor Party has, does he really believe that anybody would take a verbal assurance—really, does he? I would like him to think about that one because it may be a harder question to answer than the ones I have already given him. Even if it is in writing, I am not sure that I would really believe that I had it. I have a copy here of a document called the memorandum of understanding. It has some of the best autographs about on it too. It was one of these excellent agreements that we have been talking about. This is the way to stretch the wherewithal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose signatures are there?

—I think we have John Kerin on the top and his offsider Geoff Miller, followed up by Ray Groom and Robin Gray. What is the value of that agreement, dated 12 June 1986? We have a list of very good agreements, excellent agreements, about five in a row, every one of which has been overridden by the Commonwealth. What is the point in having an agreement with the Minister? Whether it is in writing or verbal, I cannot see that it makes a lot of difference.

PARA.TAB: But at least if there are any bona fides, which we have already established do not exist, if there is any goodwill, which we have already established does not exist, then surely to goodness it is not too much to say that even once more, in spite of the history, we are prepared to look at a signed copy of the document which, as I understand it, was produced in the Minister's office; it has his address, Parliament House, Canberra, and the date, 28 April 1992, on the bottom. I do not think anybody is disputing that it was produced in his office or the date and address.

This is just another Wesley Vale replay; it just goes on and on. They had to stop the Wesley Vale project by one means or another; the environmental issues would not carry the weight. It is just another case. When they have made up their minds, it does not matter what the result is, so long as they can achieve it to the advancement of the overall issue. May I have the answers to those questions, please?

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate will shortly draw to a close, given the expiry of the 90 minutes allowed by this chamber for it to be completed. I want to note for the record that earlier this day Senator Coulter said that the debate in the committee stage had been going on for four hours. He was pulled up on a point of fact and told that it had been going for two hours and 52 or 54 minutes.
—Fifty-six, I think.

—Fifty-six, was it? The debate has now been going for almost an extra hour and a half; we still have not dealt with the first amendment. The calls for better and further debate really amount, in summary, to filibustering on the other side to prevent this chamber dealing with the amendment that is before it.

PARA.TAB: I remind the chamber that this is an Opposition amendment—an amendment which the Government is moving in order that we might move on to the cherished other amendments that the Opposition proposed to have brought forward. Before we got into the substantive debate on this issue we had a procedural debate. In that debate there was a lot of bleating and complaining that members in this chamber do not have the opportunity to debate all the amendments.

The second point for the record is that Opposition members have had an opportunity to do so but have not sought to debate any of their amendments. They have not sought to move them or bring them before the chamber and conduct a proper debate of their amendments. I do not know whether that means they are afraid of them, that they are not wedded to them, but the fact is that in this debate they have not bothered to move them.

I do not know what Opposition members think is the great parliamentary tactic in this procedure. If they think the great parliamentary tactic is that somehow or other that will reflect badly on the Government, then I remind the Opposition members that when this debate does come to a conclusion and this Bill is voted for, they have the option of voting for it or against it. The Opposition will decide whether this Bill carries or not. The Opposition will decide that fact. If the Bill carries, it means that major projects in this country worth up to $5 billion will go ahead and development will ensue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a guarantee?

—That is the undertaking by the industry, and Senator Archer well knows that. Development will go ahead. Jobs will be created. In the specific circumstances of this industry we have it on the word of Mr Chris Oldfield of Northern Broken Hill Peko that the project in north Tasmania will go ahead. A substantial number of jobs will be created in the construction phase.
—Where did he say that?
—It is quoted in the Hobart Mercury of Friday, 30 April.

PARA.TAB: Opposition Senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators may well deride the Mercury as the gutter press, as in fact Senator Archer did, but the advice I have is that that is an accurate quote. This company wants the legislation to be carried.

PARA.TAB: Somewhere the Opposition has to confront the following question. Why does it hate Tasmania; why does it hate development; and why does it hate people who are unemployed getting access to employment? The Opposition has to confront that question because pretty soon it will be casting a vote to determine where it stands. It can enable this project to go ahead; it can enable these jobs to be created; it can enable economic development to occur; it can enable the balance of trade to swing more in our favour; it can enable downstream processing to occur on the very valuable and ecologically and environmentally rare resource of forestry—it can enable all those things to occur.

On the other hand, if the Opposition votes this legislation down, the investment will not flow because the security will not be there. The Opposition has this choice; this is its decision. The Government has strenuously been presenting the case to the Opposition and it should make the decision in the affirmative. I understand that the Opposition is locked in, it is blinkered, and it will not proceed to make this decision.

I refer to some of the major arguments that those opposite have put. The first is the disgraceful, totally misrepresentative and disingenuous argument that the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) has somehow made an agreement. Senator Walters went to the extreme and actually quoted him. As far as I am aware, Senator Walters was not there. She does not have the power to read someone else's mind. Nonetheless, she maintains intransigently that these are the words he used.

What did Mr Griffiths do? He issued a document to the industry for exploratory discussions in order to open up the deadlock and get people talking again. When the outcome of these discussions had been concluded—it is on this point that those opposite always argue the contrary; I am here to tell them on behalf of the Government that this is the case—Mr Griffiths indicated that he would take the matter back to the Government and that it would respond. Mr Griffiths was not and did not seek to be in a position to conclude an agreement and nor did he. He referred the matter back to the Government and the Government, as a whole, responded.

There is a lot of disingenuous praise of Mr Griffiths. I think praise is merited. He is a very good Minister and he far surpasses those on the other side who have discussed this matter with him. Mr Griffiths did not do what is claimed by the Opposition: he did not conclude an agreement. Those opposite may stand up and say, `He did! He did! He did! He did!', like some child hankering after a toy. Repetition does not change circumstances; the circumstances are that he did not conclude an agreement.

I return to the NAFI board. On 18 February, the NAFI board issued a statement saying that of course it would prefer some amendments to the legislation but, if not, `Members would not be opposed to its passage if this is a necessary step to establish a pulp mill in northern Tasmania'. We know that it is a necessary step; we know that the amendments are not going to carry. The industry organisation is saying, `Carry this Bill'. The Opposition is saying that that is not true. I understand that this was re-endorsed by the NAFI board again today. What might have been said between when it was carried and now cannot be used as the case for where it stands now. This has been re-endorsed today and those opposite are bound to listen to it.

The third point I refer to is the ACTU. This is a joke and I am sure it might make `Column 8' in the Sydney Morning Herald, or some other column, as some other peculiar expression of weirdness from the Opposition. At this hour of the night we would expect a bit of weirdness. The ACTU gave evidence, through Mr Bob Richardson, to the inquiry. What is the Opposition saying? It is saying that that is the ACTU's position. The ACTU is an organisation, like many other organisations—both union and industry organisations—which is dynamic. It does not have a static position; it is not a Maginot line.

The ACTU looks at circumstances which change, and changes to meet the changed circumstances. As I understand it, in the ACTU's view, the circumstances have changed and the President of the ACTU has told the Government today, not on his own behalf but as the official spokesman for the organisation, that it supports the passage of this legislation. The Opposition says that that is not true and that it does not believe it. We may not be standing here because those opposite do not want to believe it, but it can be proved by resort to simple items of proof in physics that we are here. Whether they believe it or not, we are here. Whether they believe it or not, the ACTU's position is to support this legislation. The Opposition should not use the ACTU, NAFI and North Broken Hill as crutches upon which to argue these fictitious arguments.

That leads me to the Government of Tasmania. The Government of Tasmania won an election based on the development of pulp mills in Tasmania. It won an election on proposals to manage the forest there. It won a closely fought and bitter election in Tasmania. What does it say? It says that it wants this legislation. What does the Opposition in Tasmania say? It says that it wants this legislation. What do the two major parties representing the majority of electors in Tasmania, therefore, say? They say that they want this legislation. The Opposition here knows better. The Opposition knows better than its own political Party in government in Tasmania. It knows better than the Opposition in Tasmania. Everyone is out of step, bar the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to talk this out?
—No, I do not want to. If the indication is that the Opposition wants me to yield, I will gladly give up the floor. So let us vote on this damned amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that during the evening there have been discussions between the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, and industry representatives. I have received a message recently. I am well aware of the time and the constraint of the guillotine, and there cannot be both the guillotine and negotiations operating at the same time. If the Government is prepared to talk, the challenge is obviously to meet that negotiation, to call off the debate tonight and to consider in detail, and in the appropriate form, any agreements that are being talked about between the Minister and any industry people at this late hour.
—This is a cheap manoeuvre.

—It is not a trick manoeuvre. It is about discussions that I believe have taken place earlier in the evening between Minister Griffiths and others. I can certainly indicate that we would be prepared to discuss them on that basis.

PARA.TAB: Mr Chairman, I seek your advice as to whether I can, in these time constraints, also move the other amendments that have been circulated in my name and not have them caught and captured by the guillotine. These amendments, of course, will allow for legislative backing to accredited State or regional forest development plans. This will cover all of those investors who want to spend $3m, $500,000 or some other figure less than $100m. They do not alter the major projects part of the Bill, which will cater for projects over $100m, but they do add resource security for all the small people.

Of course, amendment 17 is most important. This simply removes a very silly clause which says that, after giving resource security, the Government can take it away and not pay any compensation—not even timber replacement. Very early in discussions with the Government, Mr Griffiths said that he would remove this clause, but he was rolled on that matter too. So what sort of security is this?

Our amendment 16, or new clause 22A, will provide timber to the investor if he loses the timber over which he has the resource security due to some unforeseen legislation. It is indeed regrettable that the Government has frustrated and thwarted the proper debates that should take place on these very comprehensive amendments. There are 17 of them in that area that I have had to precis.

TALK.START.PARA: —All you have to do is support the Bill and there will be a pulp mill.
—Listen to the latecomer who has just come into the chamber. Obviously he has got his second wind and has just woken up. The most important thing—
—He is right.

—`It's right,' says the leftie who has not contributed one bit to the debate. All of these amendments are very important, not just the amendment to clause 1, as put up by the Minister. There cannot be negotiations going on between the industry and the Minister, and then the Opposition is expected to respond to them at this point without having the appropriate form and the appropriate way of conducting those negotiations.

PARA.TAB: As we have argued this evening over and over again, a guillotine is a totally inappropriate way of dealing with such major legislation as this. It is vitally important that we get on with the proper business of this debate. It is obvious that in the future the only correction to this is going to come after the change of government, when appropriate legislation will be fully addressed by a Hewson-Fischer Government that will go down the tracks and give the commitments that, very obviously, industry is unable to achieve even in late conversations and discussions with the Government.

We have had to face the shenanigans of a government that is in its dying and gasping stages, that will not give review to the appropriate pieces of legislation in its own Party forums and that will not properly accommodate the debates that happen within its own divisions or factions in whatever way we want to cover it. It is also most noticeable that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made no mention of this matter whatsoever in his One Nation statement. So many omissions are just beginning to come to the fore.

The Prime Minister can always find and add many other issues to enter the debate, be it the flag, his new nationalism or whatever. Very obviously, we have legislation before us that demands the much closer scrutiny of this Parliament and that has been established time and again. Not one industry, union or principal media commentator has given this legislation support or endorsement in any way.

We have reached a sad and sorry time in this area. The Prime Minister's credibility will be tested. We need to record that tonight has been a shameful attempt by the Labor Government to wheel and deal and to trade and carry on in so many areas. The casualties of this whole area are the hundreds of thousands of Australian people who have lost their jobs. The industry has been prepared to cooperate and the Opposition has been prepared to cooperate and negotiate, but factions and tiny leadership deals, particularly in vested groups within the parliamentary wing of the Labor Party, are what have caused the casualties and the problems on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some credibility gaps between what Senator Cook has been saying and what I have been saying. I have accused him of wanting to scupper APPM and he tells me that I am not telling the truth. He says that the ACTU supports the legislation and I tell him that he is not telling the truth. I happen to have evidence that the ACTU is not supporting the legislation because it gave public evidence on 30 March which said—
—Read the whole lot.
—I am reading the whole lot from the ACTU House:

SPEECH.PARA: I confirm that the CFMIEU-ATAIU Division desires that the ACTU represents this organisation at the above enquiry . . .
It continues:
(a) Resource Security based on regional forest management plans supported by value adding investment proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the consideration of the Bill has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 17 standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent further consideration of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion not to take much further time of the Senate, but really to try to get an answer from the Government on the matters that have just been put to the Government by Senator Tambling. As we understand it, the Minister responsible for the Bill, the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), has indicated that he is prepared to negotiate further on the matter. We have said throughout that we are prepared to negotiate—that is what we have been trying to do for months—to reach a compromise that will allow us to pass legislation that is not faulted in the way that this legislation is.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Tambling said, the Government cannot have it both ways. It cannot on the one hand be indicating that it is prepared to negotiate whilst on the other hand exercising the power of its numbers in this place, guillotining this debate and forcing a premature conclusion to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't have the numbers in this place.

—Senator Collins should listen for a minute. Therefore, it seems to us that the sensible course of action would be for the Government to acknowledge that we have gone as far as we can tonight and to agree to hold the matter over until tomorrow. We recognise the good faith that we presume is there on the part of Minister Griffiths—
—At a later hour this day.

—At a later hour this day. We have acknowledged that Minister Griffiths has demonstrated some good faith in the past. We have reciprocated that throughout. We are prepared to continue those negotiations to see whether this legislation can be put in a form in which we can pass it. That is only consistent with the position we have adopted throughout.

PARA.TAB: Even at this very late stage, we have the opportunity—through Mr Griffiths being in the building and apparently being prepared to negotiate—to indicate again that that would be our wish. We want the pulp mill and we want legislation, but we have said throughout that it has to be legislation in a satisfactory form. I invite the Government at this last moment to consider whether it really wants to lose this opportunity for the people of Tasmania or finally be prepared to show just a touch of reasonableness.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could perhaps take a tolerant view of what has been put forward by Senator Hill if it was not for the gaping credibility gap in the performance of the Opposition in this whole debate. I need to go back over what has happened. We have had a second reading debate, we have had an inquiry and we have now had 4 1/2 hours of debate on the committee stage of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill—and we still have not dealt with the first clause. I moved an amendment, which was the Opposition's amendment, to change the title of the Bill. Those opposite, in a fit of late night weirdness, decided to oppose their own amendment which they had circulated last week as an amendment to the first clause.

PARA.TAB: One has to ask oneself what is going on here. That being the record and in the face of that performance, right at the last minute, damn it, someone bobs up and says, `Hang on, there's a last minute possibility of an agreement'. I have seen a few of those American soap operas where the trial is going on and someone bowls in with new evidence and the whole thing is turned over. This is reminiscent of the farce that those sorts of soap operas represent.

The question here is one of credibility. Senator Hill says that we should now adjourn to allow for further talks. What evidence is there that if we were even to contemplate that, there would in fact be genuine discussions, when in the last two days the Opposition has talked this out? What evidence is there that this is not just another ploy, essentially, to extend the debate and continue the farce that we have witnessed over the last few days?

The Opposition has said that it wants the pulp mill; Senator Hill said that himself. If it wants the pulp mill, which is what North Broken Hill, the State Government, the ACTU, the State Opposition and we want—and if it wants to be the last major group to join what is the collective decision of everyone else in wanting the pulp mill—there is a simple, straightforward, easy answer: vote for the legislation. If those opposite do that, hey presto, given the commitments of North Broken Hill Peko, they will get the pulp mill. So if those opposite want it, they should do that and they will get it. It is a fairly straightforward, sequential chain of decisions which will lead to an outcome that I think—
Senator Newman—What is your Minister wanting?

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the honourable senator mean? We have made it clear all the time what our position is. We have bent over backwards, we have leaned towards the Opposition position and we have given the Opposition assurances. We have moved its amendment, and those opposite still filibuster in the debate; they still do not want to address the first clause. At the last minute, we get slipped to us the whole 17 amendments moved en bloc as though they had been there all along.
—That is only because you provoked them into doing it.

—That is exactly right. That is only because we provoked them into doing it. So here we are. The time for the debate has expired. The truth has to be faced up to. What did Ernest Hemingway call these moments? He called them the moment of truth. This is the moment of truth. The Opposition has to make a decision. It would be best advised to climb down and recognise the reality and vote for the legislation.

PARA.TAB: While there might be a bit of momentary criticism of the Opposition's indecision, because it did not know which way to turn, in the end there will be longer term approval of what it has done and some respect and recognition for the courage it has shown in being prepared to change its position. I draw the Committee's attention to what Senator Hill has said and I cite the huge credibility that is hanging on the performance of the Opposition in this debate. That is a good reason why we should not pay attention to what is being said now.

TALK.START.PARA: —No way Jose on this one. Senator Cook has posed the question: what is going on here? What is going on here is incredible naivety and ineptness on both sides of this chamber. It seems to me that the Opposition is quite correct when it identifies that the Government, rather than face the deep divisions within itself, decided to bowl up this piece of legislation to the Senate in the hope that the combination of the Opposition and the Democrats would get rid of it. Of course, the chickens have come home to roost and it has been fed back to the Government. Now the Government has had to face up to a very difficult task.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition, for its part, seems to me to have been equally inept in not recognising that it is really not in its interests to continue with this debate. I am surprised that the Opposition wants to continue with the legislation rather than get rid of it. It is clear that this legislation should not be passed. Not so long ago Senator Archer quoted the Resource Assessment Commission in this debate pointing out that the Commission said that this legislation was not necessary. The Opposition, quite clearly, in the legislation which it would countenance, would severely water down the important area of environmental protection. That is quite intolerable to the Australian Democrats and, I would also hope, to the Government.

There is really no way, with the impasse that we have reached—the impasse we knew we had reached days ago—that this legislation can pass in its present form. Given the position in which it has placed itself through its mishandling of this situation, there is no way the Government will countenance further change. So let us get on with it, let us vote on it, let us get rid of it and get on with other important legislation which lies on the Notice Paper.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Jones did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Olsen.)

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.
Senator Coulter—Mr Chairman, I believe the correct course of action now is for you to put all 18 amendments together.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have all 18 amendments before us at the moment. We only have one amendment before us. We cannot have more than one amendment before the Chair without leave. The question is that the amendment to clause 1 be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 1992:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Suspect Illegal Entrant Vessel (SIEV) investigation:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Government agree with the executive summary conclusion that "on this occasion they failed to detect a significant and sensitive target vessel illegally landing in Australia".
(2) Why was there no independent evaluation of the operation.
(3) It has been said that the investigating team had no "direct involvement" in the evaluation, did they have any indirect involvement.
(4) Given the serious admissions in the report and the number of unanswered questions, will the Government have the report scrutinised by an independent group.
(5) The summary claims that without clear intelligence "Coastwatch was forced into large area searches", is this conclusion correct.

(6) Does the report demonstrate that wrong conclusions were drawn and that operations concentrated on approaches to Darwin and Broome, ignoring totally the Kimberley region where intruders eventually landed.
(7) The report says that the bottom line is "better intelligence and the wider use of risk analysis techniques", what exactly does this mean.
(8) What agencies are presently involved in intelligence gathering.
(9) Who is to be involved in new risk techniques.
(10) Why were there little or no serious long term considerations given to a deliberate landing and entry into the Kimberley region.

(11) It has been said that "there is no basis for any suggestion that Coastwatch (from either Broome or Darwin) reduced flying rates as a result of Christmas or the New Year period", does the report admit that despite the patterns of previous years, where there is a high activity of Indonesian fishing boats over the December and January periods, that the operation was not mounted until 31 December 1991; if so, why was the high risk Christmas period ignored.

(12) Why was the Coastwatch aircraft, seen by some on the vessel on 31 December 1991, not briefed about the possible SIEV arrival: (a) does this indicate a lack of co-ordination; or (b) laxity in preparing and distribution intelligence for pilot briefing.
(13) Were other aircraft operating on routine patrols briefed on the possible arrival; if not, why not.

(14) It has been admitted that in regard to inter-agency communication "liaison and co-operation arrangements could be even better structured and streamlined": (a) what are the revealed weaknesses that led to this conclusion; (b) why is the planning process flawed; and (c) what disciplines are needed to "ensure all possible scenarios are considered".

(15) Is it true that after the landing neither the vessel nor the landing parties were detected until the arrivals contacted the King Edward River Station, a period up to almost two weeks after the vessel sailed into Montague Sound.
(16) Why are there no contingency plans in place to deal with landings such as this and why are police and other such agencies not presently involved in contingency planning.
(17) Was NORFORCE ever alerted or used in the land search.
(18) Are the reports of routine NORFORCE patrol activity available to, and used by, Coastwatch, police, customs and other agencies.

(19)(a) Were Customs, RAAF or Naval resources used in relation to, or even briefed, about, the possible landing; and (b) were any of these resources deployed during the December or January periods; if not, why not.

(20) Despite knowledge that the vessel had reached Sumba, why did intelligence fail to provide ongoing information about the vessel, its replacements, its crew and passengers and does this indicate a specific failure in this case or does it demonstrate a gap in our strategic intelligence capability.

(21) The report comments on the limitations of the aircraft and equipment used by Coastwatch: (a) are these assets good enough to achieve the objectives of the organisation; (b) are there better assets available; if so, why are they not being used or acquired.

(22) It has been revealed that agencies believe that it is likely that arrivals will increase and "the potential impact of an exotic pest or disease incursion to Australia could be enormous", it is also revealed that one tactical operation of about five days "means complete disruption of Coastwatch services around the country": (a) does this indicate that one planned or unplanned "incident" could allow other arrivals to land without detection; and (b) what action is proposed to correct this dangerous lack of resources in aircraft, training pilots and observers, and finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) A small team from Coastwatch and the two policy agencies was appropriate to identify what happened and to recommend changes for the future.

(3) The Investigation Team members were directly involved in the evaluation but not in the SIEV incident. Neither did they have any involvement in the pre search stage though two of the members were briefed on developments whilst they were on leave. All three members had a management/supervisory role of their respective officers during the search. None of the officers had any involvement, direct or indirect, in any aspects of the pre-search or search stages which subsequently was the subject of the Report.
(4) Not necessary as all recommendations will be implemented and all findings were addressed.
(5) Yes.
(6) Yes wrong conclusions were drawn though it is incorrect to say the Kimberley region was totally ignored.

(7) With good clear intelligence on specific targets and sound definition of high risk areas Coastwatch is able to deploy aircraft and surface craft in support in those areas with the highest probability of detecting intruders.

(8) Australian Customs Service, Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Department of Defence all provide Coastwatch with information which is used to plan flights. Information from the general public and media sources is also used for this purpose.

(9) In the context of Coastwatch, all client agencies which provide taskings undertake some form of risk analysis and assessment as does Coastwatch when determining competing priorities for surveillance services.
(10) The area was previously designated low risk for landing/entry by Coastwatch and relevant client agencies.

(11) No. Operations against possible illegal fishing had been planned months in advance and were well under way from both Broome and Darwin before any decision was taken to address the possibility of a SIEV arrival. In terms of resource use the effect of both activities was to utilise aircraft to the maximum for the period 24 December 1991 - 9 January 1992 when the flying rate was reduced.
(b) No

At that time there was no clear evidence to suggest a SIEV vessel was likely to be in the area. There is always a standing briefing to report all suspicious activity either during or immediately after the flight has landed.

(14)(a) The conclusion reflects the concerns of the Investigating team that whilst not critical or even influential on this occasion, a number of opportunities for closer liaison and cooperation were not recognised and taken.
(i) opportunities to consult/liaise between Canberra based agencies were not as extensive as they could have been, in particular during the period leading up to the first flights on 31 December 1991
(ii) occasions for closer liaison/understanding of technical requirements/background between agencies were not recognised
(iii) the absence of a specific Contingency Plan to cover roles/agency responsibilities during a land search for people from a SIEV had never been addressed.

(b) The planning process is not flawed. On this occasion the assumptions on which flight deployments were based dictated limited or no coverage of the approaches to the Kimberley area initially then coastal not littoral coverage for a possible landing. In hindsight the assumptions were wrong.

(c) Formalised processes are being developed within the Customs Coastwatch Operational Command environment to ensure in future all possible options are considered whenever a target is not detected and commanders are determining the future direction of an operation.

(16) There are Contingency Plans for most Search and Rescue (SAR) scenarios however there has never been a situation previously when authorities including Customs, Quarantine and Immigration have such a direct interest in a search and rescue outcome. This unique situation needs to be reflected in a Contingency Plan which must be discussed in conjunction with established SAR coordinators including State Police Forces. State Police will clearly continue to coordinate land based SAR operations, including those in which Customs, Quarantine and Immigration have an interest.
(17) All three forces in northern Australia were alerted however as the search remained based on aerial resources, the Army had no involvement.
(18) Yes as they relate to these agencies' interests.
(19)(a) Both ACS and Royal Australian Navy resources were tasked by Coastwatch concerning a possible arrival. RAAF were not.
(b) RAAF were not tasked because Coastwatch aircraft were able to meet all taskings.

(20) On this occasion it has been admitted there was a gap in our knowledge and this was the critical factor in Coastwatch missing the target. Implementation of the Recommendations and findings from the Report of the Investigation into the incident should minimise a recurrence of SIEV landings.
(b) No. There are different assets available however they suffer the same constraints wherever intelligence to focus operations is unavailable.

(22)(a) Not necessarily. The answer depends on a range of issues including the circumstances of the arrivals and other factors including aircraft serviceabilities, crew availability etc. For example a series of arrivals over a period of weeks would certainly stretch Coastwatch resources however this has been experienced previously when up to 15 foreign fishing vessels were successfully detected and apprehended in both northern and north western waters at no detriment to the overall Coastwatch mission.

(b) The nature and level of threat to Australia by illegal entrant vessels is being closely monitored to ensure Coastwatch resources remain appropriate to meet that threat. Scope already exists to redeploy Coastwatch aircraft from other regions and to hire non-contract aircraft to carry Customs observers as the need dictates. Were it to be assessed that the threat from SIEV vessels was increasing further expansion and flexibility to Coastwatch capability would need to be considered by Government as the need is identified.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has a National Food Authority been formed or planned in Australia to harmonise food laws in accordance with Codex Alimentarius.
(2) As the Codex Alimentarius favours food irradiation, will this `harmonisation' enable the present moratorium on food irradiation to be abandoned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The National Food Authority was established on 19 August 1991 to develop and review food standards for uniform adoption throughout Australia by the States and Territories. Its establishing legislation is the National Food Authority Act 1991. In developing and reviewing food standards, section 10 of the Act requires the Authority to have regard to the following objectives in descending priority order:
the protection of public health and safety;
the provision of adequate information relating to food to enable consumers to make informed choices and prevent fraud and deception;
the promotion of fair trade in food;
the promotion of trade and commerce in the food industry; and
the promotion of consistency between domestic and international food standards where these are at variance providing it does not lower the Australian standard.

(2) The protection of public health and safety is the primary objective of the Authority in developing food standards. In working towards consistency between Australian and international standards, Australian standards are not to be lowered. Harmonisation of Australian standards with international standards is an important objective for the Authority in terms of Australia's obligations under the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, to which Australia is a signatory, and the decision by signatories to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade on the application of sanitary and phytosanitary measures. In the case of food the relevant international standards are those developed by the Codex Alimentarius Commission. Under these agreements, countries can diverge from Codex standards where they can justify doing so on health or safety grounds.

Australia will not lift the moratorium on food irradiation until the Government is fully satisfied that the process is completely safe. The Government has funded the World Health Organisation to undertake further research on safety and nutritional aspects of food irradiation. The study will be completed by the end of 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 10 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are veterans or their widows seeking compensation from the Commonwealth for illness or death caused by exposure to nuclear radiation from British bomb tests in Australia required, in most cases, to take action through the courts.

(2) Does the Government accept that many nuclear veterans remain unjustly uncompensated because it is not possible to establish a definite causal link between historical radiation exposure and most forms of cancer, and because radiation exposure records are inadequate.

(3) Will the Government establish a fairer and non-adversarial system of claim settlement which: (a) scales awards to veterans or widows according to the probability of a connection between their radiation exposure, as measured or imputed, and the illness which is the subject of the claim; (b) provides for compensation in the form of ex gratia payments; and (c) does not impose significant costs on claimants whose claims fail.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australian veterans who participated in the Tests Program in Australia (or their widows) who have an injury or illness which they believe resulted from participation in that program are entitled to apply for compensation under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. Compensation availability is not restricted to cancer conditions, but can cover any injury or illness. Claims are assessed by the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees (COMCARE). Following the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia, the Government extended eligibility for compensation to non-Commonwealth employees involved in the Tests Program.

In addition, the Government announced on 4 September 1989 a special administrative scheme to allow payment of compensation to those Australian participants in the British Nuclear Tests Program who have (or have died from) multiple myeloma or leukaemia (other then chronic lymphatic leukaemia). Under the Scheme compensation is also payable to the dependants of any Test participant who has died from the above two diseases.

All existing common law actions against the Commonwealth were lodged in 1988 and 1989. Since 1989 the Commonwealth has consistently sought to have these matters resolved outside the Courts, not only through COMCARE and the special administrative scheme referred to above but through an Act of Grace payments scheme established in September 1989. The intention of the Act of Grace payments scheme was for eligible cases to be assessed on their merits outside the adversarial Court system with a decision being taken jointly by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Attorney-General. In most cases information has not been provided to enable the validity of the claims to be assessed.

While the Commonwealth could have let these cases sit indefinitely in the High Court where they were lodged, it recognised the increasing difficulty of establishing the facts of each case so long after the event and sought to expedite consideration of the cases through the Federal Court. While the Commonwealth is defending these claims in the Federal Court it is still open to eligible claimants to have their cases considered under the Act of Grace payments scheme at no cost to themselves.

(2) The Government does not accept that nuclear veterans remain unjustly uncompensated. While recognising that it can be difficult to establish that a cancer was probably caused by radiation and that an individual was exposed to radiation in the course of his employment (as required under the COMCARE Act), it is noted that at least one radiation related claim has been accepted by COMCARE against this criteria.

While radiation exposure records do exist for Australians involved in the Tests, the majority of recorded doses are well below the safe dose recommended at the time by the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP).

The Government is aware that radiation is just one of thousands of causes of cancer and does not accept automatically that just because someone has cancer and was involved in the Tests that there is a causal link between the two. Most of the claims against the Government are based on no more than assertion and it would be irresponsible of the Government if it did not seek to establish the merits of each case.

(3) The Government has already established the Special Administrative Scheme and the Act of Grace Payments scheme as a non-adversarial mechanism for addressing claims arising from the Tests. These schemes together with the compensation provisions under the COMCARE Act enable all claims to be assessed fairly and equitably outside the courts.
